title: 1,000 Jet employees stage protest to demand salaries in Mumbai
og_title: 1,000 Jet employees stage protest to demand salaries in Mumbai
content: MUMBAI: Around 1,000 Jet Airways employees staged a protest rally on Wednesday and submitted a written complaint to the police against the airline management over non-payment of salaries. The police are yet to register an FIR. The protest rally by the All India Jet Airways Officers and Staff Association began at 11am from Terminal 2 of Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport and concluded at Sahar police station, Andheri East, at 1.30 pm. "We are inquiring into the matter and checking whether an FIR can be registered or not," a senior police officer told TOI. On April 12, the association inquired with the company management at Siroya Centre in Andheri about the outstanding salaries of the employees. "Our primary concern was the board of directors should not leave the country and some action should be taken to prevent it. Also, outstanding salaries and wages should be paid," said Kiran Pawaskar, president of the employees' association. On April 25, a meeting was held between the association members and the airline CEO with representatives from the HR department of the airline in attendance. The association was informed that payments for outstanding salaries and wages cannot be made immediately. "We believe this is a criminal offence. The police must investigate thoroughly," said Pawaskar.

title: Farmers protest against MNC’s FIRs against potato growers in Gujarat
og_title: Farmers protest against MNC’s FIRs against potato growers in Gujarat
content: MUZAFFARNAGAR/ BIJNOR: Hundreds of farmers under Bhartiya Kisan Union gathered at Collectorate and protested against the recent FIRs filed against potato farmers in Gujarat by PepsiCo . National spokesperson of BKU, Rakesh Tikait said, “All these FIRs are fraudulent and against the rights of the farmers.” The company’s Indian subsidiary had filed a suit against the farmers last month and later, offered to drop the case if farmers agreed to follow the company's authorized cultivation programme. On Wednesday, a large number of BKU workers staged a dharna at the collectorate in district Muzaffarnagar against PepsiCo. Farmer outfit warned that the protest against the multinational company will continue and BKU workers will remove company’s hoardings from the District. BKU workers burnt several products of PepsiCo during the protest. Tikait said, “Farmers have a right to produce any crop which benefits them. In Gujarat, PepsiCo filed cases against potatoes farmers which is totally wrong and illegal. BKU will fight against this company.” During the agitation in Bijnor, farmers brought bottles of soft drink, Pepsi and emptied its contents as a mark of protest. Farmers handed over a memorandum to district magistrate, Sujeet Kumar while addressing it to the President of India. They demanded withdrawal of cases lodged against potato farmers in Gujarat. Farmers threatened the company that if the company fails to withdraw the cases, they will stage a huge protest in UP and other states. PepsiCo India sued farmers in Gujarat for alleged 'rights infringement' for growing FC-5 potatoe variety used to manufacture the popular Lay's potato chips.

title: Sudan protest leaders insist no civilian administration without rebels
og_title: Sudan protest leaders insist no civilian administration without rebels
content: KHARTOUM: Sudanese protest leaders insisted Thursday that the civilian administration they intend to establish must include representatives from armed groups who spent years battling Khartoum during the regime of ousted leader Omar al-Bashir . "We will not have a transitional (civilian) structure without representatives from the armed groups," said Khalid Omar Yousef, a leader from the Alliance for Freedom and Change umbrella group which has led the protest movement. He did not name specific armed groups. Since 2003, Sudan has been rocked by rebellions in Darfur , South Kordofan and Blue Nile regions. Tens of thousands of people have died in those areas since ethnic minority rebels picked up arms against the Arab-dominated forces of Bashir, accusing his administration of political and economic marginalisation. In recent years, the violence has waned as rebels and Khartoum reached a series of ceasefires, but none of the rebel groups joined a civilian administration during Bashir's iron-fisted rule. Many Darfuris feel that their demand for justice for Bashir-era officials should be a bigger priority for protest leaders. Three armed groups are currently part of the Alliance for Freedom and Change which spearheaded protests since December that led to the ouster of Bashir. The Alliance is now demanding that the military council which took Bashir's place be replaced by a joint civilian-military council, although they say the number of members is yet to be finalised. On Thursday protest leaders presented the council with a proposal for the new civilian structures they want see rule the country. Protest leader Satea al-Haj told reporters that the transitional civilian government should be of 17 ministers, while the legislative body should include 120 to 150 members. He said the alliance was expecting a response from the military council in "48 to 72 hours".

title: Thousands protest again against ruling elite in Algeria
og_title: Thousands protest again against ruling elite in Algeria
content: ALGIERS: Thousands of protesters rallied peacefully in Algiers after Friday prayers, chanting "We will not shut up!" and demanding the departure of Algeria 's ruling elite a month after the downfall of President Abdelaziz Bouteflika . Weeks of demonstrations forced Bouteflika out of office on April 2 after 20 years in power. Protesters have continued mass demonstrations every Friday, demanding other members of the country's elite also give way. They are calling for the resignation of the interim president, Abdelkader Bensalah, who is serving for 90 days until an election on July 4, and of Prime Minister Noureddine Bedoui, appointed by Bouteflika days before he stepped down. "You must go" and "Thieves you have destroyed the country", read banners held up by protesters. The army remains the most powerful institution in Algeria, having swayed politics from the shadows for decades. It has so far patiently monitored the mostly peaceful protests that at times have swelled to hundreds of thousands of people. Last week the army chief of staff, Lieutenant General Ahmed Gaed Salah - who helped push out Bouteflika after having him declared unfit for office - said several big corruption cases would come to light in a crackdown on graft. A number of figures from the ruling elite including the finance minister, former prime minister and several rich businessmen have come under investigation in recent weeks.

title: Villagers protest over death of Gujjar youth
og_title: Villagers protest over death of Gujjar youth
content: JAIPUR: Villagers of Manaksas in Jhunjhunu staged a protest over alleged murder of a Gujjar youth , demanding compensation as well as job for the victim’s family. One of the protesters who pelted stones on the vehicle of a district administration official was arrested by the police. Local authorities have also arrested two in the murder case. The Gujjar youth has been identified as Madan Lal who was allegedly beaten to death on Tuesday night by four men. Jhunjhunu police as arrested two accused in the case, but the villagers refused to let the autopsy of the victim’s body be done till their demands were met. After reassurances by the officials, the post-mortem was finally conducted on Wednesday evening. Gaurav Yadav, SP, Jhunjhunu said, “Madan Lal was allegedly beaten to death by youths of higher community during a brawl on Tuesday night. We arrested two of them and are looking for the others. The locals, however, were demanding compensation and job for the victim’s family and when the district administration official visited the protester’s, one of them pelted stones at the vehicle. We arrested one individual as well.” Madan Lal (25) worked in Nagar Nigam Udaipur and had come on leave when the incident happened. “We assured the protesters that all accused will be arrested soon and if there is any provision for their other demands, then the concerned authorities will do the needful. For now the matter has been resolved,” added Yadav. A case under IPC section 302 (murder) has been registered. The victim’s body was handed over to the family after postmortem.

title: DUTA protest over age of retirement
og_title: DUTA protest over age of retirement
content: NEW DELHI: Members of Delhi University Teachers Association (DUTA) staged a black flag protest on Wednesday, as the university celebrated its foundation day. The teachers were protesting against the fact that the university has refused to intervene in the matter of two colleges - Vivekanand College and Shyamlal (E) College - issuing letters to the associate professors of physical education informing them that they would be retiring at 62 years of age instead of 65. DUTA members have been protesting day and night outside the residence of DU vice-chancellor, Yogesh Tyagi, since April 23. The association has decided to intensify its protest dharna with a relay hunger strike that will begin on 2nd May. It will hold a public meeting in which students, karamcharis and leaders of political parties will be invited to participate.

title: Student's death sparks protest in Chinhat
og_title: Student's death sparks protest in Chinhat
content: LUCKNOW: A 22-year-old student of a private engineering institute was mowed down by a Rae Bareli-bound Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) bus on Faizabad Road in Chinhat on Thursday. Incensed over the incident, students of another private institute in the area vandalized the bus and blocked the traffic for about 30 minutes. Police said at around 1 pm, Utkarsh Singh (22), a BTech (III) student and a resident of Barabanki, left the institute on his two-wheeler. When he was taking a turn in front of his college on the main Faizabad road, a speeding UPSRTC bus coming from the side of Polytechnic crossing hit him from the front. The bus driver and the conductor managed to flee after the accident. In the meantime, students of another college assembled at the scene and rushed a profusely bleeding Utkarsh to a nearby private hospital, from where he was referred to Lohia hospital. He later succumbed to his injuries. As the news spread, a mob of students gathered at the spot and vandalized the bus. They also blocked the main Faizabad road for over half an hour. Some commuters dialled UP 100 after which a police force led by SHO Chinhat Sachin Singh reached the spot and pacified the students to lift the blockade. "An FIR under the charges of causing death by negligence and rash driving has been registered against the driver who is on the run. The vehicle has been seized and will be sent for technical inspection," Singh told TOI.

title: Exercise 'maximum restraint' while dealing with protesters: Cong's Mir after Shopian encounter
og_title: Exercise 'maximum restraint' while dealing with protesters: Cong's Mir after Shopian encounter
content: JAMMU: Expressing concern over the "volatile situation" in Jammu and Kashmir 's poll-bound Shopian district after an encounter between security forces and militants, Congress leader G A Mir on Friday asked law enforcing agencies to exercise "maximum restraint" while dealing with protesters. Three unidentified militants were Friday killed in the encounter, following which clashes broke out between protestors and law enforcing personnel near the site of the gunfight after some people hurled stones at the security forces engaged in the anti-militancy operation, according to officials. Two persons suffered minor pellet injuries in the security forces' action. "We express anguish over the prevailing situation in Shopian district of south Kashmir in the backdrop of the gunfight at Adkhara village in the district. Security forces should exercise maximum restraint while dealing with protestors," said Mir, who is contesting elections as the Congress's candidate from the Anantnag Lok Sabha seat. Pulwama and Shopian districts are a part of the constituency which will see polling on May 6. In a statement, the Jammu and Kashmir Congress president also expressed serious concern over the "extremely volatile situation" prevailing in Shopian district. The atmosphere can be vitiated to a largest extent in case of civilian casualties and this can become a major setback to peace and tranquillity in south Kashmir, he said and asked security forces to exercise restraint. Efforts must be made to restore calm in the district rather than spraying pellets and bullets, Mir said. He appealed to the people, especially the youth, to maintain peace and not to confront security forces as that will create more problems in the district.

title: Maduro hangs on as Venezuelan protests peter out
og_title: Maduro hangs on as Venezuelan protests peter out
content: CARACAS: Venezuelans heeded opposition leader Juan Guaido 's call to take to the streets on Wednesday in a bid to force President Nicolas Maduro from power, but there was little concrete sign of change in a crisis that increasingly looks like a political stalemate. Guaido had called for the "largest march" in Venezuela's history and said on Twitter that "millions of Venezuelans" were in the streets in "this final phase" of his move to oust Maduro. But by late afternoon, many of the protesters in the capital Caracas had drifted home. National Guards fired tear gas at a hardcore of demonstrators who remained, and one injured demonstrator was carried by others to a first aid truck, Reuters video showed. Local rights organizations said a young woman died in surgery after being shot in the head during a protest in Caracas . Guaido confirmed via Twitter that a woman died after being shot. The standoff in Venezuela increased tensions between the United States and Russia, who accused each other of interference in the OPEC-member nation's affairs. Despite Guaido's calls for the military to support him, the armed forces leadership has so far remained loyal to Maduro, who has been in power since his mentor, the late President Hugo Chavez, died in 2013. "If the regime thought we had reached maximum pressure, they cannot even imagine," Guaido told thousands of cheering supporters. "We have to remain in the streets." It was unclear what more Guaido can do at this point. The Venezuelan opposition has often staged huge street protests against Maduro but failed to dislodge him despite a deep economic recession and hyperinflation. Demonstrators said they were prepared for the process of ousting Maduro to last a long time. "We need to keep going," said Laila Amezquita, a 52-year-old nurse from Caracas' downtown Candelaria district. "In three months Guaido's been able to do what they have not done in 20 years, and one has to be patient." Others are frustrated that nothing has changed more than three months after Guaido, head of the opposition-run National Assembly, invoked the constitution to assume an interim presidency, arguing that Maduro's 2018 re-election was illegitimate. Guaido is recognized as Venezuela's legitimate head of state by the United States, the European Union and others, while Maduro is backed by countries including Russia, China, and Cuba. U.S.-RUSSIA FRICTION Those fault lines are increasingly putting Venezuela at the heart of global geopolitical tensions. U.S. President Donald Trump 's administration has imposed sanctions on the Maduro government and refused to rule out military intervention, although it says it prefers a peaceful transition. "Military action is possible. If that's what's required, that's what the United States will do," U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told Fox Business Network. The Pentagon appeared to downplay any active preparations to directly intervene in Venezuela, but acknowledged detailed contingency planning. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov told Pompeo on Wednesday that further "aggressive steps" in Venezuela would have grave consequences, Russia's Foreign Ministry said. In turn, the United States has accused Moscow of interfering in the South American country, an ally of Russia since the time of Chavez. Pompeo said Maduro had been expected to flee the country on Tuesday but Russia convinced him to stay, which the Kremlin has denied. White House national security adviser John Bolton, a foreign policy hawk, said Moscow's involvement was not welcome. "This is our hemisphere," he told reporters outside the White House. "It's not where the Russians ought to be interfering. This is a mistake on their part. It's not going to lead to an improvement of relations." TEST FOR GUAIDO Maduro retains control of state institutions and the loyalty of the armed forces, frustrating Guaido's bid to assume the day-to-day functions of government, which he says would be a prelude to calling new elections. Seeking to appeal to Maduro's traditional base among the working class, Guaido said on Wednesday he would consider a proposal from public workers to call for a series of stoppages leading up to a general strike. Carlos Alberto, a 70-year-old small-business owner, draped in a Venezuelan flag at the Caracas protest, said: "We are tired of this regime, that has brutally impoverished us. My children and almost all my family have already left Venezuela. ... We know that if it's not today, it will be tomorrow, because this has to end." Venezuelan living standards have declined even further in the first several months of the year, with blackouts and water shortages adding to hyperinflation and chronic shortages of food and medicine that have prompted millions to emigrate. Triple the usual daily number of Venezuelans fled across the border to Brazil on Tuesday, Brazilian government data showed. Maduro, who says Guaido is a puppet of the United States seeking to orchestrate a coup, also called a march on Wednesday. In a speech to supporters gathered near the Miraflores presidential palace, Maduro said he recognized the need for "big changes within the Bolivarian revolution." He did not give details. Traveling to the pro-Maduro rally, educator Mercedes Martinez called Guaido a "lapdog" and said: "The empire wants to smother us, cut off our head and colonize us. ... The people of Venezuela are defending Venezuela."

title: Chandigarh: Protest over felling of 700 trees for a flyover project
og_title: Chandigarh: Protest over felling of 700 trees for a flyover project
content: CHANDIGARH: A group of green activists protested in the city for felling of some 700 trees to bring about a flyover connecting Zirakpur to Tribune Chowk . UT Engineering department is handling the project which is being funded by National Highway Authority of India. TOI tried to contact chief engineer , Mukesh Anand , by calling and texting him message to take his version on the matter, but he did not respond. Gunjan Rastogi, member of organisation ‘Watch the Footprint’ said, “None of us is anti-development but we want a model of sustainable development where both development and our environment can co-exist with each other. The concerned department must see if they can make changes in the project to save the trees.” Ravinder Nath, who is involved with organisation Environment Society of India is disappointed with the lack luster attitude of the officials. “It is unfortunate that administration does not pay heed to the outcry of public protest for saving trees felling . We staged similar protests against felling of trees when a flyover project near KC theatre was conceived but it was enforced ultimately .” However there are hopes that authorities may not be able to push the matter under the carpet anymore. Rajnish Watts, former principal of Chandigarh College of Architecture and member of Chandigarh Heritage Committee and president of Chandigarh Tree Lovers told TOI, “It was a year ago , a team of UT Engineering department had discussed the project with the members of Chandigarh Heritage Committee where they had assured us minimum felling of trees without exactly divulging the numbers exactly. Since the matter is now before media talking about felling of large number of trees , we will soon hold a meeting with the department to get to know the reality from them.” Talking about the two species of old trees Arjan and Mango which have been earmarked fro felling, he said that Arjan trees existed either near airport and Tribune access point and in sector 27 only in the city while mango orchards have already been shrunk to build Industrial area where most of this buffer zone is already gone. On the issue of building flyover in the city, he said, flyover is not the full-proof answer to the problem of traffic increase as it resolves the problem at one point only. Madhu Sareen, prominent environmentalist took up the debate further saying, “Flyover create nuisance for the pedestrians and create mess on the road. This is the reason in European countries , they are doing away with flyovers. In city like London, where I lived for 10 years, they made public buses so comfortable and convenient and plying private cars so expensive that people used public transport. Therefore , instead of flyover which do not serve much purpose and involves lots of costing, we must rather invest in strong network of good public buses to meet the demand of a small city like Chandigarh.”

title: Protesters ransack SP office in Arunachal Pradesh
og_title: Protesters ransack SP office in Arunachal Pradesh
content: ITANAGAR: Tension prevailed at Koloriang in Kurung Kumey district of Arunachal Pradesh on Monday after a group of protesters , mostly women, attacked the SP office there demanding immediate arrest of the killer of Papu village gaonburha (headman) Bengia Tamang. Infuriated over the lackadaisical attitude of the police, particularly the SP, the agitators demanded suspension of the SP, a source said. Later, the protesters broke into the SP's office and ransacked office furniture, computers and racks. They also marched towards DC Santosh Kumar Rai's office and locked the main entrance gate. Confirming that the protesters were demanding early arrest of the culprit, the DC said he has assured them of doing the needful. Bengia Welfare Society, in a representation to DC on April 26 last, had placed the same demand. On the other hand, a bundle of gelatin sticks was recovered from the Koloriang helipad on Sunday morning, a source said, adding that helicopters transporting EVMs after repolling could have been targeted. Sporadic poll-related violence was witnessed in this district since the announcement of election dates. A car on election duty was burnt down in a place between Kurung Bridge point and Parsi Parlo road by miscreants on Sunday. On the other hand, supporters of Palin BJP candidate Balo Raja have urged the CEO to ensure foolproof security of EVMs of Kurung Kumey and Kra Daadi district at Koloriang.

title: MP: Boy injured as mobile phone bursts in Mandsaur village
og_title: MP: Boy injured as mobile phone bursts in Mandsaur village
content: INDORE: A boy sustained injuries on his hand when a mobile phone, kept for charging, burst in Sasari Piplia village of Mandsaur district on Tuesday. The incident took place when parents of Vishal Suryavanshi , were out working on a farmland and had kept their phone on charging mode in their home, Sitamau police said. The boy was apparently playing with the phone, when it burst, they said, adding he was rushed to a hospital in Sitamau and later referred to Ujjain. The police were unable to ascertain the model of the phone used by child’s father Mohan Suryavanshi. Doctors at hospital in Ujjain claimed that the boy has received injuries on his left palm and was being treated. He was out of danger.

title: Satra row: Students turn up with black badges in protest
og_title: Satra row: Students turn up with black badges in protest
content: GUWAHATI: Situation turned tense in Auniati High School at Majuli , the revered seat of Assamese culture and a hub of neo-Vaishnavism on Monday, as a section of students boycotted class and joined protest in support of the school headmaster, who is facing a probe for cutting off the hair of 17 students, defying a 500-year-old neo-Vaishnavite practice. Controversy spurted in the school on Saturday, after headmaster Prashanta Dulakashariya forcefully trimmed hair of the students, who, being the followers of the traditions of the satras or Vaishnavite monasteries in Assam , kept long hair. While the satra fraternity wants action against the school headmaster Prashanta Dulakashariya, many other students and their guardians stood by the school head. The Majuli district unit of the All Assam Students' Union, on the other hand, is adamant on suspension of Dulakashariya. At the call of district unit of the students' body, school children in different schools across Majuli came to their classes wearing black badges on Monday. The Majuli district administration is conducting a probe into the matter through the district inspector of schools, but it's yet to reach a conclusion. Considering the gravity of the matter and its religious implications, officials from the state directorate of secondary education has also reached Majuli on Monday. "We are duty-bound to maintain peaceful conduct of classes in the school. But, unless the inquiry is completed, we cannot take action against anyone," said Majuli deputy commissioner, Debaprasad Misra.

title: Mormugao council drivesees protest
og_title: Mormugao council drivesees protest
content: VASCO: While the staff of Mormugao Municipal Council (MMC) were clearing the footpath encroachments by the businessmen in Vasco , an owner of store threatened them to kill herself if her items were touched by them. The police had to intervene and get the sitiation under control. During the drive several items worth around Rs 50,000 were seized. MMC chief officer Agnelo Fernandes said that at any cost the encroachment shall not be tolerated by the municipality. Fernandes will file a police complaint against the woman.

title: Student protests lead to partial shutdown of HNBGU
og_title: Student protests lead to partial shutdown of HNBGU
content: DEHRADUN: Two days after over 150 persons including several students of Hemvati Nandan Bahuguna Garhwal University (HNBGU) were booked under various sections of the Indian Penal Code for “holding the entire university staff hostage” , the members of various student unions of HNBGU continued their agitation on Monday leading to a partial shutdown of the varsity. The protests, which were in support of terminated outsourced employees who were fired by the university sometime back, not only disturbed classes but also led to the cancellation of practical exams. In a further embarrassment for the university authorities, the agitating students disrupted a workshop organised by a private education society in the varsity campus which was being attended by delegates from across India. Meanwhile, the university registrar threatened to lodge a police complaint against agitating students if their protest continued to impact the academic session. Talking to TOI, Annpurna Nautiyal, acting vice-chancellor of the university said that the student union members were “protesting for something that has nothing to do with them.” “They are protesting for the employees of a third-party agency and we are not at all associated with these employees. Their protest is illogical and this is the reason we are finding it difficult to pacify them,” she added. However, countering the VC’s claim, Ayush Miyan, president of Jai Ho group (a student union), told TOI that the students are not only fighting for the permanent appointment of outsourced employees but also for 15 other major demands that includes proper exams, timely results and scrutiny of the answer-sheets. “We have decided to fight for the outsourced employees because the university didn’t even bother for those class-4 employees who have been serving here since decades. All of these outsourced employees are poor locals of Srinagar and it is their right to get permanent position in the institution they have been working in,” said Miyan.

title: Bullock cart owners stage novel protest to reopen sand quarries
og_title: Bullock cart owners stage novel protest to reopen sand quarries
content: TRICHY: Aggrieved owners of bullock carts resorted to ‘Kanji Thotti’ (gruel centre) protest near Trichy district collector office insisting on reopening of sand quarries for them, here on Monday. Lamenting that the closure of the quarries in River Cauvery and Kollidam took a toll on their livelihood, as many as 500 men and women took part in the novel protest. The protestors served the gruel among themselves to underline that they were on the verge of poverty due to the closure of the exclusive sand quarries for the bullock carts which met the demands of the construction units in local areas. Being the residents of Kambarasampettai, Muthrasanallur, Pazhoor, Murungapettai and few others villages in Trichy, their livelihood was dependent on sand mining in government permitted quarries. The closure of the quarries following the Madurai bench of Madras high court ban put their income at stake since August 2018. With scarcity for river sand on the rise due to the closure of many quarries in Cauvery and Kollidam rivers, sand cart carried a small amount of sand from the permitted limited places and supplied them to local areas for construction purposes. The quarries allotted for the bullock carts were also closed gradually forcing them to stage protests for the past one year. As per the agreement signed at the peace meeting a few months back, it was assured to run the quarry at Ariyur across Kollidam River and at Keezha Mullaikudi across Cauvery River. Yet, the officials failed to keep up their promise prompting them to jump into a protest on Monday. As their protest gained momentum, the district administration held talks with them and assured to open the quarries soon after the lifting of model code of conduct (MCC) on May 23, 2019. Following which the protesters dispersed.

title: Nagpur University to reconduct engineering paper after students protest
og_title: Nagpur University to reconduct engineering paper after students protest
content: NAGPUR: After intense protest from the aggrieved students , Nagpur University has decided to reconduct a paper of engineering faculty but has not confirmed new dates. According to the aggrieved students, the paper of ‘Network Analysis and Synthesis (NAS)’ held on April 15 was partially “out of syllabus”. These questions amounted to almost 35-40 marks which are essential to clear any examination. They claimed that such happenings are regular in NU nowadays but the office bearers from its exam section are not ready to accept their blunders. It often leads to many of them failing in the exams. Even this paper would have met the same fate had senior Senate member Manmohan Bajpayee wouldn’t have come to support the students. Board of Examination and Evaluation (BoEE) director (officiating) Anil Hirekhan confirmed to TOI that they have decided to reconduct the examination of ‘Network Analysis and Synthesis (NAS)’, but refused to comment further. When asked on whether the NU panel had recommended it and how many questions were “out of syllabus”, he said, he will talk to media on Wednesday. Earlier, the students came to meet pro-VC Pramod Yeole and submitted a representation signed by many demanding rescheduling of the paper. The pro-VC had told TOI last week that they were examining the issue and would take any decision appropriately. The harried students claimed that in the April 15 paper, two units — frequency selective networks and filters and attenuators — were not covered. On the other hand, there were four questions from first unit despite there being a rule that only two questions can be given from a particular unit. “This disruption in the question paper pattern completely changes the importance of a specific topic which was evened out by the rules,” they said. The students complained that they can’t be expected to solve questions which were out of their curriculum. “All the discrepancies, if combined, amounted to at least 35-40 marks. Due to the mismanagement of the college, we are suffering ultimately and fear of failing in the paper. Re-examination is only alternative now to save our precious academic careers,” they said. NU exam section officials earlier said that out of the many students who appeared for the examination, only a few were seeking re-examination, which puts them in a difficult position. They claimed that in such cases, a conclusive measure could be drawn out only after the correction of the question papers. After evaluating the difficulty faced by students in attempting the paper, NU will come out with an answer to whether a re-examination is needed or not, they said.

title: Kolkata: Protest over patient refusal
og_title: Kolkata: Protest over patient refusal
content: KOLKATA: Locals on Monday night blocked Gobinda Auddy Road in Chetla alleging two government hospitals of denying medical treatment to Bappi Das (43), a resident of Chetla. Kolkata Municipal Corporation mayor Firhad Hakim, who is the councillor from the ward, intervened and Das was taken to a private hospital off EM Bypass. According to relatives, Das, a driver by professsion, has been suffering from cardiac problems. "For two weeks, we have been shuttling between two hospitals. We resorted to the road blockade out of desperation. We are thankful that Hakim stepped in and helped us," said a relative.

title: Just 15 get to enter fray, farmers protest
og_title: Just 15 get to enter fray, farmers protest
content: HYDERABAD: About 100 turmeric farmers and a large group of fluorosis victims and activists were in for disappointment on Monday as they were unable to file nominations in Varanasi, against PM Narendra Modi . Only 15 farmers and two activists could file papers as they were unable to produce 10 proposers each. A candidate from a recognised national or state party needs one proposer while an independent needs 10 proposers at the time of nomination. The proposers must be from the constituency the candidate wishes to contest from. On Monday, the last date for filing nominations for Varanasi which goes to the polls on May 19, only 15 farmers from Telangana and Tamil Nadu were able to file their nominations. Those turned away staged a dharna in front of the Varanasi collectorate and threatened to take the matter to EC. “They have imposed rules which are not prescribed by the EC. They insisted that we physically present the 10 proposers and that their mere signatures or thumb impressions will not do. This is not part of the rules and the whole move appears to have been created to prevent us from contesting,” said Deivasigamani PK, a farmer from Tamil Nadu and president of Turmeric Farmers Association. The farmers said they were hounded by local authorities for three days and not allowed to get local proposers. “Officials insisted we physically present proposers. Though we did arrange for proposers, they were not allowed to enter the premises,” said Kotapati Narasimham Naidu, Turmeric Farmers Association president from Telangana.

title: Telangana: Police foil ‘chalo BIE’ rally, Opposition claims maha success
og_title: Telangana: Police foil ‘chalo BIE’ rally, Opposition claims maha success
content: HYDERABAD: Police foiled the ‘chalo TSBIE’ rally planned by opposition parties here on Monday by effecting large-scale arrests of leaders and keeping them under house arrest since Sunday midnight. However, Congress and other parties said their maha dharna was a grand success as they thwarted attempts by the TRS government to suppress their voice. State BJP president K Laxman, who launched an indefinite hunger strike outside the party office in the morning in protest against the Intermediate exam results fiasco, was taken away by police and later admitted to a hospital. Preventive arrests were largely made in Hyderabad, Rangareddy and almost all other districts. The leaders condemned the ‘dictatorial’ attitude of chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao for suppressing their voice against failures of his government. They said the government cannot wash its hands of the muddle by taking action against ‘small fish’ while leaving out the ‘big fish’ responsible for the goof-up and suicides by students. AICC secretary V Hanumantha Rao threw a challenge at TRS working president KT Rama Rao to come to Peddamma temple in Jubilee Hills on Tuesday and swear on goddess that he does not know Globarena technologies as claimed by him during an interaction with the citizens on Twitter. Former minister J Geetha Reddy said she along with other women leaders were bundled into a van by male cops. “It is highly condemnable,” she said and demanded that names of politicians who had connection with Globarena Technologies be made public and education minister G Jagadish Reddy be sacked. CLP leader Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka, who is touring assembly constituencies of Congress MLAs who have defected to TRS, said: “The government is focusing on purchasing MLAs as a result of which it does not have control over BIE that had resulted in the goof-up.”

title: BJP calls for state bandh on May 2
og_title: BJP calls for state bandh on May 2
content: Hyderabad: The BJP has called for a state-wide bandh in Telangana on May 2 to protest the state government’s attitude on the intermediate examinations results issue. The party has planned a series of protests after its state president K Laxman, who had undertaken an indefinite fast, was forcibly shifted to the Nizam’s Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS) in the city. On April 30, the BJP will lay siege to the CM’s camp office ‘Pragathi Bhavan’, launch protests in all towns and districts, and take out a rally in Secunderabad. On May 1, rallies will be taken out by the BJP Kishan Morcha, Yuva morcha and allied bodies across the state. This will be followed by a state bandh on May 2.

title: Services hit as Chennai metro rail employees stage protest
og_title: Services hit as Chennai metro rail employees stage protest
content: CHENNAI: Metro rail services were delayed after employees staged a protest at the administration office in the evening, demanding that the management restore eight employees who were terminated on various grounds. The employees downed the signalling system and damaged a fire alarm at Thirumangalam station throwing services out of gear. Commuters complained that trains were delayed for 10 minutes and there was no information about services displayed on information boards at stations late in the evening on Airport to Central and Washermenpet to Airport lines. Commuters had to wait more than 25 minutes for a train at Airport metro station. "A train, which left the station at 8.50pm, took almost an hour to reach Ekattuthangal station. The train waited for 10 minutes at each station and there were no announcements," said Gayathri Srinivasan, a commuter. "Many people who had reached the metro station from the airport had to look for other modes of transport as there was no information about trains," said a commuter. Trains on the DMS to airport line didn't have station display inside coaches and no announcements inside trains and at stations. Trains also halted longer at stations. Services to Central and Mannady were stopped after 10pm. "I boarded a train at Nehru Park to Mannady. It was delayed by 20minutes. At Central, staff said trains were not running beyond Central and refunded the ticket fare. Women commuters suffered as there were not many cabs and the available ones were showing surge pricing," said K Youvanesh. The agitators, who were all permanent staff, claimed that services were disrupted as many staff who were on-duty also joined the protest. Around 200 staff members gathered in front of the administration office and staged a protest after a few of them were not allowed to meet the managing director to discuss termination of employees. An employee, who took part in the protest. said a few off-duty staff members visited CMRL administration office on Monday evening to meet the managing director and request him to conduct an inquiry and restore eight staff members. "The terminated staff had an option of appealing to the MD. But we were not allowed to meet him. So, we staged a protest," he added. "The underlying reason for the termination is that all the eight sacked members were office-bearers in the CMRL workers union." According to CMRL eight staff members, including three technical staff, two station controllers, two traffic controllers and one junior engineer in electricals department were terminated on grounds such as dereliction of duty. "Going by the report of the enquiry officer, their explanation was not satisfactory. Their termination orders were issued on April 26," a metro rail official said. In a statement, CMRL said: "Diploma & ITI staff have been well paid and CMRL has adhered to norms. It is also being highlighted that non executive cadre are provided with wages which are double the market wages, in addition to 5-10% wage hike, which has also been provided. Further higher salaries would mean higher fare for the public, which is not sustainable." The protesters have been called for talks with the labour commissioner on Tuesday.

title: Residents protest seeking closure of liquor outlet in their area
og_title: Residents protest seeking closure of liquor outlet in their area
content: MYSURU: Led by BJP leader and Chamaraja MLA L Nagendra , residents of Lakshmikantha Nagar on Monday staged a protest to pressure local authorities to close a liquor outlet cum bar that recently started operations in the locality. The residents complained that the liquor shop would be a cause of nuisance in the area, which is predominantly a residential locality, and gathered in front of the commercial complex where the establishment in question is operating out of, and demanded its closure. Corporators Lakshmi Shivanna, Subaiah, KV Sridhar, Prema Shankaregowda, Vedavathi, Pramila Bharat were among those who lent support to the residents’ protest. They were joined by former councillors Shivanna and Mahadevappa. The protesters said that the authorities were reluctant to act against the liquor outlet since it was owned by a prominent businessman in Mysuru. “The outlet is situated opposite a park, frequented by the young and old alike. Many of us take our morning and evening strolls in the park. What is more, a school is a stone’s throw away from the liquor store, and students will have to walk past this establishment every day,” the residents said. They added that the commercial complex also housed a provision store, a beauty parlour and other outlets frequented regularly by residents. “Having a liquor store in the same complex will affect our business,” said some of the traders. Chamaraja MLA Nagendra asked authorities to initiate action to shift the liquor outlet to another location at the earliest. “The excise portfolio is handled by chief minister HD Kumaraswamy . He should cancel the wine shop’s licence immediately. If the government does not initiate action, we will hold a massive demonstration in front of the deputy commissioner’s office,” said the BJP leader. In-charge deputy commissioner of excise department in Mysuru Manjunath said that the liquor outlet at the complex in Lakshmikantha Nagar had started operations only after obtaining permission from all the departments. “Owing to opposition from residents and the local MLA, the owner of the outlet has agreed to voluntarily down the shutters of the shop. Necessary measures will be taken to shift the shop to a new location,” Manjunath said.

title: Training next month for government teachers to handle KG classes, protests persist
og_title: Training next month for government teachers to handle KG classes, protests persist
content: CHENNAI: Amid protests and criticism from its teachers, the department of school education will next month begin training them to handle LKG and UKG classes at the newly added anganwadi centres in government schools in the state. “The schools will be begin by June, so it is only apt that we begin the training programme before that, so they can be prepared when the session begins,” said a senior official from the board. In January, the state government had started 2,381 LKG and UKG classes in anganwadi centres inside government school campuses. The move was made to increase enrollment of students in government elementary schools and at the same time offer an alternative to private schools. The department said it would train teachers of classes 1 to 5 to teach kindergarten instead. “There are hundreds of candidates who are trained in montessori courses waiting to be recruited. For teachers handling classes 1 to 5, it will only be a demotion,” said PK Ilamaran from Tamil Nadu Government Teachers Association. “Nobody can learn to handle children in elementary classes in a month’s time and this will only affect the children,” he said. However, officials said that only surplus teachers in schools have been roped in to teach kindergarten and that they have received a detailed list from all principals. The anganwadi workers have also raised concerns about their role, once the teachers are recruited. Workers claim that there is no mention of duties to be performed by the anganwadi workers and that their role would be reduced to assisting teachers, even though most have decades of experience teaching children in the centres. “We are worried that our jobs will be reduced to inspecting mid-day meals,” asked Vasugi Arul, president of the Tamil Nadu Anganwadi Workers Union. “Instead of sidelining us, the authorities must choose eligible, qualified candidates and provide them the required training. Right now there is a lot of confusion,” she said.

title: People protest against PMC project on Pashan hills
og_title: People protest against PMC project on Pashan hills
content: PUNE: Citizens' group Pashan Baner Tekadi Bachav Kruti Samiti has launched a protest against concreting work on hills in Pashan. The group will hold a signature campaign on the hills from 11am to 7pm on Wednesday, protesting the project, which involves the development of a citizens' plaza , an open gym, electrification and bus facilities. A retaining wall is planned to ensure the safety of visitors, as water tankers move through the area regularly. On the social media-based campaign, the group has criticized the concreting work on the hills on the Sus Road side, near the bridge on NH4, despite what they claimed were "regular requests by citizens". Terming the hills the "lungs" and "an important part of the watershed area of Pune", the group has called for their preservation. "We follow rules and pay municipal taxes regularly. If such acts of environmental destruction are undertaken despite repeated objections by citizens, the situation demands firm action by all of us," said Pushkar Kulkarni, a member of the group, adding, "We demand that PMC must immediately cancel all proposals - past, present or future - to carry out any concretization/destruction under the pretence of development, facelift, beautification on Pashan-Baner hills or any other hills in Pune." According the members, they had reached to corporators and PMC to put an end to the work. Local corporator Amol Balwadkar said the civic body was mindful of the biodiversity and the ecological balance of the Baner-Pashan hills while carrying out the work. He said they had consulted environmentalists on this project and even sought suggestions from other stakeholders. "We are not violating any rules or destroying the environment. We are ensuring 100% maintenance of groundwater levels," he said.

title: Thousands take to Hong Kong streets to protest new extradition laws
og_title: Thousands take to Hong Kong streets to protest new extradition laws
content: HONG KONG: Thousands of people marched on Hong Kong's parliament on Sunday to demand the scrapping of proposed extradition rules that would allow people to be sent to mainland China for trial - a move which some fear puts the city's core freedoms at risk. Opponents of the proposal fear further erosion of rights and legal protections in the free-wheeling financial hub - freedoms which were guaranteed under the city's handover from British colonial rule to Chinese sovereignty in 1997. Early estimates suggested several thousand people had joined the march along Hong Kong Island from Causeway Bay to the council in the Admiralty business district. Veteran Hong Kong activist and former legislator Leung Kwok-hung said the government's move risked removing Hong Kongers' "freedom from fear". "Hong Kong people and visitors passing by Hong Kong will lose their right not to be extradited into mainland China," he said. "They would need to face an unjust legal system on the mainland." Some younger marchers said they were worried about travelling to China after the move, which comes just as the government encourages young people to deepen ties with the mainland and promotes Hong Kong's links with southern China. The peaceful marchers chanted demands for Hong Kong's Executive Carrie Lam to step down, saying she had "betrayed" Hong Kong. Some sported yellow umbrellas - the symbol of the Occupy civil disobedience movement that paralysed parts of Hong Kong for 11 weeks in 2014. The proposed changes have sparked an unusually broad chorus of concern from international business elites to lawyers and rights' groups and even some pro-establishment figures. Chris Patten, the last British governor of Hong Kong who handed the city back to Chinese rule in 1997, on Saturday described the move "as an assault on Hong Kong's values, stability and security", government-funded broadcaster RTHK reported. Chief Executive Lam and other government officials are standing fast by their proposals, saying they are vital to plug long-standing loopholes. Under the changes, the Hong Kong leader would have the right to order the extradition of wanted offenders to China, Macau and Taiwan as well as other countries not covered by Hong Kong's existing extradition treaties. As a safeguard such orders, to be issued case-by-case, could be challenged and appealed through the city's vaunted legal system. Government officials have said no-one at risk of the death penalty or torture or facing a political charge could be sent from Hong Kong. Under pressure from local business groups, they earlier exempted nine commercial crimes from the new provisions. The proposals could be passed into law later in the year, with the city's pro-democratic camp no longer holding enough seats to block the move. The government has justified the swift introduction of the changes by saying they are needed so a young Hong Kong man suspected of murdering his girlfriend in Taiwan can be extradited to face charges there. The government's assurances are not enough for Lam Wing-kee, a former Hong Kong political bookseller who said in 2016 he was abducted by mainland agents in the city. Lam left Hong Kong for Taiwan last week, saying he feared being sent back to the mainland under the new laws and his experienced showed he could have no trust in China's legal system. A group of 33 followers of Falun Gong, a religious sect banned in China, flew from Taiwan to Hong Kong on Saturday to join the march but were refused entry to Hong Kong, RTHK reported. Sunday's march comes amid renewed calls for deeper electoral reforms stalled five years ago after Occupy protests. Four leaders of the movement were last week sentenced to jail terms ranging from eight to 16 months, part of a group of nine activists found guilty after a near month-long trial.

title: Sector 48 shopkeepers protest against opening of liquor vends in motor market
og_title: Sector 48 shopkeepers protest against opening of liquor vends in motor market
content: CHANDIGARH: The shopkeepers of Sector 48 motor market staged a protest against opening of liquor vends in the market on Saturday. Shopkeepers blocked the roads for around two hours and called off the protest after police intervention. They are demanding to shift the vends from the market area to some other places. Karan Singh, a shopkeeper said that they were aware that two booths were allotted for liquor vends. They came to know that the two booths have been allotted for liquor vends to open when they saw some workers cleaning up the booths. Upon asking, the shopkeepers came to know that the liquor vends will be opening shortly in the market. Soon, all shopkeepers of the motor market gathered and opposed the opening of liquor vends in the sector. Later, they sat on the road in front of the market and blocked the road. After receiving the information, Sector 49 police reached the spot and told the shopkeepers to call off the protest. Later, the shopkeepers met BJP leaders in their office in Sector 33 and apprised them about the allotment of liquor vends in the market. Shopkeepers said that it is the first time that any liquor vend has been allotted in the motor market. Meantime, residents of Khuda Lahora village gathered in hundreds and protested against the allotment of liquor vend near the bus stop and bank. Gurminder Singh, resident of Khuda Lahora said they had met the owner of shop who had rented it out to a liquor vend owner, around four days ago and requested him to not to allot the same to a liquor vendor. The shop owner had promised the locals that he would not give his shop to a liquor vendor, however, on Saturday, the liquor shop was opened. Anguished upon seeing the liquor shop operating in the area, residents staged a protest against the shop owner. Cops from Sector 11 police station reached the spot and asked them to submit a complaint against the vend. Cops said their complaint will be forwarded to the excise and taxation department. On the assurance of the cops, residents called off the protest.

title: Hyderabad: Daughter-in-law of retired HC judge demands child’s custody
og_title: Hyderabad: Daughter-in-law of retired HC judge demands child’s custody
content: HYDERABAD: Former high court judge N Rammohan Rao’s daughter-in-law Sindhu Sharma, who on Saturday lodged a complaint with the police over dowry harassment against Rao’s family, staged a protest along with her family members and women’s rights activists in front of his house at Jubilee Hills on Sunday, demanding that her husband’s family hand over the custody of her two daughters to her. After seven hours of protest, Rao’s family members handed over Sharma’s 18-month-old daughter to her. On Saturday, based on Sharma’s complaint, a case was registered at Women Police Station (WPS) of Central Crime Station (CCS) under Sections 498-A (subjecting a married woman to cruelty), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 406 (criminal breach of trust) of IPC and Dowry Prohibition Act. Avinash Mohanty, Joint Commissioner of Police, CCS said that the case was registered against retired justice Rammohan Rao, his wife Lakshmi and son Vashista after the latter’s wife Sindhu Sharma lodged the complaint with CCS women’s police station. Sharma alleged that she was physically harassed by her husband. “My husband used to beat me. But few days ago, even my mother-in-law and and father-in-law physically assaulted me. They are trying to portray me as mentally retarded. My elder daughter is still in their custody and I want her back. They are not handing over the elder daughter to me as she will inform the police about the torture,” Sharma said. Child line officials have summoned both the parties to Bharosa Centre on Monday to discuss the custody of the elder daughter.

title: Congress nominee fails to answer queries, faces protest in Sangrur
og_title: Congress nominee fails to answer queries, faces protest in Sangrur
content: PATIALA: The Congress candidate from Sangrur, Kewal Singh Dhillon, faced a spur-of-the-moment protest by the residents of Bahadurpur village in Sangrur district on Saturday, after he could not answer queries on promises made by the Congress before it came to power in Punjab. A video of the protest was in circulation on WhatsApp. However, only the protesters were visible in it and not the Congress leader. The protesters had asked Dhillon about chief minister Amarinder Singh’s failure to meet promises of paying an unemployment allowance of Rs 2,500 per month, eradicating the drug menace in four months, and arresting accused in desecration cases. “We heard his entire speech and later some of us had gone to him to ask him why he had come to beg for votes when his government had failed to meet promises,” said Rajveer Singh, a resident of Bahadurpur Dhillon could not be contacted for comment. An official at Sunam police station, under whose jursidiction the village falls, confirmed the incident, but said no case had been registered as there was no violence or law and order trouble. According to Rajveer, he and a group of youngsters from the village had taken the mic and asked Dhillon about the promises, but Congress workers took the mic away from them. “After this, some other villagers appreciated our step and started raising slogans against Dhillon. We are not against or in favour of anyone, but we will ask these leaders about work done,” Rajveer added.

title: Telangana faces uncertain weather, more farmer protests likely
og_title: Telangana faces uncertain weather, more farmer protests likely
content: When a sudden tropical storm flattened over 100 trees, destroyed homes and killed two persons on Monday evening in Hyderabad, weather trackers realised that there was no warning from the IMD or other weather agencies. The next day, IMD issued a rain alert for three more days, but denizens who set out to work, carrying umbrellas and raincoats, ended up complaining of sweltering heat and humidity. So, are the agencies assigned with the task of tracking weather getting it wrong? Not really, say several leading climate change experts of the country, as predicting weather, which has always been a big challenge, has now become even more difficult. Under the influence of global warming, unusually high temperature at 35.5°C, during mid-February, coupled with rising pollution, generated a lot of moisture in the air, which was released in the form of rain and hailstorms for the past one week. “The weather phenomena are unusual, because suddenly troughs are developing from March 31, due to big increase in temperature and subsequent formation of moisture,” said RV Subba Rao, retired meteorologist, and expert in analysing weather charts. With thunderstorm activity generally starting in the second half of April, denizens in Hyderabad and thousands of farmers were taken aback as hailstorms and heavy rains destroyed 55,000 acres of land, yielding mango and several horticulture crops in Nizamabad, Khammam, Peddapalle, Mancherial, Siddipet, Jagtial and Rajanna-Sircilla districts. Now with a heatwave warning issued for the next two days and a cyclonic storm brewing in the Bay of Bengal, more devastation is on the cards, experts said. Needed better agriculture policy Climate change experts say that the shifting of monsoon is impacting local weather, and local governments must brace for more bad weather. “We have to get ready for some losses and damages. First let us protect people, secondly, it’s important to adapt and change. These days, some farmers are not leaving mangoes in the open. They are covering them with polythene, so that it doesn’t get affected by hail or rain. That’s adaptability, but it’s expensive,” said Sanjay Vashist, expert at Climate Action Network (CAN). Agriculture experts say if farmers don’t get adequate compensation or minimum support price for crop loss, there could be more protests. “Farm agitation will grow in India, as they don’t know what’s hitting them. So, they want minimum support price,” added Vashist. Skymet predicted isolated rains over Telangana this month, but do not expect the weather activity to recur for few more days. Weather experts say rain could be back from May 1 and could have another round of disastrous impact before monsoon. Skymet has doppler radars in Hyderabad and lightning detectors, but they confess that pinpointing exact weather system under the current scenario and sending an alert in advance is difficult. “With time so less in our hands, the administration is not able to take precautionary measures,” chief Skymet meteorologist, Mahesh Palawat, told TOI from Delhi. “While climate and weather pattern are changing, farmers are doing traditional farming. They are not being educated about the new variety of seeds that are weather resilient and climate resilient. The chemicals and pesticides that are banned by government, are still being used,” added Palawat.

title: Police lathicharge protesters vandalizing private hospital after patient’s death
og_title: Police lathicharge protesters vandalizing private hospital after patient’s death
content: ROPAR: Over a dozen people in Ropar district vandalized a private hospital following the death of a woman who was brought there with complaints of high blood pressure and chest pain on Friday evening. The relatives of the patient vandalized the hospital and then resorted to stage protest by blocking the road in Morinda town of the district. Despite the police intervention they did not relent and demanded registration of case against the doctor in charge. Following this, the police lathicharged and cleared the road, leaving some of the protesters injured. The deceased, identified as Sukhdeep Kaur, 45, hailed from Morinda town of Ropar and was brought to the hospital in Morinda on Thursday evening. The doctors claimed they advised the patient’s relatives to shift her to Chandigarh as Sukhdeep’s condition was serious but the family members didn’t agree on it. The family members alleged that doctors, who initially said that Sukhdeep’s condition was stable, asked them to shift her to Chandigarh only when the patient’s condition got deteriorated. By the time they reached the hospital Sukhdeep was already dead and her body was lying in a car. They said the doctors did not even informed them about the death. The family members have demanded an independent probe against the doctors. SS Virk, deputy superintendent of police Morinda, said, “We have registered a case against the accused and arrested one person who was not related to the patient but came there only to vandalize the hospital. The case against doctor will only be registered if he is found guilty by the inquiry team comprising doctors, as per the guidelines of the Supreme Court. The post mortem of the deceased was conducted by a three-member team of doctors.”

title: Protesters ransack govt building, set ablaze governor's effigy in J&K's Kishtwar
og_title: Protesters ransack govt building, set ablaze governor's effigy in J&K's Kishtwar
content: JAMMU: A mob ransacked a government building, damaged several official vehicles and set ablaze an effigy of Jammu and Kashmir Governor Satya Pal Malik in Kishtwar district on Saturday after hundreds of people took to streets to protest against the recent killings of four people, officials said. Sanatan Dharam Sabha (SDS), a local religious group, had called for a peaceful march from its headquarters at Char Chinar to the deputy commissioner's office in the communally sensitive town to lodge their protest against the killings and alleged failure of police to nab the culprits. RSS leader Chandarkant Sharma and his security guard were killed by a terrorist inside the district hospital on April 9, while state secretary of BJP Anil Parihar and his brother Ajeet Parihar were killed in the town on November 1 last year. Raising slogans against the killings, hundreds of people, including women, marched in a procession in the town under police protection, the officials said. On reaching the DC office complex, however, some of the protesters turned violent and set ablaze the effigy of the governor and damaged several official vehicles, they said. They said the mob also broke open the main gate of the multi-storied building and ransacked several rooms, damaging some records. The protesters also tried to force their way into the office of deputy commissioner Angrez Singh Rana but were chased out of the building by policemen without using any force, the officials said. Later, they said the protesters dispersed on their own before the arrival of the reinforcements. Rana said police were directed to exercise restraint to avoid any civilian casualty. "We have taken a serious note of the hooliganism and appropriate action is being taken against the persons involved in it," he told PTI. The deputy commissioner said an FIR was being registered in connection with the incident. "Police are making all efforts to nab the killers," he said, appealing to people to cooperate with the administration to maintain law and order in the district.

title: Greens organize tree walk to protest destruction of trees
og_title: Greens organize tree walk to protest destruction of trees
content: KOCHI: Following the ongoing Shantivanam protests against the cutting down of trees, green activists on Saturday organized a Tree Walk from NGO quarters cross-roads to Ambadymoola road at Thrikkakara. The walk was organized to check out the destruction of trees in the 17 acre land - which contain an estimated 3,000 trees of different varieties - that has been handed over by the state government to Kochi Metro for the construction of a Metro village. “We will meet on May 15 and organize another tree walk to raise awareness. A three-member panel of experts, including ecologist Anita Sharma, former DFO N C Induchoodan and botanist C M Joy will draw up an ecological estimate caused by the destruction of the trees in the area for concrete construction,” said social and environment activist C R Neelankandan. The walkers found waste being dumped all over the place. The activists are planning to submit an ecological damage assessment to the different agencies. “We identified around 25 species in the approachable area. There must be even more. Since a thorn fence has been put up, we couldn’t venture further. We were wondering how such a greenery can be removed off in the name of development,” said ecologist Anita Sharma. She said that when a city is being developed as a Smart city, it is important to have green and open spaces. “This is important for our health which is at stake due to pollution. One index of city development is its greenery. Though right now it is being said in name only.” Former forest official N C Induchoodan said that the only greenery in Thrikkakara municipality in a public space is here in this 17 acres and the destruction of this would be a disaster.

title: Bharat Van gets support from Vidarbha as many associations join protest against road
og_title: Bharat Van gets support from Vidarbha as many associations join protest against road
content: NAGPUR: Consistent efforts of saving Bharat Van from a concrete road is galvanizing the masses into action. To save the long-standing trees, the citizens’ campaign is turning over a new leaf by inviting objections from various organizations. Since about five months, the residents of Bharat Nagar and green activists have been agitating against a proposed road, which threatens to kill age-old trees and a biodiversity habitat at the mini-forest Bharat Van, presently owned by Dr Panjabrao Deshmukh Krishi Vidyapeeth (PDKV). To change the decision of policymakers, the spearheaders of the campaign are seeking objection letters from organizations, which they plan to submit to the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), Nagpur bench of Bombay high court, Union minister Nitin Gadkari and state chief minister Devendra Fadnavis. “The proposed road passing through the green area will cost us around 200 fully-grown trees and almost 500 small trees ageing around 10-12 years. Taking into account the loss to the environment, it is highly recommended that existing adjacent roads should be widened after requisite modification in the development plan,” stated the letter filed by Nagpur Residential Hotels Association. Another letter by NGO Green Vigil Foundation states that cutting hundreds of age-old trees will be a big loss to the city. “Alternate road via Ravi Nagar exists and the need of this proposed road itself is debatable,” it adds. Not just from Nagpur organizations from all across the region have extended support to the campaign. Satpuda Foundation, which works for forest and tiger conservation in Central India, submitted an objection letter stating, “The virgin forest patch near Bharat Nagar is one of the last few green patches left in Nagpur. This green cover actually helps reduce the atmospheric carbon and to fight the climate change. The proposed road by cutting large number of natural old trees is unnecessary, avoidable and against the concept of smart city adopted by the government.” Amravati-based Center for Animal Rescue and Study wrote, “We have studied the area and the road is unnecessary. We request the authorities to rethink their strategy on such unsustainable development.” On May 1, a human chain aiming to be the state’s longest one is being organized at Futala at 7.30am. To gather public participation for the event, a missed call campaign has been organized by the agitators. “We are getting a positive response. Till date, we have received hundreds of missed calls,” they said. Recently, actor-producer Dia Mirza, who is also the United Nations Environment Goodwill Ambassador for India, came forward to support the campaign.

title: Pune biker beats up student for wrong-side protest
og_title: Pune biker beats up student for wrong-side protest
content: PUNE: A biker beat up a 20-year-old engineering student with a wooden stick on Karve Road on Wednesday night, as the latter had objected to his wrong side riding. The Deccan Gymkhana police have registered an offence under sections 324 (voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means) and 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of peace) of the IPC on the basis of a complaint lodged by Chaitanya Bajoria of Kothrud on Thursday. Bajoria is a second year engineering student of a private engineering college in Kothrud. On Wednesday night, Bajoria and his friend were on their way on a bike to the Deccan area to have an ice-cream. While they were on the SNDT Road, they spotted the biker approaching from the Athawale Chowk. “This stretch is prohibited for vehicular entry. Bajoria alerted the biker about the rule,” Deccan Gymkhana police senior inspector Deepak Lagad said. “Instead of stopping, the biker abused Bajoria and his friend and rode towards Karve Road. Bajoria and his friend went ahead, took a right turn from the Athawale Chowk on Law College Road and started plying via Karve Road,” a Deccan Gymkhana police officer said. “By the time they reached near a petrol pump on the road, the biker intercepted them. He forced Bajoria to get down from the bike and started abusing him. After forcing Bajoria to get on to his bike, the suspect started speeding towards one of the by-lanes off Karve Road. He stopped on a by-lane, beat up Bajoria and fled,” the officer said. Bajoria sustained minor injuries. “We have got the registration number of the suspect’s bike and will soon arrest him,” Lagad said. This is not the first instance of wrong-side motorists assaulting people objecting to such road rule violations. In December 2018, the Hadapsar police had arrested a cab driver for attacking a traffic policeman and misbehaving with a woman constable after he was caught for wrong-side driving between Sasanenagar and Kalepadal. The month before, a woman professor was arrested for attacking a traffic constable following a dispute over wrong side driving at the Magarpatta junction.

title: TTV condemns GAIL laying pipeline with police protection, despite farmers’ protest in Cauvery delta
og_title: TTV condemns GAIL laying pipeline with police protection, despite farmers’ protest in Cauvery delta
content: CHENNAI: AMMK general secretary T T V Dhinakaran on Friday condemned the attempts by GAIL to lay its planned gas pipeline, with police protection, in spite of protests and opposition from farmers in Cauvery Delta districts. “The move should be immediately stopped and farmers’ agricultural interests should be accorded its due importance in the delta districts,” Dhinakaran said in a statement. Reacting to reports that police protection has been accorded to help GAIL lay its pipeline for 29 km distance in Naangur region in Sirkazhi taluk of Nagapattinam district , Dhinakaran said the prevailing sentiment in the delta districts is to make it a ‘protected agricultural zone’. “Projects should be for people and people should not be made to suffer for the sake of corporate projects. There is no reason to bring such projects and destroy the lives of people in the delta districts, where agriculture is the lifeline,” Dhinakaran said. “Knowing this pretty well, Amma ( Jayalalithaa ) did not allow such projects to come in. However, the present state government, which calls itself as Amma’s government, does not care for the welfare of the people,” Dhinakaran said. “Both the Centre and the state government should immediately put a stop to such projects. If they don’t do that, the people will teach them the right lesson,” he added.

title: Parents protest outside Education officer for allotment of schools to their kin under RTE
og_title: Parents protest outside Education officer for allotment of schools to their kin under RTE

title: Amravati protests excess reservation demands
og_title: Amravati protests excess reservation demands
content: AMRAVATI: On Thursday evening, the city witnessed a huge rally in protest of the ‘excess reservation’ that allegedly blocks admission to various courses and opportunities of employment and promotions to merit students from the open category. Doctors, engineers, lawyers, chartered accountants, post graduate students of medical colleges and women folks from the open category voluntarily took part in the Dandi stir as the organizers, Anti-excess reservation Ekta Manch, called it. The protesters walked to the collectorate from Nehru Maidan wearing Gandhi caps and displaying banners and placards with slogans ‘Save merit, save nation’ and ‘Murder of merit’. A memorandum, demanding cancellation of ‘excess’ reservation in the state, was submitted to Collector Shailesh Naval. Coordinator of the rally, Dr. Shrigopal Rathi told TOI,” We are not against Constitutional reservation. We are against excess reservation granted to various sections of the society in the state. This decision is depriving merit students from getting admissions to various courses.” Adv. Brajesh Tiwari called for cancellation of excess reservation. “It will effect a forced brain drain as merit students will migrate to other countries for education and jobs as well.” Dr. Atul Alsi said that excess reservation has left only 4% to 5% seats for the open category. “The constitution of India had granted reservations for the first ten years only, but successive governments persisted with them for political gains. Though the Supreme Court has called for limiting reservation to 50%, the Central and state governments have extended it to 78% and with the earmarking system, it has gone up to almost 95%, leaving hardly any room for merit students from the open category. Is it not absurd that there are only 5% seats for the open category whereas there are 95% seats for the reserved category.” In the memorandum submitted to the Collector, the march listed eight demands. Besides cancellation of excess reservation and earmarking system, the other demands included conditional reservation, only one time reservation in education/employment, no reservation in PG courses and in promotions, confining reservation to government schools and colleges only and reservations purely on economic norms and not on the basis of caste.

title: Talks inconclusive, protesters continue stir in Wayanad
og_title: Talks inconclusive, protesters continue stir in Wayanad
content: KOZHIKODE: The landless people, evicted from the encroached vested forestland near the Harrisons Malayalam Limited at Thovarimala in Wayanad, are continuing their agitation in front of the collectorate in Kalpetta , after talks with the district collector remained inconclusive. Their main demand include allocation of two acres each for the people and release of the leaders of the agitation who were arrested under the Forest Act. "We had a round of discussion with the collector and raised our demands. The collector told us that a decision on distribution of land can be taken only with the consent of the cabinet. He promised us to convey the demand to the ministers concerned," said M K Dasan, state general secretary of the CPI-ML (Red Star), which is leading the struggle. "We have also demanded the release of three of our leaders, M P Kunhikanaran, Rajesh Apatt and K G Manoharan, who are now lodged in Vythiri sub-jail. We will consult the leaders about the future course of the agitation once they are freed," Dasan said. Hundreds of people, including tribesmen, encroached and occupied the land at Thovarimala on Sunday. The agitators were later forcibly evicted by the police and forest department officials. They gathered in front of the collectorate and continued their agitation under the All India Krantikari Kisan Sabha.

title: Medical courses by Osmania University faces doctors protest
og_title: Medical courses by Osmania University faces doctors protest
content: HYDERABAD: A doctors’ body has sent a representation to the Telangana State Medical Council ( TSMC ) seeking an inquiry whether the Osmania University has authority to offer medical courses. As per the representation by the Healthcare Reforms Doctors’ Association (HRDA) , the University has been offering 15 post-graduate (PG) diploma and advanced PG diploma healthcare courses (PG diploma in operation theatre technology, cardiac pulmonary physiotherapy, perfusion technology, medical research assistant etc). “A few hospitals are offering PG diploma and advanced PG diploma courses with affiliation to the Osmania University to non allopathic practitioners by collecting huge fee,” the representation said. “This is leading to quackery. As far as we know, all healthcare courses should be affiliated to the health universities only. We request you to enquire whether Osmania University is having legitimate powers to affiliate such health care courses and take necessary action as early as possible,” the representation said.

title: Madhya Pradesh: Mother strangulates two-year-old who did not stop crying, arrested
og_title: Madhya Pradesh: Mother strangulates two-year-old who did not stop crying, arrested
content: INDORE: Infuriated over continuous wailing of her two-and-half year old son, a woman strangulated him with a muffler in Shamgarh town of Mandsaur . The woman named Sonu, wife of one Sanjay Sen, was arrested on Saturday after she admitted to strangulating the kid because she was angry and frustrated over looking after him. According to the police, the incident took place in Melkheda village of Shamgarh on April 13. At around 7am, the kid named Gaurav woke up and started crying.
