His mother first tried to hush him up but when he did not stop crying, she used a muffler to strangulate him. She then informed her family members that Gaurav was not waking up. They rushed him to the civil hospital in Garoth where he was declared brought dead. His father, however, suspected that something was wrong about the child’s death as he was fine a day ago. Doctors conducted a post mortem examination and found that the boy had died of asphyxiation caused by strangulation. After they received information, the police started investigating the matter and while questioning the family members, Sonu was detained. She later accepted committing the crime while claiming that she was frustrated because of the baby. SP Vivek Agarwal said that a case was registered and the accused was produced before the court.

title: Forest officer whips out pistol to quell wage protest
og_title: Forest officer whips out pistol to quell wage protest
content: MUMBAI: A forest officer in Palghar district has landed in the soup after whipping out his service revolver when a group of tribal workers approached him for their pending wages on Wednesday. Photos of Range Forest Officer Dilip Tonde holding a pistol during a heated conversation with the workers have gone viral. While the workers approached Wada police with the photos, no case has been registered. Police said the matter is under investigation and they have they have sought Tonde’s statement. Tonde, in charge of Vikramgad forest division , was given additional charge at Wada around two months ago. On Wednesday, tribals employed on contract basis by the forest department to dig pits to plant saplings approached him for their wages, allegedly pending since December. Sources said the workers, affiliated to the NGO Shramajivi Sanghatana , allegedly tried to barge into Tonde’s office, but as they were not allowed entry, they stood outside and raised slogans. According to the protestors, when Tonde came out to meet them, he whipped out the revolver and threatened them. Bhagyashri Jadhav, who was among the agitators, said Tonde’s action caused a scare among the protesters. Forest officials said that government supplied firearms are given to officers which can be used for self defence. Tonde is believed to have told his seniors that he placed the revolver in his hand to keep away the protesters from assaulting him.

title: Protesters pelt stones at DC’s office in Raichur, police prevent violence
og_title: Protesters pelt stones at DC’s office in Raichur, police prevent violence
content: KALABURAGI/BALLARI: Timely intervention by police stopped a huge protest from turning violent in Raichur on Thursday. Thousands of students were protesting near the deputy commissioner’s office seeking action against culprits involved in the alleged rape and murder of an engineering student reported recently. The girl’s body was found hanging on a hillock on the outskirts of Raichur. When police stopped the agitators from entering the DC’s office by closing its gate, the latter threw water packets, slippers and stones towards the office. One of the stones fell on the district president of Vishwakarma community , Guru Vishwakarma, injuring him. The protesters were reportedly trying to enter the office to submit a memorandum. The rally seeking justice for the 21-year-old student started at Manikprabhu Temple. The protesters comprised women from Jain and minority communities, students and members of AIDSO, SFI, AIDYO, ABVP and Youth Congress. Kannada actors Harshika and Bhuvan, who were also part of the rally, demanded a fair investigation. When a leader of the community — to which the girl belonged — tried to immolate himself, police stopped him from doing so and rushed him to hospital. The agitators later demanded the DC come to the protest venue and receive the memorandum. When the situation was about to go out of control, Raichur DC Sharath B heeded the demand. Police took one person into custody for stone-pelting. In Ballari, District Viswakarma Vikas Vedike held a peaceful protest, condemning the student’s death. 2 cops suspended for refusing to file case Police sub-inspector Mariyamma and constable (writer) Anjaneya, both attached to the Raichur women’s police station, have been suspended for allegedly not registering the girl’s death case initially. CID gets accused to reconstruct scene Criminal Investigation Department (CID) sleuths on Thursday took accused Sudarshan Yadav, 25, to those places he had gone with the engineering student in Raichur on April 13, the day she went missing. CID is probing the alleged rape and murder of the girl, whose decomposed body was found hanging from a tree in a forest on the outskirts of Raichur on April 16. The girl’s mother had filed a complaint accusing Yadav of murdering her daughter after raping her. Raichur police arrested Yadav on April 18 after booking him under sections 376 (rape) and 302 (murder) of IPC. “The accused has been questioned about his relationship with the girl. Her mother had complained that Yadav was harassing and stalking her for a long time, forcing her to skip college. On April 13, the day she went missing, Yadav was seen near her house,” sources said.

title: Protest over railways giving ‘bulk of jobs in Tamil Nadu to north Indians’
og_title: Protest over railways giving ‘bulk of jobs in Tamil Nadu to north Indians’
content: TRICHY: Tamil Desiya Periayakkam has announced a big protest in front of Ponmalai Railway Workshop on May 3 against what it called the discrimination of the railway ministry towards Tamil Nadu. It says that the ministry has been giving preference to people from north India in appointments to vacancies in railway jobs in the state, particularly the Group D posts. While addressing reporters here on Thursday, Tamil Desiya Periyakkam leader P Maniarasan said that the BJP-led central government has been discriminating against Tamil people in many ways, which include providing employment opportunities to the youths in the state. The Union government had been neglecting the youths in providing jobs in the 18 public sector undertakings in the state. Only 10% of the youths in the state are given chance while the remaining 90% are from northern state, he alleged. “Out of the 1,765 candidates who were called for training under the Apprenticeship Act at Ponmalai railway workshop, only 100 were Tamil youths. A total of 300 were inducted in Ponmalai for apprenticeship training, and none of them was from Tamil Nadu. The situation is same in Coimbatore and Chennai as well. Out of the total 2,600 postings, 2,300 candidates were from north India. The Railway Recruitment Cell has been purposely showing discrimination towards the people of the state,” he said. As many as 3,000 employees are working at Ponmalai railway workshop in Trichy. Of them, 50% are from north India. The proportion should be 90% Tamils and 10% others in the public sector units in the state, he said. “The entire coaching centres functioning in north India are stealing jobs from Tamil Nadu. Officials and ministers are part of this conspiracy. This has to be stopped. The vacancies in every public sector unit should be filled with 90% of the candidates from the state where the unit is functioning, Maniarasan said. The Tamil Desiya Periyakkam is organizing the stir to press for its demands. All the like-minded people should participate in the protest safeguard the rights of the Tamil youths, he added.

title: Right to dissent includes right to spill milk on streets: HC
og_title: Right to dissent includes right to spill milk on streets: HC
content: MUMBAI: The right to dissent includes the right to spill milk on the streets in protest , Bombay high court ruled on Thursday. A division bench of Chief Justice Pradeep Nandrajog and Justice Nitin Jamdar closed a suo motu public interest litigation initiated last year following milk protests organised by Swabhiman Shetkari Sanghatana. “The right to dissent and protest will include the right to throw milk belonging to an individual by the individual himself or an association if the act is to draw attention of the public to the producer’s plight,” said the judges. The PIL was filed after a former judge wrote a letter drawing the court’s attention to the protest and wastage of milk. “The letter does not state that the Sanghatana destroyed the milk despite producers of the milk not agreeing (to it),” observed the bench, adding that the “right to protest and lodge one’s dissent in a democratic society” could not be throttled. In July 2018, dairy farmers led by the Sanghatana had launched a protest seeking a hike in milk procurement prices. The farmers were protesting as they were being paid Rs16-20 for a litre of cow milk. At many places, protesters had blocked milk tankers and emptied contents on the road or distributed milk packets free to the public. The four-day blockade was called off after the state agreed to hike the price paid to milk suppliers to Rs25 per litre. The letter had sought action against the Sanghatana for destroying milk to be sold in the open market. Additional government pleader Abhay Patki told the court that a loss was caused as the milk was wasted. The bench said that it was a form of protest. “There may be merit in the point that destruction of a food product is not desirable, but this should be left to the decision of the owner of the food product,” said the judges.

title: Family protests as hospital delays autopsy
og_title: Family protests as hospital delays autopsy
content: TIRUPUR: Relatives and neighbours of a 40-year-old man, who died of cardiac arrest on Friday, staged a protest at the Palladam Government Hospital after the hospital authorities allegedly delayed the postmortem process. The victim, K Saminathan of Pongalur, was working in a knitwear unit at Kaliappa Nagar in Palladam. He had collapsed at a tea shop on Friday morning. Though Saminathan was rushed to the GH, he was declared brought dead. His kin and neighbours staged a protest after doctors said that the time for postmortem process was over. A police team reached the spot and pacified the protesters. Subsequently, postmortem was completed before 6pm.

title: Frequency of Ro-Ro: Kochi residents plan protest
og_title: Frequency of Ro-Ro: Kochi residents plan protest
content: KOCHI: Fort Vypeen Janakeeya Koottayma ( FVJK ) is planning to start agitation if Kochi corporation authorities fail to operate two roll-on roll-off (Ro-Ro) vessels from morning to evening in Fort Kochi-Vypeen sector. As of now, one vessel is operating from morning to evening, while the second one operates only in the afternoon. According to leaders of FVJK, they would wait until the first anniversary of Ro-Ro service for the authorities to act. "It was on April 28, 2018, that the Ro-Ro service was launched by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan. If the corporation authorities don't take any measures to operate two vessels from 6.30am to 9.30pm, we will tread the course of agitation," said FVJK chairman Majnu Komath. "Corporation authorities had cited unavailability of drivers as the reason for not operating two vessels from morning to evening. Now, there are three trained drivers. So, they could start the services throughout the day," he said. There is a long queue of vehicles to enter the Ro-Ro vessels. The rush can be avoided only if both the vessels are operated from morning to evening. Meanwhile, the corporation and Kerala Shipping and Inland Navigation Corporation (KSINC) haven't signed an agreement for operating Ro-Ro vessels in the sector even after one year of starting the service. In the absence of an agreement, insurance company won't be providing compensation in case of any accident occurs. Mayor Soumini Jain had said in a meeting of the council held in March that the local body would take immediate measures to sign the agreement. Then, the mayor had asked the finance standing committee headed by deputy mayor T J Vinod to procure financial statements of Ro-Ro services, which has been operating by KSINC since April 28, 2018, and submit a report after going through it. The mayor also asked the town planning committee to meet and effect changes in it, if necessary. Jain had also said that the council would be convened within seven days for giving nod for the agreement to be signed, but nothing happened so far.

title: Cops clamp down on illegal parking, but lodge FIR against protesters
og_title: Cops clamp down on illegal parking, but lodge FIR against protesters
content: KOLKATA: Cops on Wednesday came down on illegal parking in the neighbourhood of South Point High School , but, in a move that came as a shocker to residents, they also slapped an FIR on “unknown” protesters who hit the streets in the past 48 hours to demand their right to free movement. Protesters had assembled on Cornfield Road and Swinhoe Street on Tuesday, hours after a similar protest on Monday. Cops said the case has been registered under IPC sections 143 (unlawful assembly) and 283 (danger or obstruction in public way or line of navigation). The protesters on Tuesday mostly included senior citizens — more than half of whom were women. “We had a detailed discussion on their problems on Monday. On Tuesday, we had asked them to give us some time. But none of our pleas were heeded and several people — including students — had to suffer in the heat,” said an officer. On Wednesday morning, though, the police tried to put its best foot forward. Officers from the southeast traffic guard stopped illegal parking on Anil Maitra Road, Cornfield Road and Swinhoe Street, allowed open access to Swinhoe Street and clamped around six vehicles that were flouting rules. Locals expressed their satisfaction, but wondered if the same action would be witnessed in the coming days. “It was a good beginning, but this needs to be sustained. The evenings are equally crazy, but the cop presence goes down,” said Kalyan Sen, a local resident. TOI visited the spot in the evening and found sergeants moving in from 5pm, well before the senior school got over. The instructions were clear — no parking that can block the road will be allowed. The police said they were implementing one step at a time in order to reach the “middle path”. “There are thousands of students who study here. We cannot take any hasty decisio. The idea today was to stop illegal parking. We have clamped around half a dozen cars on Wednesday. We put in more men on the road at almost each crossing in and around South Point High School. However, no change of traffic movement has been proposed as yet,” said an officer. The cops said that with two political rallies in the vicinity, there was pressure on both Syed Amir Ali Avenue and Gariahat Road on Wednesday. “However, we went ahead with the enforcement. We acted against only those who had abandoned their vehicles for a long time,” said an officer. Swinhoe Street, too, was two-way all through the day. Not all the students, though, agreed with the “hurried” way in which the rules were implemented. “There are many pool cars waiting for students. When we came to our designated spot, we did not find our car. We had board the vehicle from Bosco Residency after walking some distance in thick traffic. The vehicle was in the middle of the road and we had to jump in. No cop helped us while we were boarding,” said a student, Sutanuka Lahiri. An officer of the Southeast traffic guard said, “The only other solution other than stopping illegal parking is to ask students to walk or have buses pick up and drop off students on a rotational basis. This is one decision that we cannot take since it can have serious repercussions on traffic.”

title: Students to resume protest over error in BCom exam paper
og_title: Students to resume protest over error in BCom exam paper
content: SURAT: In absence of an amicable solution by the authorities of Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU) over the errors in BCom question paper, the aggrieved students plan to revive their agitation which was put on hold due to Lok Sabha elections. Students of third year BCom had protested at the VNSGU campus couple of weeks ago alleging serious errors in the management accountancy question paper of the sixth semester students. The students claimed that due to multiple errors many students were set to lose marks. Following the agitations VNSGU accepted errors in the question paper and offered relaxation. The university acknowledged that some questions had wrong figures. They also found that some questions were out of the syllabus, while a few were lengthy ones that could never be answered in limited time. University in an informal letter informed students that those who attempted those questions will be given full marks and some other relaxations were also announced. But the students are demanding that they be given more relaxations arguing that those who could not understand the erroneous questions, might have not attempted it at all.

title: Four Hong Kong 'Occupy' leaders jailed for 2014 democracy protests
og_title: Four Hong Kong 'Occupy' leaders jailed for 2014 democracy protests
content: HONG KONG: A Hong Kong court jailed four leaders of 2014 pro-democracy protests on Wednesday amid heightened concerns over the decline of freedoms in the China-ruled city nearly five years after activists took to the streets in mass protests. The sentencing of the nine activists followed a near month-long trial that was closely watched as China’s Communist Party leaders have put Hong Kong’s autonomy under increasing strain, stoking concern among foreign governments, rights groups and business people. Law professor Benny Tai, 54, and retired sociologist Chan Kin-man, 60, were both jailed for 16 months for conspiracy to commit public nuisance tied to the protests that paralyzed parts of the Asian financial center for 79 days in late 2014 and became known as the Umbrella Movement. Their sentence had been reduced by two months given their clean criminal record and positive character, Justice Johnny Chan said. Pro-democracy lawmaker Shiu Ka-chun and activist Raphael Wong were both jailed for eight months for inciting public nuisance. “We maintain our determination to achieve universal suffrage ... this won’t change,” Wong shouted out in court as he was taken away. Since the city returned to Chinese rule in 1997, critics say Beijing has reneged on a commitment to maintain Hong Kong’s high degree of autonomy and freedoms under a “one country, two systems” arrangement. The protesters had demanded that China's Communist Party leaders allow genuine universal suffrage in Hong Kong to select its leader. Police cleared the demonstrators in December 2014, and authorities granted no democratic concessions. Chan, in passing sentence, acknowledged the right to civil disobedience and the right of assembly and free speech, but said the protracted road blockages had caused suffering to the public and that some restrictions on freedoms were necessary in a democratic society. Retired pastor Chu Yiu-ming, 75, received a suspended sentence, as did veteran democrat Lee Wing-tat and former student leader Eason Chung, with the judge taking into account their ages, public service and clean records. Another former student leader, Tommy Cheung, was ordered to carry out 200 hours of community service. Tanya Chan, a democratic lawmaker, 47, had her sentencing postponed until June 10, following the discovery of a life-threatening brain tumor that required an operation, she said. Several hundred supporters, many wearing yellow ribbons and holding yellow umbrellas, a symbol of the protests, gathered outside the West Kowloon Law Courts, and later at an evening vigil, demanding the four men be freed. “I’m sad I can’t be in jail with them. It’s their bright moment to enshrine their love of democracy,” said Chu, as the crowds around him cheered and cupped candles in their hands. The trial was considered the most significant legal maneuver by authorities to punish those involved in the 2014 protests, called Occupy Central, in reference to the city’s central business district . The demonstrations were Hong Kong’s biggest and most protracted in recent decades and one of the boldest challenges to China’s leaders since pro-democracy protests in and around Beijing’s Tiananmen Square in 1989. Organizers estimated that more than one million people took part in the protests over nearly three months. All the leaders had argued the protests were intended as peaceful, non-violent civil disobedience, only to benefit society and make positive democratic progress. Justice Chan said their “martyrdom ... was a concocted one”, noting that the price the defendants were prepared to pay had also to be borne by an inconvenienced public. ERODING FREEDOMS Authorities have clamped down on opposition forces, disqualified democratic legislators, jailed activists and banned a pro-independence political party. After the sentences, the five freed defendants urged the public to turn out en masse on Sunday for a protest to show solidarity with those jailed and to oppose proposed extradition laws that would allow people to be sent from Hong Kong to mainland China for trial. Critics fear the laws, which are expected to be passed this year, could further erode legal protections so vital to the capitalist hub, and undermine the city’s international reputation. A representative for the British consulate in Hong Kong said it would be “deeply concerning if the outcome for these individuals (the Occupy leaders) were to deter the people of Hong Kong from participating in peaceful protest in the future.” The U.S. consulate said in a statement it was concerned by the Hong Kong government’s decision to bring the charges against organizers of the “peaceful protests in 2014”. “Such prosecutions can stifle the exercise of the basic freedoms enshrined in the Basic Law,” said a U.S. consular spokesman, referring to the city’s mini constitution. Taiwan’s Mainland Affairs Council said in a statement that it “deeply regretted” the court’s decision, which it said showed the failure of “one country, two systems” to protect political rights.

title: Hong Kong democracy leaders jailed over Umbrella Movement protests
og_title: Hong Kong democracy leaders jailed over Umbrella Movement protests
content: HONG KONG: Four prominent leaders of Hong Kong's democracy movement were jailed on Wednesday for their role in organising mass protests in 2014 that paralysed the city for months and infuriated Beijing. The prison terms are the latest hammer blow to the city's beleaguered democracy movement which has seen key figures jailed or banned from standing as legislators since their demonstrations shook the city but failed to win any concessions. Nine activists were all convicted earlier in April of at least one charge in a prosecution that deployed rarely used colonial-era public nuisance laws over their participation in the Umbrella Movement protests, which called for free elections to appoint the city's leader. Their trial renewed alarm over shrinking freedoms under an assertive China which has rejected demands by Hong Kongers for a greater say in how the financial hub is run. Two key leaders of the mass protests — sociology professor Chan Kin-man, 60, and law professor Benny Tai, 54 — received the longest sentences of 16 months in jail, sparking tears in court and angry chants from hundreds of supporters gathered outside. Two other leaders — activist Raphael Wong and lawmaker Shiu Ka-chun — received eight months while the rest either had their jail terms suspended or were given a community service order. One defendant, lawmaker Tanya Chan, had her sentencing adjourned because she needs surgery for a brain tumour. The jail terms are the steepest yet for anyone involved in the 79-day protest which vividly illustrated the huge anger — particularly among Hong Kong's youth — over the city's leadership and direction. As Wong was led away by guards he proclaimed: "Our determination to fight for democracy will not change." Tai and Chan founded a civil disobedience campaign known as "Occupy Central" in 2013 alongside 75-year-old Baptist minister Chu Yiu-ming, one of the defendants to have his jail term suspended. Their original idea of taking to the streets to demand a fairer system and the right to directly elect Hong Kong's leader was a precursor to the student-led Umbrella Movement a year later that brought parts of the city to a standstill. Authorities in Hong Kong and the mainland have defended the prosecutions as a necessary measure to punish the leaders of a direct action movement that took over key intersections of the city for many weeks. But activists and rights groups have argued that the use of the vaguely worded public nuisance laws — and wielding the steeper common law punishment — is an insidious blow to free speech and a new tactic from prosecutors. "The long sentences sends a chilling warning to all that there will be serious consequences for advocating for democracy," said Maya Wang, Human Rights Watch's senior researcher on China. But city leader Carrie Lam remained unmoved by such criticisms. Asked by reporters on Wednesday whether the jailings would damage Hong Kong's free speech reputation, she replied: "I can't see any impact." There were emotional scenes outside the courthouse with the defendants met by a noisy crowd of supporters shouting "Add Oil!", a popular Cantonese phrase to signal encouragement. Others sang "We Shall Overcome", the gospel song that became an anthem of the civil rights movement in the United States. Speaking after the sentencing, Tanya Chan told the crowds: "I hope Hong Kongers will not lose hope, will not be afraid, will not have regrets or back down now". Many supporters were holding umbrellas, an emblem of the 2014 protests after they were used by young demonstrators to defend themselves against police batons, tear gas canisters and pepper spray. Joseph Lo, 59, was wearing a yellow T-shirt with the phrase "I was not incited" — a reference to the charges laid against the protest leaders. "We were not incited by these nine people," he told AFP, adding he hit the streets in 2014 because of the refusal to grant Hong Kongers universal suffrage and the police's decision to fire tear gas at protesters. While the financial hub enjoys rights unseen on the Chinese mainland under a 50-year handover agreement between Britain and China, there are fears those liberties are being eroded as Beijing flexes its muscles and stamps down on dissent. Hong Kong's leader is elected by a group of just 1,200 largely pro-Beijing appointees, in a city of seven million. Judge Johnny Chan ruled that the 2014 protests were not protected by Hong Kong's free speech laws because the demonstrations impinged on the rights of others. During sentencing, Chan said the defendants had expressed no regret for the "inconvenience and suffering caused to members of the public". He added that an apology was "rightly deserved ... but never received" from the protest leaders.

title: Protests mark polling by Kashmiri Pandits for Anantnag Lok Sabha seat in Jammu
og_title: Protests mark polling by Kashmiri Pandits for Anantnag Lok Sabha seat in Jammu
content: JAMMU: Migrant Kashmiri Pandits staged demonstration outside a special polling station here Tuesday after some of them found their names missing from the voters list during the first phase of the three-phased poling in the Anantnag Lok Sabha seat . However, Assistant Returning Officer Pankaj Anand said the election office has made sure that no voter, who has filled the M-form, is left out as over 4,000 electorates including 1826 women cast their ballots at the designated polling centres in Jammu . The polling in the south Kashmir constituency, spread over four districts of Anantnag, Kulgam, Shopian and Pulwama covering 16 assembly segments, is being held in three phases with the second phase scheduled to take place on April 29 followed by the final phase on May 6. Former chief minister Mehbooba Mufti and state Congress chief G A Mir are among 18 candidates whose fate would be decided by the polling in the constituency which has a large number of registered migrant voters. The Election Commission set up 21 special polling stations for Kashmiri Pandit migrant voters in Jammu, one in Udhampur and four in Delhi to ensure their participation in the democratic exercise. Dozens of KPs held noisy protest outside one of the polling station at Jagati camp in the outskirts of Jammu after some of them claimed their names were missing from the voter list. "We have completed the cumbersome formalities like filing of M-form to exercise our right to franchise but left dejected on finding our names missing," said Sunil Pandita, one of the protesters. The protesters threatened boycott of upcoming assembly polls if the election commission continues with the present formalities.

title: Income Tax office protest: Karnataka High Court rejects PIL seeking action against CM
og_title: Income Tax office protest: Karnataka High Court rejects PIL seeking action against CM
content: BENGALURU: The high court has dismissed a public interest litigation ( PIL ), seeking police action against chief minister HD Kumaraswamy and other public servants for holding an unlawful assembly outside the income tax office on March 28. A Mallikarjuna, a resident of Chelur village in Gubbi, Tumakuru district, had filed the PIL, claiming police have not taken any action in the matter despite a complaint to the DG&IG. Citing several media reports, the petitioner claimed the main motto was to threaten the I-T officials who were on election duty and were unearthing huge amounts of cash and valuables while working as per the directions of Election Commission of India. However, a division bench headed by acting chief justice L Narayana Swamy rejected the plea while observing that even if the petitioner may have a good case, the same cannot be remedied in a PIL. HC rider on new autorickshaw permits The high court has put a rider on issuing permits for new autorickshaws in Bengaluru while hearing a PIL challenging the March 27, 2018 notification increasing the permits in the city from 1,25,000 lakh to 1,55,000 lakh. While agreeing to hear the PIL after the summer vacation of the court, a division bench headed by acting chief justice L Narayana Swamy said any new permits granted during the interregnum period will be subject to the result of the petition. City resident Nithin R Puthige has filed the PIL seeking directions against permitting new autorickshaws in the city and urging action against autos plying without valid permits. According to him, despite increase in noise and air pollution levels in the city, a gazette notification has been issued to enhance the ceiling by 30,000 units. During the hearing, the government advocate informed the court that they are digitising autorickshaws to check those plying without valid permits.

title: Anti-Shatrughan protest at Bihar Congress HQ
og_title: Anti-Shatrughan protest at Bihar Congress HQ
content: PATNA: A group of around 24 people led by a Congress leader from Saran district held a demonstration outside the state Congress headquarters Sadaquat Ashram here on Monday, demanding cancellation of candidature of actor-turned-politician Shatrughan Sinha from Patna Sahib Lok Sabha constituency. Sinha, who won Patna Sahib seat twice in 2009 and 2014 as BJP candidate, joined the Congress a few weeks ago after meeting AICC president Rahul Gandhi in Delhi. He was later declared as Congress candidate from Patna Sahib where filing of nomination papers began on Monday. The demonstrators, who were holding placards in their hands, alleged that Shatrughan was “dropped through a parachute” at the RJD’s behest and has been made Congress candidate without consultation from the grassroots workers of the party. They alleged that senior Congress leaders “sold” the Patna Sahib seat to Shatrughan at the behest of RJD chief Lalu Prasad. Bihar Pradesh Congress Committee spokesperson Rajesh Rathore said except one of the demonstrators, who is a Congress leader from Chhapra, the others were unknown people. “They were never seen at the Congress office. We believe they were sent by the rival BJP,” Rathore told TOI. He said Shatrughan’s candidature from Patna Sahib has been decided by none other than the Congress high command. “Once the party’s high command takes a decision, no devoted Congress worker goes against it,” he said. Earlier on Sunday, Shatrughan was heckled at the Congress state headquarters while he was addressing a meeting of party workers. The star-turned-politician annoyed a section of Congress workers across the country, including Bihar, when he visited Lucknow a few days ago and campaigned for his wife Poonam Sinha , who is contesting the Lucknow seat on a Samajwadi Party ticket. Shatrughan drew flaks from a section of Congress workers after he described BSP supremo Mayawati and Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav as prime ministerial candidates in Lucknow.

title: Telangana Inter result 2019: Protesters seek action against BIE and minister; say just re-evaluation not enough
og_title: Telangana Inter result 2019: Protesters seek action against BIE and minister; say just re-evaluation not enough
content: HYDERABAD: Continuing their agitation over the result fiasco, distressed students, on Wednesday, staged a dharna outside Pragathi Bhavan, the official residence-cum-camp office of the CM, and demanded action against those responsible for the faux pas. Their attempt at gheraoing the premises, or the Board of Intermediate Education office in Nampally, was foiled by the police. "It took 19 deaths and a week's time for the chief minister to take note of the issue that's affected lakhs of students. Just announcing free re-evaluation will not bring any relief to parents and students or build their confidence on the current government or inter board," said K Ramesh, a protestor. Students questioned why no probe has still been ordered against the BIE. "When mistakes were committed even during evaluation process, ordering a probe only on Globarena Technologies doesn't make sense. An independent body should be formed and thorough inquiry be conducted. There is also a need to completely revamp intermediate board," said A Shankar, who protested in front of inter board office. Angry parents also organised protests in front of Globarena's office on Banjara Hills Road No 12 and asked how the firm could be so negligent and allow such errors to slip in. "Globarena along with the board officials has played with the lives of lakhs of students. If they were aware about the possibility of such errors cropping up, they should have resolved them before announcing the results instead of releasing them and creating unrest among students and their parents," said M Venkat Reddy, who protested outside the Globarena office.

title: Madurai Central Prison inmates stage protest, pelt vehicles with stones
og_title: Madurai Central Prison inmates stage protest, pelt vehicles with stones
content: MADURAI: Around 50 remand prisoners in Madurai Central Prison on Tuesday staged a protest to press their demands including better food and basic amenities. They climbed on a building and hurled stones at the vehicles on the New Jail Road. The protesters threw stones at prison security personnel too. When police tried to control them, some prisoners hurt themselves with sharp objects. Police blocked traffic movement on the busy New Jail Road which connects Arasaradi with Tamilsangam Road. The vehicles were diverted through alternative routes. Additional police personnel were deployed in the prison. Higher officials including deputy commissioner of police (law and order) V Sasi Mohan reached the spot. The protest that started around 3.15pm ended around 5.30pm after police and revenue officials held talks with the remand prisoners.

title: Marathi Samaj march to protest Pragya’s remark on Karkare
og_title: Marathi Samaj march to protest Pragya’s remark on Karkare
content: BHOPAL: Angry over Sadhvi Pragya Thakur’s statement on 26/11 hero Hemant Karkare , members of the Marathi community organised a candle march from 6 Number to Shaurya Smarak on Tuesday. Raising slogans like ‘Hemant Karkare Amar Rahe’, people marched with the portrait of martyr Karkare and slammed the statement of BJP candidate from Bhopal . The community members said that while the nation respects Karkare for making the supreme sacrifice, Pragya Thakur has insulted him, thus hurting the sentiments of people. They also demanded an FIR against Pragya Thakur for the remark. Lata Devre, who organised the march, said: “Such hate speeches are unacceptable. How can someone insult a martyr? Karkare gave up his life to save others, and we must respect him. Being so insensitive towards a real hero is really condemnable. We strongly oppose Pragya’s comment. Though she has taken back her statement, but she has caused tremendous pain to the whole community and people of the country.” Sanjay Athrikar said, “The BJP candidate has insulted Hemant Karkare and the entire community is very angry with her behaviour. No one has the right to abuse a martyr.” Satish Munde, a former corporator, said: “Though Pragya has taken back her statement, but the damage has been done. The sentiments of the community have been hurt. We want to tell Karkare’s family that we stand by them and will not let anyone insult our national hero.” Poonam Kulkarni, president of the Kolar Maharashtra mandal, also condemned the statement strongly. “Pragya should talk about real issues and not try to win polls with such divisive statements. Why didn’t she complain to the human rights department about the atrocities on her in jail ? Insulting a martyr is really sad. She should understand that one cannot win people’s support by hurting their sentiments”, she said.

title: EC issues notification for fourth phase of polls
og_title: EC issues notification for fourth phase of polls
content: BHOPAL: Notification for the fourth and last phase of elections in state was published on Monday. In the last phase, elections would be held in 8 parliamentary constituencies including Dewas, Ujjain, Mandsaur , Ratlam , Dhar, Indore , Khargone , and Khandwa , chief electoral officer VL Kantha Rao said. “Last date for filing nominations, which had started today, is April 29. Scrutiny of the nomination forms would be done on April 30. Candidates can withdraw their nominations by May 2 and elections would be held in these constituencies on May 19,” Rao said.

title: Residents protest over renaming of heritage junction in Udaipur
og_title: Residents protest over renaming of heritage junction in Udaipur
content: UDAIPUR: Hundreds of residents living in and around Ayad area protested against Udaipur Municipal Corporation’s (UMC) decision to rename the famous ‘Dhoolkot Chauraha’ to Sant Pipaji Chauraha. People assembled in large numbers when they saw the new board put up at the chauraha. Following the protest , MLA Gulab Chand Kataria himself reached the spot to pacify the people. The residents insisted on retaining the old name Dhoolkot which they said was a heritage site related to the 4,000-year-old Ahar civilization and had public sentiments attached to it. They claimed the Udaipur Municipal Corporation authorities didn’t bother to seek public consensus before deciding to rename the chauraha which sparked unrest among the people. “Ayad has a glorious history and around 1951-52 the Archaeology and Museums Department began excavation here. It was last in 1960-61 when the department collaborated for horizontal excavation with the Deccan College, Pune,” said Rajesh Verma, a resident. The Archaeological Museum in Ahar is a popular attraction which was made to preserve the excavated items of the ancient era.

title: Road built after protests has potholes in a month
og_title: Road built after protests has potholes in a month
content: GHAZIABAD: The residents of Indirapuram’s Ahimsa Khand , who had threatened to opt for NOTA if the roads weren’t repaired and the area not freed from encroachers, may have managed to spur the Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) into action. But within a month, the road built by GDA now lies broken and filled with craters, accumulating drain water in many spots. Before the April 11 election was held, representatives of 22 societies of Ahimsa Khand had on March 15 said that they would press the NOTA (none-of-the-above) button if the agency did not address the issue. The GDA had started work within three days. “We had apprised public representatives and officials of our decision to opt for NOTA if roads are not built. We thought that the pressure worked and GDA wrapped up the construction work just before polls,” said Alok Kumar of Federation of Apartment Owners Association and a resident of Arihant Harmony in Ahimsa Khand. “But within days, the black topping (of the surface) has eroded and the potholes and craters are back,” added Kumar. Sally Singh, a resident of Exotica Elegance society, said that near DPS Indirapuram, the condition is so pathetic that drain water has spilled on the roads. “The potholes are filed with drain water and pedestrians are often greeted with a splash every time a vehicle passes,” said Singh. “It speaks of the seriousness, or rather the lack of it, on the part of GDA, which has basically fooled residents,” she added. GDA’s chief engineer VN Singh said they have received complaints from residents. “We were under public pressure when we started work on the road and ideally we needed more time,” he said. He denied that sub-standard material had been used. “The road was damaged due to spilling of drain water,” he said. “We have drawn a long-term plan to tackle the drain problem. A consultant was hired but that is not going to happen overnight,” he added.

title: Jet employees protest with hope of flying again, seek government support
og_title: Jet employees protest with hope of flying again, seek government support
content: BENGALURU: Over 150 pilots, in-flight crew members , engineers and ground staff working with Jet Airways banded together for a peaceful protest at Town Hall on Monday demanding the central government’s intervention in keeping the airline afloat. Donning their uniforms and armed with banners and placards that read ‘Save Jet Airways’, a majority of the staffers said they’re still hoping to fly again. “Over 20,000 Jet Airways employees across India and 500 in Bengaluru have been hit by the recent developments. This protest is an appeal to the authorities concerned to save us from this situation. Staff members across the spectrum have been reporting to work every day but have no work with all operations being temporarily suspended,” said Harish Shenoy, general manager, Jet Airways, Bengaluru. “Families of the employees are also a part of this organisation, hence, save Jet Airways and save our families,” said Sunith James, a member of the cabin crew. Hari (name changed), a senior commander for Boeing 777 fleet from Bengaluru who has been working with Jet Airways for over 18 years, said he now has to start over in the aviation industry. “All these years of working and scaling the ladder seem to have gone in vain. We request the government to preserve the Jet Airways slots. In the current scenario, the slots are being taken over by other airlines, which shows the Centre’s apathy,” he said. Other pilots at the venue opined that employment prospects now appear bleak with gaps in their flying training being one of the key concerns. The protesters stressed they want the government to keep the airline afloat so that they continue to have a steady source of livelihood “Everyone knows what Jet Airways stands for. We just need a chance to prove it,” said Soni, a cabin supervisor who has been with Jet Airways since 2008. The employees felt there isn’t adequate support from the government to keep thousands of employees in jobs. “The government is definitely helping us but since the SBI took over, there’s been no proper communication with employees,” a senior official with the airlines said. “We are being offered half the salary we were earning. One has to pay EMIs, loans and bills. It’s a nightmare,” he rued. (Inputs by Poorvi Kadakol, Adyasha Guru and Thanmaya Prakash)

title: Parents protest against fee hike by private schools
og_title: Parents protest against fee hike by private schools
content: JAIPUR: Hundreds of parents of students studying in private schools of city protested against arbitrary fees hike on Tuesday. They also gave a written complaint to the district education officer against Mahaveer Public School in Jaipur for increasing school fees. Anil Mathur, one of the parents, who filed a complaint against Mahaveer Public School, said that every year the school is increasing 15-25% fees and excessively charging for stationery. “As per the rules, there should be a parent-teacher committee that will later on form a School Level Fee Committee (SLFC). In SLFC, five parents have to be selected from parent-teacher committee but none of the parents in the school know about the members of the committee. When asked, the school gave us the names of members and when we approached the parents concerned, they denied having any knowledge of being part of such a committee. This is sheer misuse of power,” said Mathur. Similarly, parents of students studying in Jayshree Periwal High School in Jaipur shouted slogans in front of the school against the arbitrary increase in fees and no information of parent-teacher committee. Abhay Sharma (name changed), whose children are studying in fourth and fifth standard of the school, said that the stationery provided by the school costs 30% higher than the market rate. “The school posted about the parent-teacher committee on school website six days back, but we want to ask them why didn’t they write it in the school diary of the students. The school management has accepted our request to hear us out on Saturday. So, we are waiting for a solution to come up by then or else we will take legal action against the school,” said Sharma. Principal of Jayshree Periwal High School Madhu Maini denied the allegations made by the parents. She said that the school has been following all the rules as per law. Similar statement was given by the management of Mahaveer Public School. It said, the fees were increased after taking consent of the parents in the committee formed. Jaipur district education officer Ram Chandra Pilaniya said that the team of three officers of principal cadre has been formed that will look into the matter and submit the report to the state government. “The Rajasthan School Fee Act, 2016, has been stayed by the Rajasthan High Court until further decision. That is why there are currently no regulations guiding the fees structure. We have formed the committee that will investigate the matter and submit the report to the government. After that it will be the prerogative of the government,” said Pilaniya.

title: Parents protest outside two schools seeking rollback
og_title: Parents protest outside two schools seeking rollback
content: NEW DELHI: The protests over fee hike in private schools continue. On Monday, parents gathered outside two schools in south and northwest Delhi demanding that the fee hike be rolled back. According to the lists uploaded on the directorate of education (DoE) website, both schools — Apeejay School , Sheikh Sarai and Darbari Lal DAV Model School , Shalimar Bagh — are built on land allotted by government agencies. “We know that this school is built on government land, so how can they increase the fee? The school has been citing some clauses in the allotment letter and claiming they do not have to seek prior approval,” said a parent outside Apeejay School. The parents protested at the school holding placards with slogans such as ‘Stop Extortion, Start Education’, ‘Don’t commercialise education’ and ‘Few Teachers, Big Arrears’. AAP MLA Saurabh Bharadwaj met the protesting parents. The principal, Ritu Mehta, said she would talk about the issue on Tuesday. At Shalimar Bagh, the parents’ association held banners with slogans such as ‘Roll back fee hike’, ‘Treat like a temple, not business’ and even went to meet the DoE director. The Delhi parents’ association also joined the protest. According to the protesters, the school is charging fees under heads like safety and security, and login ID. “We were told by the DoE director that a notice has already been sent to the school that they cannot increase the fees nor demand arrears from parents,” said Aprajita Gautam of the Delhi parents’ association. “During audit, it was found that the school has excess funds. We have asked the director to issue a show-cause notice and, in case of non-compliance, to de-recognise the school,” she added. The school principal did not respond to calls and messages. With the schools built on private land also increasing the fees and parents being forced to pay, the parents’ association requested the director to restrain them as well.

title: Silent protest to save sacred grove in Kerala
og_title: Silent protest to save sacred grove in Kerala
content: KOCHI: A group of green activists has decided to exercise NOTA (none of the above) option in the Lok Sabha polls in Kerala as a mark of silent protest to save Shantivanam , a green abode with sacred groves and ponds at North Paravur in Ernakulam. As many as 55 signatories, including National Alliance for People’s movement (NAPM) and noted environmentalists like former chairman of Kerala state biodiversity board V S VIjayan, will participate in the silent protest to save the man-made forest on Monday. Several research organizations like Kerala Forest Research Institute and society for environment education in Kerala in their reports had outlined the significance of these sacred groves. “We have decided to go for NOTA option. We will observe a silent protest at Shantivanam on Monday,” said NAPM state coordinator Kusumam Joseph. The greens said that the initiative to opt for NOTA began two days ago primarily against the Kerala state electricity board (KSEB) decision to align a 110kV line with construction of huge towers through the two-acre sacred grove and manmade forest at North Paravur. “The area is home to hundreds of birds, snakes and other animals,” said former head of state disaster management centre K G Thara, one of the signatories to NOTA option. “It is also a source of groundwater and offers fresh oxygenated air to the otherwise polluted surroundings. It is alleged that there is an alternative alignment but KSEB is not interested as it passes through the plot of a former KSEB chairman,’’ she said.

title: Seniors lead protest against cars clogging lanes near South Kolkata school
og_title: Seniors lead protest against cars clogging lanes near South Kolkata school
content: KOLKATA: Exactly four months after residents of a tony south Kolkata neighbourhood protested against lanes being clogged by pool cars ferrying children to and from the school with the largest number of students in the city and police putting up no-entry boards at several places, the locals were back on the streets on Monday. The agitation was led by over 20 senior citizens who face the maximum problems while leaving and entering their homes around South Point High School . The cops, however, assured them that a critical “no-entry” board has been withdrawn from Swinhoe Street and the police would help them gain access to their homes from now on. But other demands made by the locals — like asking students to walk down to school from Cornfield Road — were “beyond the cops’ purview”. TimesView This is a vexed problem with no easy solution. But the right to free movement in one’s own neighbourhood is something that every citizen should take for granted. All stakeholders must meet and try to seek solutions with honesty of intent. Residents of Ballygunge Place, Anil Maitra Road, Cornfield Road, Swinhoe Street and Jamir Lane had, on Thursday, vented their ire over the no-entry boards. Nandita Sengupta said it was very difficult to get any sleep from 6.30am because of the noise and smoke from the cars that start to arrive for school. Kalyan Sen, who travels to Howrah for work, said he was fed up with the traffic mess near his home. “We don’t even have access to our homes, a basic right of any citizen,” he said. For the last 30 years, the situation has remained the same. Residents’ complaints range from “denied access to homes” and “ambulances can’t reach the ailing” to “driving in and out of the area during school hours is impossible”. “We have to park our cars two-and-a-half-kilometres aw-ay. App cabs refuse to pick us up from our doorstep. We can’t even take a rickshaw as cops don’t allow them,” said Suchandra Das, a resident of Ballygunge Place. An officer of the southeast traffic guard, which manages traffic in the area, said: “The only solution is to ask students to walk or have buses pick up and drop off students on a rotational basis. The residents have suggested some other solutions too — asking students to walk down from Cornfield Road and banning buses and cars from being parked outside main entrances to houses. The first one is not a decision we can take. As for the second, it can have serious repercussions on traffic. We will help locals collect passes so that we can facilitate their entry through Swinhoe Street.” The cops rejected the locals’ claims that Swinhoe Street had been made either a no-entry zone or one-way. “Contrary to perception, Swinhoe Street has been open for residents since last December,” said an officer. “Yes, it is a problem. The school has been here for the last 50 years. A number of high-rises have come up and population in the locality has increased exponentially. But the traffic problem is something which only cops can resolve. We do whatever police advise us. Time and again, we circulate advisories to students. We also help cops come up with tenable solution to problems,” a spokesperson of South Point School had earlier informed TOI.

title: DoE nixes fee-hike plea of 170 schools
og_title: DoE nixes fee-hike plea of 170 schools
content: NEW DELHI: The directorate of education ( DoE ) rejected the proposals of 170 private schools of the 266 that had applied for increasing fees as they were found in possession of excess funds, official data has revealed. There were 30 private schools that withdrew the proposal on their own, suggesting that they didn’t require a fee hike . Schools built on government land (allotted by Delhi Development Authority) have to seek prior approval from DoE before increasing fees. In total, there are 301 schools built on DDA land . DoE said the proposals were rejected after calculating the financial implications of the Seventh Pay Commission while conducting audit of the schools. “In total, 170 schools were found in possession of excess funds, so they have not been granted permission to hike fees. While making these calculations, the financial implications of the VII CPC have been taken into consideration. Therefore, these schools shouldn’t deny benefits of the pay commission to their staff,” the education department’s document said. Seven schools whose applications were rejected have moved Delhi high court. Their case is yet to be settled. The high court is also hearing another case over fee hike and has granted a stay till April 30. The 30 schools who withdrew their proposal cannot hike fees nor deny benefits of the Seventh Pay Commission to their staff. Schools given permission have to keep the fee hike restricted to the limit set by DoE. Action will be taken on schools not complying with DoE’s directions. The schools that didn’t submit a proposal have no provision to increase their fees, the DoE document added. School principals, however, highlight that such “overregulation” by the government is causing a lot of problems. Sadhna Bhalla, chairperson of National Progressive Schools Conference (NPSC), a consortium of 200 schools, said, “Everybody is feeling oppressed. The autonomy of private schools has to be kept intact. We have to pay high salaries, but fees have been capped at a very low rate. We are open to scrutiny, but the government has to develop an efficient system. After the scrutiny there is delay in action. We have to submit a request to find out about our proposals, which causes a lot of problems.” In Bhalla’s Mira Model School, fees have not been increased for the past six years. While there is a rule in place for schools built on DDA land, confusion prevails over those constructed on land given by other government agencies. There are 448 private schools built on land given by other government agencies. Many such schools have increased the fees and have been asking parents to pay the dues along with arrears.

title: Congress workers protest seeking cancellation of Shatrughan Sinha's candidature from Patna Sahib
og_title: Congress workers protest seeking cancellation of Shatrughan Sinha's candidature from Patna Sahib
content: PATNA: A group of 15 to 20 people led by a Congress leader from Chhapra district, on Monday held a demonstration outside the state Congress headquarters Sadaqat Ashram here, demanding cancellation of candidature of actor-turned-politician Shatrughan Sinha from Patna Sahib Lok Sabha constituency . Sinha who won Patna Sahib seat twice in 2009 and 2014 as BJP candidate, joined the Congress a few weeks ago in the presence of the AICC president Rahul Gandhi and he has now been declared as Congress candidate from Patna Sahib where nomination began from Monday. The demonstrators, who were holding anti-Sinha placards in their hand, also alleged that Shatru was “dropped through a parachute” at the ally RJD’s behest and has been made Congress candidate without consultation from the grass-root workers. They also alleged that Congress senior leaders “sold” the Patna Sahib seat to Shatru at the behest of RJD chief Lalu Prasad. When contacted, Bihar Pradesh Congress Committee spokesperson Rajesh Rathore said except one of the demonstrators who is a Congress leader from Chhapra, all other demonstrators were unknown persons. “They were never seen at the Congress office. We believe they were sent by the rival BJP camp to create a sort of confusion among the electors of Patna Sahib seat,” Rathore told TOI. He said the Sinha’s candidature from Patna Sahib has been decided by none other than the Congress high command. “Once the party’s high command takes a decision about anything, no devoted Congress worker goes against the high command’s decision,” he said. Earlier on Sunday, Sinha, also known as Shotgun, was heckled at the Congress state headquarters while he was addressing a meeting of party workers. The star-turned-politician annoyed a section of Congress workers across the country including Bihar, when he visited Lucknow a few days ago and campaigned for his wife Poonam who is contesting the Lucknow seat as the candidate of the BSP-Samajwadi Party-RLD combine. A section of Congress workers became angry with Sinha after he stated in Lucknow that the BSP supremo Mayawati and Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav as prime ministerial candidates.

title: Supporters of 2 Congress leaders protest ‘snub’
og_title: Supporters of 2 Congress leaders protest ‘snub’
content: NEW DELHI: Supporters of former Delhi minister Raj Kumar Chauhan and ex-MP Mahabal Mishra on Sunday protested outside Congress headquarters and the residence of party president Rahul Gandhi for denying tickets to their leaders. While sources claimed that candidates for all seven seats had been finalised, the party did not declare the list till late on Sunday. While Chauhan was in contention from the reserved constituency of North West Delhi, Mishra, a Poorvanchali leader, was seeking ticket from West Delhi. According to sources, the Congress working committee, at a meeting earlier this month, had finalised names of four candidates, including Chauhan. The names, however, were not formally announced. “Chauhan was even informed after the meeting that his name had been finalised and was told to start preparing for the election. The party’s decision to give the ticket to somebody else came as a surprise. That is why hundreds of his supporters reached the Congress headquarters,” said a party leader, requesting anonymity. Sources said caste equations within the community tilted the balance against Chauhan. A source said: “The party leadership got several representations from the ‘Balmiki’ community that it was being overlooked. Chauhan, who belongs to the ‘Khateek’ community, lost out to Congress working president Rajesh Lilothia, a ‘Balmiki’.” Chauhan quelled speculation that he might quit the party. “I abide by the party’s decision. I have always been a Congressman and will remain one. When I came to know about the protests, I immediately called up people who were leading the agitation and asked them to come back,” said Chauhan, who won four consecutive Delhi assembly elections between 1993 and 2008. While Congress was initially keen to field a Poorvanchali in Delhi, it finally seemed to have decided to go for Olympic silver-medallist wrestler Sushil Kumar, a Jat, from West Delhi. “I am trying to pacify my supporters, but they are angry over neglect of Poorvanchalis. West Delhi is dominated by Poorvanchalis and its (not giving ticket to Poorvanchali) impact will be visible in the results of eastern UP and Bihar also,” Mishra said. A three-time MLA from Naseerpur (deleted after delimitation) and Dwarka, Mishra was elected to the Lok Sabha in 2009. Sources said Congress had finalised names of Sheila Dikshit from Chandni Chowk, JP Agarwal from North East Delhi, Ramesh Kumar from South Delhi and Arvinder Singh Lovely from East Delhi Lok Sabha seats.

title: Madhya Pradesh: Three held for raping minor in Mandsaur village
og_title: Madhya Pradesh: Three held for raping minor in Mandsaur village
content: INDORE: Three persons were arrested on Monday for raping a minor girl after abducting her from a village of Mandsaur district . The 17-year-old rape survivor had lodged a complaint with the Pipliamandi police station alleging that the accused abducted her from her village and took her to an isolated spot near a temple in Sabakheda village, where they beat her up and gang raped her, police said. The accused also threatened her of dire consequences if she went to the police, they said, adding that the girl narrated her ordeal to her parents, following which they lodged a complaint with the police. Police arrested Ganpat Gyari, Anil Naik and Prabhu alias Ballu Bheel. They were booked under relevant sections of Indian Penal Code for abduction and rape.

title: Flat buyers protest misuse of funds, handover delay
og_title: Flat buyers protest misuse of funds, handover delay
content: GURUGRAM Over 400 homebuyers and residents of three different projects in the city staged protests against the developers and RWA on Sunday. The protesters had similar grievances — financial irregularities and delay in possession by the builder. On Sunday morning, hundreds of residents of Mahindra Aura in New Palam Vihar staged a protest at the society clubhouse against the “malpractices and financial irregularities” conducted by their RWA. Aura residents said they had brought a no-confidence motion and dissolved the current RWA by calling a special general body meeting on September 16 last year, but the RWA continues to hold financial powers. “The RWA office bearers have, in collusion with the district registrar office, carried out several illegal activities, including replacement of security agency at a higher cost, increasing maintenance charges and installing poorly-planned CCTV cameras at a cost five times greater than the market rate,” said Tej Malik, a protester. Mahindra Aura RWA president Yashish Yadav said the matter is in court. “A group of residents are harassing RWA office bearers,” he said. Meanwhile, around 200 buyers of Greenopolis housing project in Sector 89 protested at the New Delhi residences of the directors of developer Orris Infrastructure, Vijay Gupta and Nirmal Singh. The buyers alleged that the builder has stopped meeting them after taking their money despite the project being way past its 2016 deadline. An Orris representative said he couldn’t comment on the matter as the case is with Rera. Around 100 homebuyers of Shree Vardhman Flora also protested against the developer at the project site in Sector 90 against the delay in completion. “No work is going on at the site and completion doesn’t seem likely in the near future,” said Shambir Yadav, a buyer. Vardhman spokespersons didn’t revert to messages sent by TOI.

title: Telangana government to buy 40 lakh metric tonnes rain-hit paddy
og_title: Telangana government to buy 40 lakh metric tonnes rain-hit paddy
content: HYDERABAD: In what could be seen as applying balm to angry farmers , the state government said every seed of paddy, including stocks that got soaked in the recent unseasonal rains and hailstorm , will be purchased from affected farmers. Senior officials said the government has set a target of purchasing 40 lakh metric tonnes (MTs) of paddy from farmers. The civil supplies department has already procured 2.97 lakh MTs of paddy from 27,591 farmers and shifted 2.58 lakh MTs to rice mills. Civil supplies commissioner Akun Sabharwal, who held a teleconference with officials here on Monday, said every step is being taken as per the instruction of chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to ensure that farmers do not suffer. The government is offering an MSP of Rs 1,770 per quintal to grade A paddy and Rs 1,750 per quintal to normal category of paddy. “Gunny bags and money to purchase and store paddy are in place,” Sabharwal said. A control room has also been set up at the civil supplies commissioner’s office to monitor the situation on a daily basis. Farmers can register complaints and suggestions on toll-free number 1800-425-00333 or WhatsApp number 7330774444. Sabharwal, who also visited paddy procurement centres (PPCs) in Nalgonda and Suryapet districts, promised that wet paddy would be bought from farmers. He also interacted with farmers and reviewed paddy procurement, transportation and condition of PPCs. Lorries would be available to transport paddy from paddy procurement centres to rice mills. The government said over 3,600 PPCs have been set up. “In case of emergency, officials will inform district joint collectors and head office immediately,” he said. The civil supplies department has also started taking measures and directed officials to keep tarpaulin sheets in sufficient quantity and numbers at PPCs and shift paddy to rice mills immediately after purchase. Meanwhile, the extent of damage to crops in the unseasonal rains swelled to 65,000 acres on Monday from 55,000 acres on Sunday with rains lashing several parts of the state.

title: Jangpura residents protest against rising crime graph, ask cops to act
og_title: Jangpura residents protest against rising crime graph, ask cops to act
content: NEW DELHI: Residents of southeast Delhi's Jangpura Extension on Sunday came out on the streets to protest against a spike in theft, snatching and drug-related crimes in the area. Scores of protesters assembled outside the Jangpura Extension police post and raised slogans. Kapil Kakkar, president of Jangpura Extension Residents' Welfare Association, said: "In the last 15 days, nearly 100 cases of snatching and theft of items like stereos, tyres and other accessories from vehicles have taken place, but police have failed to do anything." Kakkar claimed that lack of patrolling had led to a spurt in crime. "Our complaints are not entertained and we are told that there is no point in filing an FIR as it would mean regular visits to court. Also, anti-social elements have a free run because there are no police barricades or patrolling," he alleged. A senior police officer dismissed the allegations of complaints not being heard. "Patrolling has been intensified in the area and we are coordinating with residents," an officer said. Ramneet Singh, a resident of O Block, said he had come out to highlight their helplessness. "Some guests had stayed overnight, and to our embarassment, their car was missing in the morning. Several of my neighbours have also complained about thefts," Singh said, adding that it took him three months to get a response from the police. Neelam Bhatia, another resident, said she was worried about regular snatching incidents. "A friend of mine was out for a walk and snatchers targeted her right in front of the police station. Such cases are becoming too frequent," Bhatia said. Last week, the residents said, they had lodged a complaint against the rising crime graph with the southeast Delhi DCP after which police had started patrolling the area. However, they demanded that police take long-term measures. Anil Talwar , a senior citizen, suggested that exit points to the society be barricaded.

title: Kanhaiya Kumar’s men thrash protesters
og_title: Kanhaiya Kumar’s men thrash protesters
content: BEGUSARAI: A fight erupted during CPI nominee Kanhaiya Kumar’s roadshow in Korai village under Garhpura block of Begusarai district on Sunday after a few youths showed him black flags and raised ‘Kanhaiya wapas jao’ slogan. This outraged his supporters who were accompanying him in large numbers. As the protesters kept shouting the slogan, Kanhaiya’s supporters thrashed them with bamboo sticks. They even chased away the protesters. However, a police team soon arrived and brought the situation under control. Supporters close to Kanhaiya said the incident was part of a plan to defame him as BJP and its supporters were shaken by the tremendous support and goodwill Kanhaiya enjoyed among the electors. Incidentally, Sunday incident was the third when black flags were shown to Kanhaiya or his roadshow has been disturbed since campaigning started for Begusarai Lok Sabha seat early this month. Earlier, a few youths had shown him black flags in Lohia Nagar of the town. He was also stopped during campaigning at Ramdiri in the district. His supporters had blamed ABVP activists for the Lohia Nagar incident.

title: Green ministry notice to Delhi's Okhla waste plant after protests
og_title: Green ministry notice to Delhi's Okhla waste plant after protests
content: NEW DELHI: The Union ministry of environment forest and climate change has issued a show-cause notice to the Okhla waste-to-energy plant for violation of the environmental clearance. Last month, residents of Sukhdev Vihar, Ishwar Nagar, New Friends Colony, Jasola, Sarita Vihar and Haji Colony took out a rally to protest against the plant. "In September 2018, the National Green Tribunal was told by a joint inspection committee of Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) and Delhi Pollution Control Committee (DPCC) that the Okhla waste-to-energy plant and also the ones at Ghazipur and Narela-Bawana were not compliant with emission standards," Ranjit Devraj, a resident of Sukhdev Vihar who has been spearheading the protest against the Okhla plant, had said. "We condemn the failure of authorities to shut down the plant despite evidence of toxic emissions from it polluting the area." The notice issued by the ministry also points out that the plant authorities have not replied to its earlier communication. "A representation from Dr Umesh Bharti and others, residents of Sukhdev Vihar Residential Colony, dated October 14, 2018 was received by the ministry that the power plant is not complying with the environmental pollution standards and is not in line with the original proposal envisaged in the Environmental Impact Assessment Report... The ministry (on October 30, 2018) sought a reply from M/S Timarpur Okhla Waste Management Company Pvt Ltd on the issues mentioned in the representation submitted by Sukhdev Vihar Residential Colony. A reply in this regard is yet to be received," it said. The notice directs M/S Timarpur Okhla Waste Management Company Pvt Ltd to show cause within 15 days of its receipt. The environment ministry also cites a GIZ report on September 25, 2018, which highlighted several operational issues such as overloading of waste against the designed capacity, malfunctioning of emission monitoring systems, unburnt carbon in the bottom ash that led to the reduction of efficiency, and uncontrolled emissions into atmosphere. "The ministry has taken cognisance that the increase in waste throughout to the incinerators that will increase the pollution load, increase in installed power generation, construction of new chimney without the ministry's permission, failure to set up bio-methanation plant at Okhla and RDF plant at Timarpur are non-compliance of the environmental clearance dated March 21, 2007 and its conditions," the notice, a copy of which is with TOI, states.

title: Protest against audio clip spreads to Sivaganga
og_title: Protest against audio clip spreads to Sivaganga
content: Madurai: Following the violence unleashed by the members of a community at Ponnamaravathi in Pudukottai district over a derogatory audio clip, members of the community from villages in Sivaganga bordering Madurai district also carried out a protest. They gathered in large numbers at Kottampatti blocking the road for an hour. Irate mob started protesting and unleashing violence in a few villages in Pudukottai after an audio clip containing derogatory remarks against a particular community went viral on Whatsapp. They demanded police to find the miscreants who circulated the audio clip. The violence in Ponnamaravathi forced the revenue officials to clamp down prohibitory orders in the villagers in Pudukottai. It soon spread to other villages including Singampunari in Sivaganga district. In the protest in Madurai, around 1,500 people including 400 women armed with broom sticks from a few villages blocked the Madurai-Trichy four-way lane demanding the immediate arrest of the miscreants. As the traffic movement came to a halt on the vital road, the Madurai district police diverted vehicles. The protest, which started around 11.45 am, lasted for an hour. Madurai district superintendent of police N Manivannan and Sivaganga district superintendent of police T Jayachandran rushed to the spot and had talks with the community members. Although the protestors were obstinate initially, they cooled down after the intervention of the higher officials. The police promised that the miscreants would be traced and arrested soon.

title: After protests, Karnataka government to probe Raichur girl’s mystery death
og_title: After protests, Karnataka government to probe Raichur girl’s mystery death
content: RAICHUR/KALABURAGI: The mysterious death of an engineering student in Raichur early this week has touched off shock and outrage in the state. Netizens have launched a campaign seeking justice for the girl. The 21-year-old deceased girl was a sixth-semester civil engineering student at Navodaya Institute of Technology in Raichur. Her name has been withheld on request from parents. According to police, the girl left home on April 13 ostensibly to write internal exams — and never returned. Her body was found in a decomposed state in a forested area near Manikaprabhu Hill, Raichur, three days later. A death note found next to the body suggested she had committed suicide over academic failure — a charge dismissed by her parents as ludicrous. Taking note of the spontaneous student protests, the Karnataka government asked the DG&IGP to conduct a probe into the incident and bring the guilty to book. Students seek impartial probe into girl’s death Student organisations and classmates of the girl took out a rally and torchlight parade in Raichur seeking an impartial probe into her death. Some Kannada film actors have lent their voice to the protests. Police sources said the girl’s parents insisted — with corroboration — that it was a case of unnatural death and, possibly, murder. After two days, the girl’s parents suspected the role of Sudarshan Yadav, her collegemate in PU. Based on their complaint, police arrested him and remanded him in judicial custody. Police said the boy and girl may have been in a relationship, grounding their theory on texts recovered from their phones. Her parents rejected the version. Since the body was recovered from a forested area, an attack by animals is not ruled out. However, the body appeared to have been partially burnt and it was found hanging from a tree branch with her feet touching the ground. This has raised suspicions that the girl may have been murdered and then her body was hanged from the tree. Home minister MB Patil tweeted: “... I have directed the DGP to conduct thorough investigation...” An online petition addressed to Karnataka police on change.org alleged attempts to hush up the case. In Video: Raichur: Engineering student raped and murdered, 1 arrested

title: After cycle ride protest, Betul man enters poll fray
og_title: After cycle ride protest, Betul man enters poll fray
content: BHOPAL: Azad Chandrashekhar Pandole from Betul, who cycled his way to Delhi to appeal to Election Commission put curbs on the expensive campaigns by political parties for the Lok Sabha elections, has now thrown his hat in the poll ring. Pandole is contesting as an Independent candidate from Bhopal and Varanasi. With his bicycle adorned with giant hand-written slogans on cardboard placards and a black flag to protest against expensive elections, he spoke to TOI on Friday, explaining his agenda and motto for contesting the elections. “I went to New Delhi with my letter, but did not get any response from the EC. It was then that I decided to file my nomination and contest the polls to raise the voice of common men,” said Pandole. He maintained that parties spend money of the public to campaign for elections and then use corrupt means to earn back the money, he said. “If this continues, no party will work for public welfare. All of them are busy filling their own pockets. If the EC puts a strict check on over-expenditure during poll campaign, the public’s hard earned money will be saved,” Pandole added. Filing nomination from two cities -- Bhopal and Varanasi -- Pandole is all set to campaign for himself on his bicycle, decorated with placards that read ‘Loktantra ka dushman, kharcheela chunav’ ( democracy 's enemy, expensive polls). “I will file the nomination from Bhopal on Saturday and then head to Varanasi with my bicycle loaded in a train. I will file the nomination in Varanasi by April 24 and contest the elections without spending a single penny. I will ride across the two cities on my cycle and address people at tea stalls and bus stands,” he explained. Pandole further said that instead of turning the country into a concrete jungle in the name of development, political parties should understand that forests are essential for the country's well-being and the government should create jobs for the protection of forests.

title: Thousands protest in support of Morocco activists
og_title: Thousands protest in support of Morocco activists
content: RABAT: Thousands of people demonstrated Sunday in the Moroccan capital Rabat, calling for the release of dozens of activists jailed for up to 20 years over their role in a protest movement. "The people want the release of the detainees" demonstrators shouted as they marched behind a banner supporting activists linked to the Hirak movement.
