title: Protesters in Bangladesh after girl is burned to death
og_title: Protesters in Bangladesh after girl is burned to death
content: DHAKA, BANGLADESH: Dozens of protesters gathered in Bangladesh's capital on Friday to demand justice for an 18-year-old woman who died after being set on fire for refusing to drop sexual harassment charges against her Islamic school's principal. Nusrat Jahan Rafi told her family she was lured to the roof of her rural school in the town of Feni on April 6 and asked to withdraw the charges by five people clad in burqas. When she refused, she said her hands were tied and she was doused in kerosene and set alight. Rafi told the story to her brother in an ambulance on the way to the hospital and he recorded her testimony on his mobile phone. She died four days later in a Dhaka hospital with burns covering 80% of her body. The violence has shaken Bangladesh, triggering protests and raising concerns over the plight of women and girls in the conservative Muslim-majority nation of 160 million people where sexual harassment and violence are often unreported, victims are intimidated and the legal process is often lengthy. Many avoid reporting to police because of social stigma. "We want justice. Our girls must grow up safely and with dignity," Alisha Pradhan, a model and actress, told The Associated Press during Friday's demonstration. "We protest any forms of violence against women, and authorities must ensure justice." Tens of thousands of people attended Rafi's funeral prayers in Feni, and Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina promised Rafi's family when they met in Dhaka that those responsible would be punished. At least 17 people, including students, have been arrested in connection with the case, said Banaj Kumar Majumder, the head of the Police Bureau of Investigation. In late March, Rafi filed a complaint with police that the principal of her madrasa, or Islamic school, had called her into his office and touched her inappropriately and repeatedly. Her family agreed to help her to file the police complaint, which prompted police to arrest the principal, infuriating him and his supporters. Influential local politicians backed the principal, and ruling party members were also among the arrested. Police said the arrested suspects told them during interrogations that the attack on Rafi was planned and ordered by the school's principal from prison when his men went to see him. It was timed for daytime so that it would look like a suicide attempt, Majumder said. Human Rights Watch said in a statement that Rafi's family said that they had received death threats before the attack telling them to drop the case. While Rafi's case is now being treated with urgency, that wasn't the case until her death. A video taken on March 27 while Rafi reported the assault shows the local police chief registering her complaint but telling her that the incident was "not a big deal." The chief was later removed from the police station for negligence in dealing with the case. For Bangladeshi women, it is often not easy to file sensitive complaints with police. Victims often fear further harassment and bullying. Police also often show an unwillingness to investigate such cases and are often accused of being influenced by local politics or bribes. But the call for dealing with violence against women, especially related to sexual harassment and assault, is also getting louder. "The horrifying murder of a brave woman who sought justice shows how badly the Bangladesh government has failed victims of sexual assault," said Meenakshi Ganguly, South Asia director at Human Rights Watch. "Nusrat Jahan Rafi's death highlights the need for the Bangladesh government to take survivors of sexual assault seriously and ensure that they can safely seek a legal remedy and be protected from retaliation."

title: Hindus in Pakistan protest abduction, forced conversion of girls
og_title: Hindus in Pakistan protest abduction, forced conversion of girls
content: ISLAMABAD: Protest against the abduction of teenage Hindu girl by an influential person continued on Thursday in Rahim Yar Khan in Pakistan’s Punjab province with members of minority Hindu community demanding her safe recovery from the government. A teenage girl Naina was allegedly kidnapped from Rahim Yar Khan last month by an influential person Tahir Tamri with the help of his father and brothers. According to the FIR lodged by Naina’s father Ragu Ram on April 5, six people had abducted his daughter on March 13 and the main suspect, Tahir Tamri, had taken her to the southern port city of Karachi . On March 14, the FIR said, she was converted to Islam at a seminary, Jamiatul Saeed Gulshan-i-Maimar, in Karachi. The complainant stated that after conversion to Islam, Naina was given a Muslim name Noor Fatima before tying a matrimonial knot with the suspect. Her father said the video of embracing Islam and solemnising Nikkah was uploaded on social media. Following failure of police to recover the girl in last two weeks, members of the Hindu community came on roads in Liaquatpur in Rahim Yar Khan district blocking the main highway for traffic. Their protest entered the second day on Thursday with members of the community holding placards and banners outside the Liaquatpur Press Club and chanting slogans against forced conversions of Hindu girls. “Stop the forced conversion of Hindu girls after kidnapping them,” read a placard. During the protest the girl’s parents reportedly threatened that they would set their house ablaze if they were not provided justice. Police, however, assured the protesters that they would use all possible resources to provide them justice. Umar Farooq Salamat, Rahim Yar Khan’s top police officer, said that he has sent a police party to Karachi for the recovery of the girl. The protesters ended their demonstration after being assured by police that the justice would be done. Last month, two minor Hindu sisters, Raveena and Reena were allegedly kidnapped, forced to accept Islam and then got married to Muslim men in Ghotki town of Sindh . Following marriages of the girls, they were moved to Rahim Yar Khan.

title: Barkas murder victim’s kin seek fresh investigation
og_title: Barkas murder victim’s kin seek fresh investigation
content: CHARMINAR: Family members and relatives of a woman who was stabbed to death a month ago staged a protest demanding a fresh investigation into the murder on Friday. After Friday prayers at Barkas Badi Masjid, family members of the victim and others who had come to offer prayers at the mosque held the protest outside the mosque. They alleged that the Chandrayangutta police had let off key conspirators behind the murder of Fatima Sadi, 22, a resident of Salala Barkas, who was stabbed to death by her husband Ahmed Ba Ismail on March 5.“The accused had surrendered before the Chandrayangutta police, but the other key conspirators were let off by the police,” they said. "The slow pace of investigation has forced us to raise our voice against the injustice. We have been protesting and demanding fair and transparent probe into the matter and will move the court against the injustice,” said Ali Saadi, the victim’s father. Station House Officer, Chandrayangutta, G. Koteshwar Rao termed the allegations baseless and said that the probe was conducted as per law. "Following complaints, the accused were booked and jailed,'' said Rao. The protesters also demanded that the kin of the accused be moved out of the locality.

title: Sudan protest leaders to unveil civilian ruling body
og_title: Sudan protest leaders to unveil civilian ruling body
content: KHARTOUM: Protest leaders Friday announced plans to unveil a civilian body to take over from Sudan 's ruling military council as crowds of demonstrators kept up the pressure outside army headquarters and Washington said it will send an envoy to encourage the transition. The military council, which took power after ousting Sudan 's longtime leader Omar al-Bashir on April 11, has so far resisted calls from protesters to quickly make way for a civilian adminstration. The Sudanese Professionals Association, which has been spearheading the protests, said in a statement that the civilian council members would be named at a news conference at 1700 GMT on Sunday outside the army complex to which foreign diplomats are also invited. "We are demanding that this civilian council, which will have representatives of the army, replace the military council," Ahmed al-Rabia, a leader of the umbrella group of unions for doctors, engineers and teachers, told AFP. Four months after anti-regime protests started, access roads were packed on Friday with crowds flocking to huge square outside army headquarters. Activists mobilised demonstrators through social media to keep up the pressure for replacing the military council, now led by General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan. "Power to civilians, power to civilians," protesters chanted through Thursday night. "I won't leave until Burhan transfers power to a civilian government," said Wali Aldeen, who has camped outside the complex since the day Bashir was ousted. Activists have called for large crowds to gather after weekly Muslim prayers, as on previous Fridays. Protests first broke out on December 19 in response to the tripling of bread prices, swiftly turning into nationwide rallies against Bashir's three-decade rule. After his ouster, protesters demonstrated against General Awad Ibn Ouf who took over as the first head of the military council, insisting he was a tool of the old regime. Ibn Ouf stepped down in less than 24 hours and was replaced by Burhan, who so far has appeased protesters by lifting a night-time curfew and vowing to "uproot" Bashir's circle. The United States on Thursday praised orders by Sudan 's new military leader to free political prisoners and end the curfew as it dispatched Makila James , a deputy assistant secretary of state, on a mission to Khartoum this weekend. The United States will "calibrate our policies based on our assessment of events", State Department spokeswoman Morgan Ortagus said, adding however that talks on delisting Sudan as a state sponsor of terrorism remained suspended. "We are encouraged by the decision to release political prisoners and cancel the curfew in Khartoum," Ortagus said in a statement. She said that the United States wanted the military council and other armed units to "show restraint, avoid conflict and remain committed to the protection of the Sudanese people." "The will of the Sudanese people is clear: it is time to move toward a transitional government that is inclusive and respectful of human rights and the rule of law," she said. A senior US official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Washington's short-term goal was to "get the military folks out of centre-stage" and "back to being responsible for security, nothing else." "Longer term is to make absolutely sure that whichever group is going to be responsible for the transition prepares a transition implementation that will lead to a truly democratic government that will reflect the will of the Sudanese people," he said. The official did not specify whom James would meet in Khartoum but said, "the US engages with everyone."

title: Indonesian President's poll rival warns of protests
og_title: Indonesian President's poll rival warns of protests
content: Indonesian authorities warned against unrest as a firebrand ex-general Prabowo Subianto rejected unofficial poll results that appeared to hand President Joko Widodo another term. Subianto said he would challenge the result in court and would stage protests.

title: Former Assam CM Prafulla Kumar Mahanta abstains from voting in protest against Citizenship Bill
og_title: Former Assam CM Prafulla Kumar Mahanta abstains from voting in protest against Citizenship Bill
content: GUWAHATI: Assam Agitation patriarch and former CM Prafulla Kumar Mahanta did not vote on Thursday in protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Bill , which BJP has promised to bring back. “I didn’t exercise my franchise. I have been saying from the very beginning that the Citizenship (Amendment) Bill is a danger to the state”, he said.

title: HC: Protests are OK, but follow noise rules
og_title: HC: Protests are OK, but follow noise rules
content: MUMBAI: The Bombay HC on Thursday said citizens have right to organise public meetings and peaceful demonstrations using loudspeakers in public places but subject to noise control rules and except in designated silence zones. A bench of Chief Justice Pradeep Nandrajog and Justice NM Jamdar gave the direction while hearing a PIL filed by advocate Abha Singh over denial of police permission to use loudspeakers at a protest at Carter Road Amphitheatre last year. The court agreed with Singh's submissions and said demonstrations and dissent is the backbone of democracy . The HC said "use of loudspeaker is permissible within city limits subject to applicable decibel limits and timings stipulated by rules" including the Noise Pollution Rules and the petitioner will have the right to use loudspeakers in accordance with the law and rules. If Singh applies for permission to conduct a demonstration in a public place, police shall accord the necessary permission, said the HC. The only consideration to be kept in mind is that it should not cause traffic congestion or problems, it added. The court said police should display application of mind and not act in a high-handed manner. The Chief Justice expressed displeasure over the manner in which section 37 of the Bombay Police Act was being used every 15 days by the police to issue circulars banning use of loudspeakers in public places. The section empowers police to pass orders for a temporary period to prevent disorder or social unrest in an area. The DCP-headquarters of Mumbai police commissioner was present and on his behalf, additional government pleader Abhay Patki assured the HC that in future, the merits of a case would also be looked into.

title: Ludhiana: BJYM protests against Congress MP Bittu in Ludhiana
og_title: Ludhiana: BJYM protests against Congress MP Bittu in Ludhiana
content: LUDHIANA: Continuing with their ongoing drive to highlight failures of Congress MP Ravneet Bittu the members of Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha staged a protest in Salem Tabri and Chander Nagar on Thursday. The leaders claimed that Congress MP did nothing in past five years and to befool the voters Congress displayed big hoardings at various places. The leaders claimed that Congress has always made false promises with the voters and Bittu is also one of those Congress leaders who did not keep their promise. The president of BJYM Mahesh Sharma said Bittu in his hoardings claimed Rs 4.38 crore was spent for cleaning of Buddha Nullah but heaps of garbage can be seen at many locations inside the drain. He further said due to pollution in drain people are becoming sick and are suffering from serious diseases. He said the voters will give befitting reply to Bittu and Congress by not supporting the MP in this election. He said they will continue this drive against Congress in the coming days as well.

title: Punjab Roadways employees to protest against minister
og_title: Punjab Roadways employees to protest against minister
content: Jalandhar: Punjab Roadways Employees Joint Action Committee has threatened to hold a protest march against the Congress government’s failure to fulfil its promise of ending mafia control on transport. The employees will hold a protest in transport minister Aruna Chaudhary’s Dinanagar constituency on April 27. Addressing a press conference here, the committee leaders said protests will be held at all 18 depots of Punjab Roadways in the state. “Congress had announced that it would end transport mafia in the state and stregthen public sector undertakings. However, after coming to power, the Punjab government has failed to implement decisions of Supreme Court and high court and illegal operations of private buses are continuing,” said action committee leader Mangat Khan. They also alleged that before polls, Capt Amarinder Singh had announced to provide jobs in every household but was planning to merge Punjab Roadways and Punbus into Pepsu Road Transport Corporation. “Quite a few rounds of meetings for the purpose have already been held, but that urgency is completely missing for ending transport mafia, stopping illegal operations of private buses,” they said.

title: 'AGP losing support of Assam Agitation martyrs' families'
og_title: 'AGP losing support of Assam Agitation martyrs' families'
content: GUWAHATI: The 'unclear stand' of the BJP-AGP alliance on the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, as viewed by the families of those killed in the anti-foreigners' movement in Assam, may bring to an end the inseparable association between the regional party and martrys' families after the Lok Sabha polls. The Sadou Asom Swahid Pariyal Samannayrakhi Parishad, the coordination committee of such families, had extended full support to AGP till the 1996 assembly polls when the party formed government in Assam for the second term. Though the support was there even after AGP's defeat in the 2001 assembly election, it slowly started diminishing due to a number of reasons. But now, these families are distancing themselves from the regional party that was formed by the agitators of the movement following the signing of the Assam Accord in 1985. "AGP leaders stated that though they have formed an alliance with BJP in this Lok Sabha polls, the regional party will think about the citizenship bill in its own way. But this very stand is suspicious. When AGP was part of the BJP-led government in Assam (since 2016), the coalition government failed to detect and deport illegal migrants as assured prior to the election. Instead, BJP tried hard to grant citizenship to illegal migrants (by attempting to pass the citizenship bill). We don't have much expectations from the alliance. So, we have left it to the people of Assam to decide on AGP's fate," said Chandra Kanta Talukdar, secretary of the coordination committee and younger brother of Khargeswar Talukdar, who is regarded as the first martyr of the anti-foreigners' movement. He added, "If AGP doesn't formulate a clear strategy to fight the primary issue of illegal migrants in Assam and keep itself engaged in alliance politics, we will be compelled to announce an alternate political decision for the sake of the martyrs' sacrifice before the 2021 assembly elections." Though Congress supported the anti-citizenship bill movement that swept Assam early this year, Talukdar said the martyrs' families have been considering the opposition party as an 'arch-rival' and their stand on Congress remains the same since the days of the anti-foreigners' movement. Considering all its limitations, a steering committee call has been given to the district units of the martyrs' families to choose 'competent candidates' whom they feel trustworthy for safeguarding the interests of Assam by curbing illegal influx. "At this moment, we have no other option than appealing to voters to chose the candidates whom they believe competent for raising their issues in Parliament. We are no more in a position to support one particular political party, especially after seeing the hazy stand of AGP and BJP on the citizenship issue," said Talukdar. Upset over the NDA government's move to pass the controversial citizenship bill in the Lok Sabha in January, several families of those killed in the anti-foreigners movement had returned the honours they had received from the Sarbananda Sonowal government in 2016. AGP, which had parted ways with BJP at that time following differences over the citizenship bill, had also expressed solidarity with the martyrs' families. However, its decision to rejoin the BJP alliance on the eve of the 2019 Lok Sabha polls was opposed by the families.

title: Punjab: Protest march for next phase of Bargari protest
og_title: Punjab: Protest march for next phase of Bargari protest
content: BATHINDA: The 21-member committee appointed by Sarbat Khalsa-appointed Akal Takht jathedar Jagtar Singh Hawara took out a protest march from a gurdwara at Burj Jawahar Singhwala village to Bargari on Wednesday. To chalk out plan to start the next phase of the Bargari Insaf Morcha sit-in, they decided to hold a meeting in Amritsar on April 28. The Bargari Morcha was earlier held for three demands pertaining to arrest of all those guilty of acts of sacrilege, arrest of cops guilty of killing two protesters at Behbal Kalan village on October 14, 2015, and release of all detainees who have completed their jail terms. The Hawara committee members, Narain Singh Choura and Ramandeep Singh Bhangchari, said that before the akhand path at Gurdwara Tibbisar at Behbal Kalan, a protest march was taken out from Burj Jawahar Singhwala village, from where bir of Guru Granth Sahib was stolen in 2015. “The march concluded at Behbal Kalan, where the first case of sacrilege was reported on October 12, 2015. Now, the committee will decide on its next course of action for protest in Amritsar on April 28.” They added that as the Insaaf Morcha was lifted without the acceptance of their, it is important that justice is done in the next phase of morcha. Earlier, Sarbat Khalsa appointed jathedar Dhian Singh Mand had taken up the morcha, but now he is not part of the protest by Hawara committee. After Mand had lifted the protest from Bargari after over six months, many organisations had accused him of doing it in a only on the assurance of two ministers of Congress government that their their demands would be accepted.

title: Bombay HC says police may permit peaceful protests with loudspeakers within noise rules
og_title: Bombay HC says police may permit peaceful protests with loudspeakers within noise rules
content: MUMBAI: In a PIL filed by advocate Abha Singh over denial of use of loudspeakers last year by police at a protest, a bench of Chief Justice Pradeep Nandrajog and Justice NM Jamdar on Thursday directed that she has a right to organise public meetings and peaceful demonstrations in public places except in designated silence zones. The court also held that “use of loudspeaker is permissible within city limits subject to applicable decibel limits and timings stipulated by rules” including the Noise Pollution Rules and the petitioner will have the right to use loudspeakers in accordance with the law and rules. If advocate Singh applies for any permission to conduct a demonstration in a public place, the Mumbai Police shall accord the necessary permission, said the HC. The only consideration to be kept in mind is that it should not cause any traffic congestion or problems, it added. The court also said that Mumbai Police should display due application of mind and should not act in any highhanded manner. The chief justice further expressed displeasure at the manner in which section 37 of the Bombay Police Act was being used every 15 days for 365 days a year by issuance of circulars by the police banning the use of loudspeakers in public places. The section empowers police to pass orders for a temporary period to prevent disorder or social unrest in an area. The DCP headquarter of Mumbai Police Commissioner was present in person and on his behalf, the additional government pleader Abhay Patki assured the HC that in future, the merits of a case would also be looked into. Singh and other NGOs were denied permission last year to use loudspeakers at Carter Road Amphitheatre, and hence she had approached the HC. The court agreed with her submissions and said that demonstrations and dissent are the backbone of democracy.

title: Where are new homes? Ghatkopar transit camp residents to boycott polls
og_title: Where are new homes? Ghatkopar transit camp residents to boycott polls
content: MUMBAI: On Wednesday afternoon, a group of women from Amrut Nagar transit camp in Ghatkopar (W) took to the streets with placards—protesting against the government and politicians for ignoring their demand to get their “promised new homes” under the slum rehabilitation project for a decade. The residents of this transit camp have decided to boycott the Lok Sabha elections to protest against this “inordinate delay.” There are nearly 1,000 registered voters in the Ramnagar-A transit accommodation in two seven-storey buildings—Sindhudurg and Sinhagad. “We have been running from pillar to post seeking redressal to expedite the SRA project. We were promised that the project would be completed in 18 months, but its been nearly 10 years and the project is still in limbo,” said Sulochana Bhalekar, who was holding a placard: “Pratham zopdi dharkache ghar, nantar tumhala mat (First give slum-dwellers their homes, then we will vote for you).” “We are fed up with false assurances. Every time we are told that the project will kick off the next week or the next month, but it never happens. So, this time, we have decided not to go to the polling booths on April 29. We will boycott the elections.” Project developer Praful Satra told TOI that the project was stuck for seven years (2011-2018) due to civil aviation permission and then there was an issue of providing 300-sq ft carpet area flats to each family, which was recently resolved. “We have started work and will give them homes in two years,” he said. A senior SRA official told TOI that regular hearings were being conducted for over 300 famlies at the transit camp to resolve their issues with the developer. “We will look into the issues raised by Amrut Nagar transit camp occupants,” the official said.

title: Ghaziabad: Youth shot dead for liquor protest
og_title: Ghaziabad: Youth shot dead for liquor protest
content: GHAZIABAD: A 24-year-old man was shot dead in Modinagar on Wednesday. The deceased, Dipendra, was from Krishna Kunj area. The crime took place around 5 pm when Dipendra was in the house of his friend Vicky Tyagi on Tibra road. Five men allegedly barged into the house and fired 12 bullets. Six of those hit Dipendra. He was taken to a nearby private hospital, where he was declared brought dead. Sources said there was tension in the area after a liquor shop opened. Women opposed it and Dipendra was on their side. On Wednesday, Dipendra and a rival group had an argument over it. Modinagar SHO Sanjeev Sharma said: “We are yet to receive a complaint.”

title: APPSC rejects call to postpone exam dates
og_title: APPSC rejects call to postpone exam dates
content: VIJAYAWADA: Candidates for Group-2, panchayat secretary and other competitive examinations staged a protest at Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission ( APPSC ) on Tuesday, demanding the date of examinations be postponed. K Subramanyam, an aspirant from Guntur, requested the board postpone the notification till the government gave some clarity on reservations for Economically Backward Classes . “Union government had introduced EBC reservations for the poor in Other Castes. APPSC brought out 33 notifications before the reservations came into force. A majority of the examinations are about to start from Wednesday and students will lose their right of availing reservations,” he said. Aspirants face problems in appearing for the examinations due to the hot weather, Subramanyam said. P Udaya Bhaskar, APPSC chairman, said EBC reservations cannot be implemented for the 33 notifications already issued as they date before the EBC bill came into force. Bhaskar asked aspirants to cooperate with the commission as there are no free dates to conduct examinations in the upcoming three months.

title: Coordination committee formed to avert student protests
og_title: Coordination committee formed to avert student protests
content: Karnal: To avert more trouble after Industrial Training Institute (ITI) case, Superintendent of Police (SP) Surinder Singh Bhoria has constituted a coordination committee between students, teachers and police team. Its purpose is to help resolve such problems in future. The SP said strict action would be taken against outsiders who might try to interfere in this matter or go against the law. He said for security of students, two traffic police personnel have been deployed on the ITI Chowk to help them stop buses. Apart from this, adequate arrangements have been made by the district police to save students from any inconvenience. On April 12, police used batons and tear gas to disperse the protesting students who allegedly indulged in stone pelting after the death of an ITI student. He was crushed by a roadways bus. Superintendent of police Surinder Singh Bhoria said: “We are studying the CCTV footage to investigate the matter. It is also suspected that some outsiders were involved in the case who were provoking others and indulging in stone pelting.”

title: Unfazed by protests in Khajuraho, VD Sharma says all is well
og_title: Unfazed by protests in Khajuraho, VD Sharma says all is well
content: BHOPAL: After strong protests in Khajuraho against naming VD Sharma as BJP candidate for Lok Sabha seat , the local party cadre has urged the party chief to reconsider his decision. Sharma’s candidature evoked sharp criticism from local BJP leaders. The party leaders have now asked national president Amit Shah to reconsider Sharma’s name. Khajuraho, so far was represented by Nagendra Singh - who hails from Satna. Unfazed by the protests against him, Sharma told TOI over phone, “All is well. Everything is under control and there is enthusiasm among the party workers to work for BJP win.” Sanjay Nagaich, a prominent BJP leader from Panna - a part of Khajuraho seat said, “The outsider factor is dominating here and we have asked the party leadership to reconsider Sharma’s candidature.” He claimed, “It is very difficult to convince the people and local workers and the moment they learnt that VD Sharma belongs to Chambal region, they start protesting.” Nagaich said Khajuraho people suffered last time as well as Nagendra Singh also hailed from Satna. He said, BJP had made an assurance to give him the Lok Sabha ticket, but backed out at the last moment. Amidst protests on Tuesday, Sharma held a meeting of party workers in Panna. He said, “All those who have been protesting belong to the BJP family and many of them have worked with me. Now they have given up the protests and have decided to work for the party.” Several protests took place on Tuesday in Panna and Chattarpur where Sharma’s effigies were burnt and posters with “VD Sharma Wapis Jao” (VD Sharma go back) message were displayed. Virendra Khatik, the party candidate from neighbouring Tikamgarh also faces a similar problem. “In fact, he is banking heavily on PM Narendra Modi and party president Amit Shah’s campaign beginning later this week.” party sources said. A senior BJP leader, who had contested Rajya Sabha elections has also lodged a complaint with organisational general secretary Ramlal about the issue of outsiders being fielded from Bundelkhand.

title: Salary on hold, Jet staffers in Kolkata stare at bleak future
og_title: Salary on hold, Jet staffers in Kolkata stare at bleak future
content: KOLKATA: For 10 years, Sajal Goswami (37) has been loading luggage onto and off Jet Airways planes at Kolkata airport. At the end of the month, he took home Rs 14,000 that was sufficient to pay for the family's modest needs. The last wage he received was in end-February. When the cash-starved airline failed to pay the salary for March, Goswami did not disclose anything to his parents or wife. But they came to know about the truth when he was unable to pay his son's tuition fees at the beginning of this month. Ranjan Hazra (45), a maintenance helper with the airline for 14 years, has not received his wage in March. His salary of Rs 15,500 was enough to make ends meet. With no salary for 46 days, he has run up dues at the local provision store and also borrowed money from friends with no idea when he will be able to repay the debts. Goswami and Hazra are among 462 contactual employees in Kolkata, who are struggling to come to terms with the reality of an airline, which is precariously perched on the cusp of going bust. They have launched an agitation before the old domestic terminal at Kolkata airport, sitting on dharna before the Jet Airways office and holding rallies. "If the management does not listen, we may escalate the movement to a hungerstrike," said Goswami. Sadly, even those in managerial positions in the airline also face an uncertain future and are in no position to provide any assurance. Right from veteran pilots with salary of 4 lakh to airport ground staff drawing Rs 30,000-35,000 a month, there has been no salary since February. Even those who drew fancy salaries like general managers and pilots are feeling the pinch as they have not been paid for three months. A captain, who has been with Jet Airways for two decades, has restricted his social life to not only avoid the embarrassment of answering awkward questions on the company and his future, but also to cut down on expense. "One cuts one's coat according to the cloth. I led a certain life when I had a regular salary. I tried to maintain that for a couple of months. But with savings now getting depleted, I have to make adjustments," said the captain who has earned around Rs 4 lakh, a month of which EMI accounted for Rs 1.25 lakh. While he is in a position to cut down on his expenses and eke out a living till the airline revives or he finds employment, a young pilot with salary of Rs 1 lakh, who had taken a loan of Rs 30 lakh against an EMI of around Rs 30,000 to get trained for Jet Aiways, is now staring at defaults and his family house being confiscated by the bank. "I had mortaged the house for the loan, hoping to pay it off in three years. But soon I may be without a roof if the airline doesn't start flying again," he said. Suddho Ghosh, who had joined Jet Airways in 1994, the year the airline started services from Kolkata, before quitting it to join Kingfisher Airlines that he left just before the airline went bust, says the Jet scenario is a virtual replay of what happened at Kingfisher in 2012-13. "The wife of a Bengali engineer who was posted in Mumbai had committed suicide due to the financial turmoil that the family had been thrust into after Kingfisher was grounded. I am praying Jet employees and their family members are more resilient. Like Jet, Kingfisher too had started defaulting on pay before it shut down," he remarked

title: Murder, not suicide, allege Jyotsna’s kin
og_title: Murder, not suicide, allege Jyotsna’s kin
content: VISAKHAPATNAM: The death of a first-year engineering (BTech) student Singupalle Jyotsna (21) has turned into a conundrum for city police as leaders and activists of various women’s organisations in the city on Tuesday claimed that Jyotsna was murdered but her death was made to appear as a suicide . It may be recalled that Jyotsna, a resident of Malkapuram, was found dead under suspicious circumstances — she was found hanging from the ceiling fan at her lecturer’s house in Shanthinagar on April 15. The lecturer, Akkur Kishlay told the police that he found Jyotsna dead in his house Although the police have registered a case under Section 174 of CrPC (suspicious death), parents, family members and women organisations are demanding that the police register a case of murder against Kishlay. Sources said that Kishlay and his colleague Patel Niranjan, from Uttar Pradesh , live in a flat in Shantipuram. Jyotsna, who was a first year BTech student from a private college, was once a student of Kishlay. It was learnt that Jyotsna had proposed Kishlay, who had rejected her. Inspector of Fourth-Town police station Y Ravi said that they are investigating the case from various aspects based on the versions of the victim’s family members, parents and the lecturer. “So far no arrests have been made in the case and we have not changed the Sections as the investigation is still on,” he added.

title: Residents protest supply of foul drinking water in Indore
og_title: Residents protest supply of foul drinking water in Indore
content: INDORE: Residents of Shivshakti Nagar , Bengali Square, Nath Mandir and nearby areas on Tuesday staged protest against contaminated drinking water supply . They complained that they were getting contaminated water for past two months increasing risk of various water-borne diseases. Residents reached Shivshakti Nagar overhead tank at around 9.00am and started protesting against Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC). They alleged that despite repeated requests, no action has been taken to solve their problems. “We are living under constant threat of diseases as water supplied to our area is mixed with sewerage water,” Gunita Bhalekar, one of the protesting residents said. Mahesh Tayde another protesting resident said that the water is often yellow in colour and emanates foul smell. “This is the water we are supposed to use for drinking, cooking and other purposes?” he said. Protesting residents said that they were left with no option but to launch protest. “A number of times we have raised the issue with ward corporator, but problem remains. Corporation has not taken any step to resolve our problem,” they added. Residents entered zonal office premises and started chanting slogans against IMC. The protest ended after MC officials assuring them to solve the problem in next two days. IMC’s additional commissioner Sandeep Soni said that instructions have been issued to check supply lines of the area. “There might be a leakage in water supply line and drainage line network, owing to which drain water is getting mixed with Narmada water. We are checking pipelines for leakage,” he said, adding that problem will be solved within two days, and till then we will make arrangement for supply through tanker.

title: No water, no vote: Dhamni Valley villagers boycott polls
og_title: No water, no vote: Dhamni Valley villagers boycott polls
content: KOLHAPUR: Representatives of the Dhamni Khora Vikas Kruti Samiti, which comprises about 60 clusters of villages on the banks of River Dhamni, forced a team of election officials to beat a retreat on Tuesday afternoon. Election officials literally “faced the music” as the villagers sang “powadas” (ballads) to them when the officials sought reasons for why they were planning to boycott Lok Sabha polls. The villagers are determined to boycott polling here, scheduled on April 23. Officials have been visiting them to persuade them to vote . People in these villages are facing the worst spell of water scarcity in about three decades. There are about 35,000 eligible voters in the 60 villages of Dhamni Valley, large enough numbers to swing the election outcome in Kolhapur constituency. And indeed the people of the area have swung results in the past two Lok Sabha elections. Water experts say it is ironical that although the Dhamni river basin receives an average of over 5,000 mm of rainfall, there is no dam to hold water and it flows away. Villagers have erected makeshift weirs, at their own expense, to store what water they can, especially for use in summer. The gram panchayats of the cluster villages passed the resolutions to boycott polling and submitted them to the district administration, the chief minister’s office, and the state governor’s office. “We have just got a reply from district collector’s office, seeking to convince us to exercise our franchise on April 23. The collector visited Mhasurli village , the centre of the Dhamni river basin, on Sunday, April 14, to convince us to vote. We are not going to budge. Until there is a resolution to our water problems, we will not vote,” said Sarjerao Patil, one of the members of the action committee formed to address the issue. Patil said that after elections were announced, a few political candidates visited the villages. They were all ignored by villagers. Villager Shahaji Patil said farmers have to pay from their pockets for digging weirs in the river bed. The water lasts just a few weeks, sometimes days. The gram sabhas last month appealed to villagers to unite against the government and its disinterest in the issues that matter to them. “We are committed, we are united, and we want a resolution on the issue in any case. We are not going to help any politician, unless he addressed the issue or at least tries to resolve it,” he said. District collector and returning officer Daulat Desai told TOI, that work on the dam is set to begin, once the stay imposed on it is lifted and the dues owed to the former contractor are paid. New tenders will then be floated, he said. “Villagers should understand that whether they boycott polling or not, work on the dam will begin. And if work is going to start, why cannot they just exercise their franchise,” the collector asked. Dam 80% complete; stuck since 2012 Dhamni Dam, with total capacity of 3.85 TMC, according to district administration officials, was first sanctioned in 1996 with allocation of Rs 120 crore. It was meant to provide drinking water to villages in Radhanagari, Gaganbawda, and Panhala talukas. The project was delayed and approved again with revised administrative approval of Rs 320 crore in the year 2000. Construction is now 80% complete, and has been stuck since 2012. The contractor, according to sources, filed a case in court seeking payment of dues of Rs 277 crore in the year 2017. There have been 34 hearings in the matter so far, and the case continues. The next hearing is on April 25.

title: Cop accused of cheating woman after marriage vow
og_title: Cop accused of cheating woman after marriage vow
content: VIJAYAWADA: A 25-year-old woman staged a protest outside a police constable’s house alleging that he exploited her after promising her of marriage . The incident took place at Kilesapuram village under Ibrahimpatnam mandal in Krishna district on Tuesday. The woman later lodged a complaint with Ibrahimpatnam police against the constable identified as P Joseph who is stationed at Vijayawada thermal power station. According to cops, the woman used to work in a private company and got acquainted to Joseph three years ago. He allegedly sexually exploited her under the pretext of marriage and love. The woman, in her complaint, claimed that after she disclosed the matter to both her parents, they agreed for marriage. “However, Joseph created a scene falsely accusing me of having an affair with another man just to avoid me,” the woman said while addressing the media. She went on to say, “he did not want to marry me so that he could get dowry elsewhere.” While Joseph’s parents are seeking for a settlement, the 25-year-old is seeking police action against him. Extending support to the victim, women activists reached Joseph’s house and raised slogans against him and his family members.

title: ‘Sukhbir in know of imaginary protest, forgets police firing’
og_title: ‘Sukhbir in know of imaginary protest, forgets police firing’
content: Jalandhar: Rubbishing allegations levelled by SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal and other Akali leaders during a rally here on Monday that late Master Gurbanta Singh showed black flags to B R Ambedkar when he visited Jalandhar in 1952, Congress candidate MP Santokh Singh Chaudhary asked the former deputy CM brush up his knowledge of history. The MP also challenged Sukhbir to reveal where he read about the incident of 1952. “Sukhbir needs to brush up his knowledge of history. Ambedkar never came to Jalandhar in 1952. He came in 1951 to Jalandhar and no such incident of protest took place at that time,” Chaudhary said, adding “Sukhbir must reveal that where he read about the incident of 1952.” “This is a completely false and hollow allegation as my father was on very good terms with Dr Ambedkar and there was no question of any protest during his visit to Jalandhar during those days. Protest is an imagination of Suikbir and other Akali leaders,” Chaudhary, said while addressing a public meeting at Phillaur on Tuesday. Taking a jibe at Sukhbir, Chaudhary said, “One can assess Sukhbir’s mind as on one hand he claims to know about the incident of 1952 which actually never happened, but on the other forgets the gruesome incident of sacrilege and killing of four Sikh youths in police firing of 1986 even as it is already being hotly debated for the last some months.” The Congress MP also said that even SAD candidate Charanjit Singh Atwal, who was Punjab assembly speaker when report of Justice Gurnam Singh Commission was tabled in the state assembly in 2001, had said that it was for the government to take action but Sukhbir feigned ignorance and it was clear that SAD-BJP government hushed up the matter.

title: Bijnor women protest against Azam remark on Jaya Prada
og_title: Bijnor women protest against Azam remark on Jaya Prada
content: Bijnor: Two days after Samajwadi Party leader leader Azam Khan allegedly passed an objectionable comment on actor-turned-politician Jaya Prada, who is BJP candidate from Rampur, women in Bijnor assembled here on Tuesday to protest against Khan. They wrote an open letter to the President demanding that Azam Khan be declared ‘undeserving’ to contest elections. The women protested under the banner of Durga Vahini., women wing of Vishwa Hindu Parishad. A case has been registered against Khan in Rampur for allegedly making derogatory remark against his electoral rival Jaya Prada. However Khan claimed he did not refer to Jaya Prada in his speech. He is contesting from Rampur. Women under the banner of Durga Vahini gathered at Nagar Palika Chowk and staged a protest against the remark. They went to the collectorate and handed over a memorandum to SDM, Bijnor, Brajesh Singh, to be forwarded to the President. Addressing the gathering, city president of Vahini Archna Chaudhary said, “Azam Khan’s statement is extremely disrespectful. He insulted all women. Such type of men should not be allowed to go scot-free and should be sent to jail. If such people are elected as MP and go to Parliament, it will be an insult to the nation. We women demand that he should not be allowed to contest the polls.”

title: Madhya Pradesh: Amidst more protests BJP candidate in Khajuraho says 'all is well'
og_title: Madhya Pradesh: Amidst more protests BJP candidate in Khajuraho says 'all is well'
content: BHOPAL: Amidst more protests against the BJP candidate from Khajuraho VD Sharma on Monday, local party leaders have asked the national president Amit Shah to “reconsider” his name. However, VD Sharma told TOI over phone , “Everything is under control and there is enthusiasm among the party workers to work for the BJP victory." The protests started soon after the BJP declared the name of VD Sharma as the BJP candidate from Khajuraho, so far represented by Nagendra Singh , who hails from Satna. Sanjay Nagaich, a prominent BJP leader from Panna, part of Khajuraho seat, said, “ the outsider factor is dominating here and we have asked the party leadership to reconsider his candidature.” He claimed, “ it is very difficult to convince the people and the local workers and the moment they learn that VD Sharma belongs to Chambal region, they start protest.” He said that Khajuraho people suffered last time as Nagendra Singh also belonged to Satna. He said that the party had made commitment to him to give ticket for the Lok Sabha elections but denied at the last moment. Amidst protests, on Tuesday, Sharma held meeting of party workers in Panna. Talking to TOI, he said, “ all those who have been protesting belong to the BJP family and many of them have worked with me. Now they have given up the opposition and have decided to work for the party.” Large number of protests took place on Tuesday in Panna and Chattarpur where his effigies were burnt and posters were displayed with “ VD Sharma vapis jao “ written on it. Virendra Khatiq , the party candidate from the neighbouring Tikamgarh also faces similar problem. “In fact, he is banking heavily on PM Narendra Modi and party president Amit Shah’s campaigns beginning later this week”, party sources said. A senior BJP leader who had contested Rajya Sabha election has also lodged complaint with Ramlal , organisational general secretary about the issue of outsiders in Bundelkhand.”

title: Adhir begins protest after assault on Cong ranks
og_title: Adhir begins protest after assault on Cong ranks
content: Behrampore: Congress MP Adhir Chowdhury began a protest here on Monday night after his party workers were alleg-edly beaten up at Burwan in Kandi subdivision. On Tuesday morning, police arrested Trinamool supporters Mahe Alam and Babai Chowdhury over the incident. Congress leader Tapas Dasgupta was allege-dly attacked on Monday afternoon while campaigning for the former Pradesh Congress president. He received injuries in his hands and legs and was hospitalised. “Trinamool leaders are saying it will be a repetition of the panchayat polls. They have started attacking our leaders out of desperation in order to create an ambience of fear. Our workers were seriously injured. We do not have any complaint about the Election Commission, but the police are not impartial,” said Chowdhury, who held the protest near the statue of Mahatma Gandhi. Gautam Roy, president of Trinamool Congress’ Kandi subdivision, said his party was not behind the incident. “It could have been out of a personal grudge. Chowdhury is trying to draw media attention. But we will definitely get people’s support in his constituency,” he said.

title: Nearly 300 arrested at London climate protests
og_title: Nearly 300 arrested at London climate protests
content: LONDON: Nearly 300 people have been arrested in ongoing climate change protests in London that brought parts of the British capital to a standstill, police said on Tuesday. Demonstrators began blocking off a bridge and major central road junctions on Monday at the start of a civil disobedience campaign that also saw action in other parts of Europe. The protests were organised by the campaign group Extinction Rebellion, which was established last year in Britain by academics and has become one of the world's fastest-growing environmental movements. London's Metropolitan Police said that by Tuesday evening, 290 arrests had been made. "We expect demonstrations to continue throughout the coming weeks," the police statement said. The arrest figure includes three men and two women who were detained at the UK offices of energy giant Royal Dutch Shell on suspicion of criminal damage. Campaigners daubed graffiti and smashed a window at the Shell Centre building. The majority arrested were seized for breaching public order laws and obstructing a highway. The protest saw more than a thousand people block off central London's Waterloo Bridge and lay trees in pots along its length. Later, people set up camps in Hyde Park in preparation for further demonstrations throughout the week. The police have ordered the protesters to confine themselves to a zone within Marble Arch, a space at the junction of Hyde Park, the Oxford Street main shopping thoroughfare and the Park Lane street of plush hotels. "We so far have 55 bus routes closed and 500,000 people affected as a result," the police said. London mayor Sadiq Khan said he was "extremely concerned" about protesters' plans to disrupt the underground on Wednesday. "Targeting public transport in this way would only damage the cause of all of us who want to tackle climate change," he said in a statement. Campaigners want governments to declare a climate and ecological emergency, reduce greenhouse gas emissions to zero by 2025, halt biodiversity loss and be led by new "citizens' assemblies on climate and ecological justice". Extinction Rebellion spokesman James Fox said the group had attempted to maintain a blockade overnight at four sites in central London before the police came to impose the new restriction. Protesters attached themselves to vehicles and to each other using bicycle locks, said the spokesman. "We have no intention of leaving until the government listens to us," he said. "Many of us are willing to sacrifice our liberty for the cause."

title: Sukhbir Badal invokes ‘protest’ in 1952 to attack Congress candidate
og_title: Sukhbir Badal invokes ‘protest’ in 1952 to attack Congress candidate
content: JALANDHAR: Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) president Sukhbir Singh Badal invoked an incident which took place during B R Ambedkar’s alleged visit to Jalandhar in 1952 to attack the Congress candidate from the constituency, Santokh Singh Chaudhary, on Monday. Sukhbir, who was speaking at an election gathering in Buta Mandi here, said Chaudhary’s father, late Master Gurbanta Singh, had waved black flags to Ambedkar when he visited Jalandhar in 1952. The SAD had called the gathering to mark the birth anniversary of Ambedkar, which fell on Sunday. Apart from Sukhbir, SAD Jalandhar candidate Charanjit Singh Atwal and other speakers made it a point to recall the “protest with black flags” to attack Chaudhary. Even as SAD leaders claimed that Ambedkar visited Jalandhar in 1952, a check by TOI revealed that he visited Jalandhar in 1951 and addressed a huge gathering. BJP state president Shwait Malik also banked on the alleged protest in 1952 to attack the Congress candidate, and so did former BJP minister Manoranjan Kalia. Asked about the 1986 Nakodar incident in which four Sikh youths were killed in police firing at a protest, Sukhbir feigned ignorance. He said he was also unaware of the a report being tabled on the issue in the state assembly in 2001. “I don’t know about the case. I have no knowledge,” he said, even as party candidate Charanjit Singh Atwal mentioned the case in his speech and attacked Santokh Singh Chaudhary over it.

title: Sukhbir Badal knows about imaginary protest of 1952 but forgets about 1986 police firing which killed 4 Sikhs: Chaudhary Santokh Singh
og_title: Sukhbir Badal knows about imaginary protest of 1952 but forgets about 1986 police firing which killed 4 Sikhs: Chaudhary Santokh Singh
content: JALANDHAR: Rubbishing allegations levelled by SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal and other Akali leaders during a rally here on Monday that late Master Gurbanta Singh showed black flags to Dr BR Ambedkar when he visited Jalandhar in 1952, sitting Congress MP and now party candidate Chaudhary Santokh Singh asked Badal to brush up his knowledge of history and challenged him to reveal that where he read about the incident of 1952, which actually never happened. “Sukhbir needs to brush up his knowledge of history, which reveals that Dr Ambedkar never came to Jalandhar in 1952, rather it was in 1951, when he visited Jalandhar and no such incident of protest took place at that time,” Chaudhary said, adding “Sukhbir must reveal that where he read about the incident of 1952.” “This is a completely false and hollow allegation as my father was on very good terms with Dr Ambedkar and there was no question of any protest during his visit to Jalandhar during those days. Protest is an imagination of Suikbir and otehr Akali leaders,” Chaudhary said while addressing a public meeting at Phillaur on Tuesday. Taking a jibe at Badal for saying he did not know about the 1986 incidence of burning of Birs of Guru Granth Sahib and killing of four Sikh youths in police firing when they were protesting, Chaudhary said, “One can assess Sukhbir’s mind as on one hand he claims to know about the incident of 1952 which actually never happened, while on the other forgets the gruesome incident of sacrilege and killing of four Sikh youths in police firing of 1986 even as it is already being hotly debated for the last some mmonths”. Congress MP also said that even SAD candidate Charanjit Singh Atwal, who was Punjab assembly speaker when report of Justice Gurnam Singh Commission was tabled in the state assembly in 2001, had said that it was for the government to take action but Sukhbir feigned ignorance as it was clear that SAD-BJP government hushed up the matter. “How is it possible that even as the issue of killing of four Sikh youths in police firing in 1986 is being debated for a long time and has often made headlines in media reports, SAD chief Sukhbir Singh Badal can deny knowledge about the incident,” he asked.

title: Karnal accident: Bus driver held, student bodies protest
og_title: Karnal accident: Bus driver held, student bodies protest
content: KARNAL: Even as the police on Monday arrested the driver of the Haryana Roadways bus that ran over an Industrial Training Institute (ITI) student last week leading to a clash between students and police, a large number of Indian Nation Students' Organisation (INSO) and Jannayak Janata Party (JJP) Yova Morcha workers organized a protest march and burnt an effigy of the state government in the city. They were protesting against the police lathicharge on the ITI students on April 12. ASI Shyam Sunder said Lal Chand, a resident of Ugala village in Ambala district , was arrested from Karnal bus stand on Monday and he would be produced before a court on Tuesday. He has also been suspended by the transport department. The INSO and JJP members condemned the lathicharge on staff members and students inside the ITI campus and also demanded a judicial inquiry into the incident, besides compensation and government job for a member of the deceased's family. Meanwhile, ITI staff has announced that they would work wearing a black badge till action was taken against the culprits. They have also sought strict action against the guilty police personnel. Uttam Ghangas, INSO district president, said, "The students were protesting against the lack of buses, but the police used tear gas shells and fired in the air to chase them away. The state government is not serious towards the issue of the students. This government believes in clamping the voice of students rather than fulfilling their demands. INSO is standing with the students. The CM should tender an apology to them." They also gave a two-day ultimatum to the district administration to cancel the cases registered against the students, besides compensation to the family of the deceased otherwise they would protest again. Additional superintendent of police Mukesh Kumar on Monday recorded the statements of ITI principal Baldev Singh and his staff.

title: No fee regulation act yet, parents protest against hikes
og_title: No fee regulation act yet, parents protest against hikes
content: BHOPAL: With Private School Fee Regulation Act still awaiting enforcement, parents of the students studying in private schools continue to bear the brunt of fee hike. As many as 100 parents gathered outside Kamla Nehru School on Monday to protest against the alleged 25% increase in fee. Many schools are charging the increased fees citing different heads like library charges, sports fees and miscellaneous. Kamal Vishwakarma, president of the MP Parents Association (MPPA) said, “The proposal for framing the Private School Fee Regulation Act was made last year and till now it has not been implemeted. The act, once implemented, is likely to cap the fee hike by private schools at 10% subject to approval from education department. And now in the absence of norms, schools continue to increase fees as per their wish” The act requires the schools to submit their annual audit reports to the education department and only after the permission the schools can increase the fee by upto10%, said Prabodh Pandya, secretary of MPPA. “If the act was implemented, the schools wouldn’t have increased the fee this year. “Besides, schools are charging Rs 200, per child for sending the SMS update and also charging fee under many different heads,” he added. Sudam Khade, Collector of Bhopal, said that the act was still under process and was sent to the higher authorities of the education department for review.

title: Sudan protest leaders demand scrapping of military council
og_title: Sudan protest leaders demand scrapping of military council
content: KHARTOUM: Sudanese protest organisers on Monday demanded the new military council be scrapped, as demonstrators kept up calls for a civilian government at a sit-in outside army headquarters. Thousands of demonstrators have continued to rally in support of demands for civilian rule, despite an apparent attempt to disperse them following the ouster last week of veteran president Omar al-Bashir . "We want the military council to be dissolved and be replaced by a civilian council having representatives of the army," said Mohamed Naji, a senior leader of the Sudanese Professionals Association. The organisation which spearheaded months of protests leading to Bashir's fall also demanded the sacking of the country's judiciary chief and prosecutor general. The SPA's latest demands came as the military council faced mounting public and diplomatic pressure to hand over power to a civilian administration. German Chancellor Angela Merkel called for "a rapid transfer of power to a civilian transitional government," in a phone call with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. "This must be followed by a credible, inclusive political process that meets the expectations of the Sudanese people with regard to economic and political reforms," her office said in a statement. Sisi meanwhile reiterated Egypt 's support for "the brotherly Sudanese people's will" and said Cairo would "not interfere in its internal affairs", according to a presidential statement. Their comments come a day after the Khartoum embassies of Britain, the United States and Norway issued a joint statement calling for "inclusive dialogue to effect a transition to civilian rule". Outside army headquarters crowds remained camped outside the complex, despite SPA warnings of "an attempt to disperse the sit-in". "We call on our people to come immediately to the sit-in area to protect our revolution," the SPA said in a statement, without saying who was responsible. Witnesses said several army vehicles had surrounded the area and that troops were seen removing the barricades which demonstrators had put up as a security measure. "I felt frustrated when they tried to break the sit-in, but I still trust the army because it's not possible that they would give up on protesters," said demonstrator Mohamed al-Fatih. Portraits of people killed in the months of rallies covered the facades of several buildings in the area. "Until we see tangible results, we are not moving from here," said protester Abdulhadi Hajj Ahmed. A 10-member delegation representing the protesters delivered a list of demands during talks with the council late Saturday, according to a statement by the Alliance for Freedom and Change umbrella group. But in a news conference, the council's spokesman did not respond to the protesters' demands. The military council however met with political parties on Sunday, urging them to agree on an "independent figure" to be prime minister, an AFP correspondent at the meeting said. "We want to set up a civilian state based on freedom, justice and democracy ," a council member, Lieutenant General Yasser al-Ata, told members of several political parties. The foreign ministry said military council head General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan was "committed to having a complete civilian government" and urged other nations to back the council in order to achieve "the Sudanese goal of democratic transition". Burhan has pledged that individuals implicated in killing protesters would be held to account and that demonstrators detained under a state of emergency imposed by the president during his final weeks in power would be freed. The SPA says Bashir must also face justice, along with officials from his feared National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS) whose chief Salih Ghosh resigned on Saturday. As part of the shake-up at the top, a new NISS head and army chief of staff have been appointed. Bashir ruled Sudan with an iron fist for 30 years before he was deposed last week following mass protests that have rocked the country since December. The SPA has additionally called for the confiscation of properties belonging to the ousted president's National Congress Party and the release of soldiers who sided with their movement. Late on Sunday, the military council said it has set up a committee to register NCP properties and seize control of them.
