title: Students and staff protest spike in water-borne diseases on BU campus
og_title: Students and staff protest spike in water-borne diseases on BU campus
content: BHOPAL: Students of (BU) are frequently contracting water-borne diseases as the quality of water supplied to the campus is reportedly of poor quality. A recent study, which took into account samples from different water sources available on the campus, revealed that water supplied to various departments, hostels and campus residences is not fit for consumption and contain — among other contaminants — the E Coli bacteria. However, surprisingly, BU officers are getting good quality water. The study — undertaken by a department of BU — has revealed that water distributed to students and employees in the campus is of very bad quality and they are vulnerable to several diseases.BU employees have complained to the university administration for allegedly supplying dirty water to them and clean water to the officers. On the condition of anonymity, a senior faculty of BU associated with the study claimed that BU needs to install better quality purifiers and water coolers. “Samples were collected from various parts of the university. Water quality is seriously poor,” said the faculty. He said waterborne pathogens are a global concern for worldwide public health. “Since pathogens in water are still a major cause of severe illness and mortality, the control, monitoring and application of regulations for water quality are urgently needed and must incorporate more effective microbiological monitoring, pathogen detection and health risk assessment in order to reach the goal of pathogen-free water,” he said. He added that index pathogens for monitoring water quality have been selected in order to indicate the presence of a large amount of pathogens in the campus water. He claimed that among these pathogens, E. Coli has been extensively present. “Water quality in BU is seriously bad. Anyone using it without purifiers is vulnerable. It needs to be checked,” said the faculty. Water distribution to the employees and officers of the university are reportedly from different sources. “Water distributed to the officers is from a cleaned well situated near the temple on the campus. We get water from a well near the aquaculture department. One look at the aquaculture well is enough to understand the poor quality of water being supplied to us,” said an employee who did not wish to be quoted. Incidentally, employees had written a letter to the higher authorities for supplying bad quality of water to them and in the hostels while the good quality of water is being provided to officers. Following this, the registrar had directed the engineers to address the issue within a week. Employees claim to have checked the total dissolved solids (TDS) of water distributed to them and the officers. Speaking on condition of anonymity, an employee said, “Officers are given water having TDS level of around 135, which implies that the water condition is good. On the contrary, the TDS level of water distributed to employees is over 450, which is not good for use.” TDS are inorganic compounds that are found in water such as salts, heavy metals and some traces of organic compounds that are dissolved in water. Excluding the organic matters that are sometimes naturally present in water and the environment, some of these compounds or substances can be essential in life. But, it can be harmful when the body takes in more than the desired amount. The university staff said they will protest against the administration to raise their demands. Incidentally, BU hostellers have already raised the issue of poor quality of water supplied to them. Though the registrar has directed the engineers to address the issue within a week, students called the directive a mere formality and questioned how the authorities can fix the issue in a week when they have been left unaddressed for years. Students claim that despite several complaints, no action was taken by the authorities. Incidentally, RTI activist and former student of BU, Dharmendra Singh Gour, on Saturday filed a complaint with Raj Bhawan for such poor conditions of the hostels. “I was also a hosteller in the past. I had never seen such a poor situation during my stay in the hostel. I hope higher authorities will look into the matter,” he said. The BU campus accommodates three boys’ hostels —Sanjay Gandhi, Munshi Premchand and Jawaharlal Nehru — each with a capacity for 100 students. Of these, Sanjay Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru are the worst-affected. University officials refused to comment on the issue.

title: Pensioners to protest during PM Modi's Nashik rally on April 22
og_title: Pensioners to protest during PM Modi's Nashik rally on April 22
content: NASHIK: When Prime Minister Narendra Modi reaches Pimpalgaon for a public rally on Monday, he will have to face thousands of pensioners from Nashik district who plan to protest "peacefully" against the government's failure to increase their pension. The pensioners are covered under the EPF-95 scheme, which is run by the Employees' Provident Fund Organisation. The protesters will carry banners and wear caps with a message during the rally, where Modi will campaign for Bharti Pawar, BJP candidate from Dindori, and Hemant Godse, Shiv Sena 's candidate from Nashik. "Before the 2014 Lok Sabha elections, the BJP promised to increase the pension under the EPF-95 scheme from Rs 1,000 to Rs 3,000 per month within 100 days of coming to power. However, the party has not kept its promise," said Raju Desle, president of the Nashik district EPF-95 pensioners' association. "We will not shout slogans during the rally but all pensioners will wear caps and hold banners asking why we should vote for the BJP," Desle said. Around 60 lakh pensioners in the country are covered under the EPF-95 scheme, including 13 lakh in the state. Nashik division alone has around 1.25 lakh pensioners, including 40,000 in Nashik district, under the scheme.

title: Sudan protesters demand 'immediate' civilian rule
og_title: Sudan protesters demand 'immediate' civilian rule
content: KHARTOUM: Sudanese protesters on Sunday demanded the country's military rulers "immediately" hand power over to a civilian government that should then bring ousted leader Omar al-Bashir to justice. Thousands remained encamped outside Khartoum's army headquarters to keep up pressure on a military council that took power after ousting Bashir on Thursday. The organisation that spearheaded the protests against Bashir, the Sudanese Professionals Association, called on the council "to immediately transfer power to a civilian government". The SPA also demanded the next "transitional government and the armed forces bring Bashir and all the chiefs of the National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS)... to justice". "The Sudanese Professionals Association calls on its supporters to continue with the sit-in until the revolution achieves its demands," it added. The military council later held a press conference at which its spokesman did not respond to the protesters' latest demands. Instead it announced the appointment of a new intelligence chief. Earlier the military council met with political parties and urged them to agree on an "independent figure" to be prime minister, an AFP correspondent present at the meeting said. "We want to set up a civilian state based on freedom, justice and democracy ," a council member, Lieutenant General Yasser al-Ata, told several political parties, urging them to agree on the figures to sit in civilian government. The protesters have insisted civilian representatives must join the military council. A 10-member delegation representing the protesters delivered their demands during talks with the council late Saturday, according to a statement by the Alliance for Freedom and Change umbrella group spearheading the rallies. The foreign ministry urged the international community to back the military council "to achieve the Sudanese goal of democratic transition". It said council chief General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan was "committed to having a complete civilian government and the role of the council will be to maintain the sovereignty of the country". Talks between protest leaders and Sudan 's new rulers were followed Sunday by a meeting between Washington's top envoy to Khartoum, Steven Koutsis, and the military council's deputy. Mohammad Hamdan Daglo, widely known as Himeidti, told Koutsis "about the measures taken by the military council to preserve the security and stability of the country," the official SUNA news agency reported. Himeidti is a field commander for the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) counter-insurgency unit, which rights groups have accused of abuses in the war-torn Darfur region. On Saturday, the military council's new chief General Burhan vowed to dismantle Bashir's regime, lifting a night-time curfew with immediate effect. He also pledged that individuals implicated in killing protesters would face justice and that protesters detained under a state of emergency imposed by Bashir during his final weeks in power would be freed. Burhan took the oath of office on Friday after his predecessor General Awad Ibn Ouf stepped down little more than 24 hours after Bashir's ouster. The United States, Britain and Norway said Sunday it was time for Sudan's military rulers and other parties to hold talks over the country's transition to civilian rule. "This must be done credibly and swiftly, with protest leaders, political opposition, civil society organisations, and all relevant elements of society, including women," the embassies of the three countries said in a statement. Tens of thousands of people have massed non-stop outside the army headquarters since April 6, initially to urge the military to back their demand that Bashir be removed. Burhan comes with less baggage from Bashir's deeply unpopular rule than Ibn Ouf, a former defence minister and longtime close aide of the deposed president. But while celebrating the fall of both men in quick succession, protesters remain cautious. Protest leaders say their demands include restructuring the country's feared NISS agency, whose chief Salih Ghosh resigned on Saturday. On Sunday night, the council announced the appointment of Lieutenant General Abu Baker Mustafa as the new head of NISS in a televised announcement in which it also announced the sacking of Khartoum's envoy to Washington Mohamed Atta. The newly formed 10-member transitional council contains several faces from Bashir's regime. On Saturday evening, the new military ruler named NISS deputy head Jalaluddin Sheikh to the council, with Himeidti as its deputy head. "Himeidti was part of the crimes that happened previously, but at least now he is on the side of the people," said Mohamed, a protester outside the army headquarters who gave only his first name for security reasons. Key regional power brokers Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have voiced support for the transitional council. Sudan is part of a UAE and Saudi-led military coalition fighting Iran-backed Huthi rebels in Yemen. But Qatar, which wielded some influence over Bashir's regime before Khartoum joined ranks with Riyadh in Yemen, has remained silent on the protests. The gas-rich country is locked in a nearly two-year-old diplomatic standoff with Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain and Egypt.

title: BJP warns of protests against govt's move to take over Padmanabha temple treasure
og_title: BJP warns of protests against govt's move to take over Padmanabha temple treasure
content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: BJP has questioned the UDF's silence on the state government's proposal in the Supreme Court that an eight- member-committee model, like the one for Guruyaur temple administration, should be set up for the management of Sree Padmanabha swamy temple. The BJP also warned the state government of strong protest if it decides to go ahead with the plan to 'usurp’ the temple. BJP state spokesperson B Gopalakrishnan has alleged that Kerala government was trying to bring the temple and its treasures worth crores under its control. "The government has no business in any temple. By proposing a Guruvayur-model administration, Pinarayi Vijayan is trying to usurp the temple. The temple and its treasure belongs to the deity and the deity belongs to the devotees. No government has any role in this. BJP would support the protests against the government plans to take over the temple administration," Gopalakrishnan said. Padmanabha Swamy temple is one of the richest temples in the world and the earstwhile Travancore royal family, the custodians of the temple, and a number of devotees and Hindu organisations have approached the Supreme Court against a Kerala high court verdict that the temple may be taken over by the state government. According to the BJP leader, the UDF leaders, especially Congress leaders who claim to have stood for the protection of faith in Sabarimala should openly declare their stand on the government's proposal. "Both these fronts have same objectives. The UDF must be thinking that the proposal would also give them opportunity in the future. Pinarayi Vijayan government will have to pay a heavy price if it goes ahead with its plans to control the temple and its belongings though its nominees. Government should better alter its stand and take steps to ensure that the administration of the temple rests with the devotees, not the government," he said.

title: Sudan protesters set demands as military rulers urge global support
og_title: Sudan protesters set demands as military rulers urge global support
content: KHARTOUM: Sudanese protesters demanded new military rulers set up a civilian government as the foreign ministry called Sunday for backing from the international community to help the country's "democratic transition". Thousands remained encamped outside Khartoum 's army headquarters overnight to keep up pressure on a military council that took power after ousting veteran leader Omar al-Bashir on Thursday. A 10-member delegation representing the protesters delivered their demands during talks with the council late Saturday, according to a statement by the Alliance for Freedom and Change umbrella group spearheading the rallies. "We will continue... our sit-in until all our demands are met," including the formation of a fully civilian government, said one of the alliance's leaders, Omar al-Degier. Later the military council met with political parties and urged them to agree on an "independent figure" to be the country's prime minister, an AFP correspondent present at the meeting said. "We want to set up a civilian state based on freedom, justice and democracy," a member of the military council Lieutenant General Yasser al-Ata told several political parties, urging them to agree on the figures to sit in civilian government. The protestors have insisted that civilian representatives must join the military council, and demanded that a fully civilian government be set up to run day-to-day affairs. Meanwhile,the foreign ministry urged the international community to back the military council "to achieve the Sudanese goal of democratic transition," it said in a statement. The council chief General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan is "committed to having a complete civilian government and the role of the council will be to maintain the sovereignty of the country", it added. Talks between protest leaders and Sudan's new rulers were followed Sunday by a meeting between Washington's top envoy to Khartoum, Steven Koutsis, and the military council's deputy. Mohammad Hamdan Daglo, widely known as Himeidti, told Koutsis "about the measures taken by the military council to preserve the security and stability of the country," the official SUNA news agency reported. Himeidti is a field commander for the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) counter-insurgency unit, which rights groups have accused of abuses in the war-torn Darfur region. On Saturday, the military council's new chief General Burhan vowed to dismantle Bashir's regime, lifting a night-time curfew with immediate effect. He also pledged that individuals implicated in killing protesters would face justice and that protesters detained under a state of emergency imposed by Bashir during his final weeks in power would be freed. Burhan took the oath of office on Friday after his predecessor General Awad Ibn Ouf stepped down little more than 24 hours after ousting Bashir. Tens of thousands of people have massed non-stop outside the army headquarters since April 6, initially to urge the military to back their demand that Bashir be removed. Burhan comes with less baggage from Bashir's deeply unpopular rule than Ibn Ouf, a former defence minister and long-time close aide of the deposed president. But while celebrating the fall of both men in quick succession, protesters remain cautious. Protest leaders say their demands include restructuring the country's feared National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS), whose chief Salih Ghosh resigned on Saturday. Rights group Amnesty International on Saturday urged the military council to examine Ghosh's actions during a crackdown against protesters during the final weeks of Bashir's rule. "It is crucial that Sudan's new authorities investigate Salah Ghosh's role in the killings of scores of Sudanese protesters over the past four months", said Amnesty's regional director Sarah Jackson. The newly formed 10-member transitional council contains several faces from Bashir's regime. On Saturday evening, the new military ruler named NISS deputy head Jalaluddin Sheikh to the council, with Himeidti as its deputy head. "Himeidti was part of the crimes that happened previously, but at least now he is on the side of the people," said Mohamed, a protester outside the army headquarters who gave only his first name for security reasons. Key regional power-brokers Saudi Arabia and the UAE have voiced backing for the transitional council. Burhan's nomination "reflects the ambitions of the brotherly people of Sudan for security, stability and development", UAE state news agency WAM said. Saudi Arabia has promised an aid package, the Saudi Press Agency reported on Saturday. Sudan is part of a UAE and Saudi-led military coalition fighting Iran-backed Huthi rebels in Yemen .

title: Taksal members protest Dera rally called to seek poll opinion
og_title: Taksal members protest Dera rally called to seek poll opinion
content: PATIALA: Tension gripped Banur after the members of Damdami Taksal blocked the Banur-Landran road to prevent Dera Sacha Sauda followers from holding a gathering here on Sunday. The Dera members had decided to hold 'Nam Charcha' as part of its inception ceremony but allegedly failed to take permission from the administration. Expecting a huge gathering, the Dera management had planned to hold the congregation at an open agricultural land. Sikhs in large numbers along with local Taksal head B S Parwana had arrived at the proposed congregation site. The Dera followers too had gathered there. However, police from Mohali and Banur reached the spot and vacated the Dera followers from the private land. They also issued prohibition orders over hold rallies without permission. Earlier, Damdami Taksal members had appealed to the district administration to not allow holding of the Dera rally and had given a two-hour ultimatum to take action. However, at around 1pm, the Taksal members blocked the road near Banur barrier in protest of no action being taken against the Dera followers holding the rally without permission. Mohali sub-registrar Rajpal Singh said, "The local Dera management was not allowed to hold the rally as they did not have permission in this regard. The followers were told to pack up at around 3pm. There was no tension as the Taksal members were protesting peacefully and within no time swift action was taken following which the gathering of Dera followers was not allowed." Sinder Paka, member of Dera's state political wing said, "We had already held these gathering under Nam Charcha in almost all the districts including Faridkot, Bathinda, Patiala, Muktsar, Ferozepur, Sangrur, Ludhiana and others, however, Mohali and Ropar are yet to be covered. We are only seeking opinion of the followers in which candidate or party to support in the upcoming elections." Rajpura DSP Manpreet Singh, said, "Everything remained peaceful and no case was registered against anyone. In fact, the matter was sorted out amicably after a discussion with the local Dera management who were asked to vacate the private land."

title: Protest against fee hike on April 21
og_title: Protest against fee hike on April 21
content: NOIDA: All Noida School Parents’ Association ( ANSPA ) on Sunday announced a protest march against fee hike on April 21. The association has been working on bringing all parents under a single roof to raise their voice against ad hoc fee structure of private schools in Noida. The association claims that despite the district fee regulation in place, no school in Noida has paid heed to the Uttar Pradesh Fee Regulation Act (2018). The rally was announced after a meeting with parents of Sapphire International School. “The parents have expressed anguish at an increase of monthly payment by about 10%. We heard their complaints. Such a complaint is however not an isolated issue. Most schools have increased their fee over permissible limits for the 2019-2020 session and we will take to the roads on April 21 to protest against this. The protest march on April 21 will also be supported by RWA groups,” said K Arunachalam, general secretary, ANSPA. Ravi Kumar, a parent at Sapphire International school, said, “We held the meeting on Sunday and will now lodge a complaint with the district fee regulation committee. We will join hands for the forthcoming parents’ protest.” ANSPA has previously raised fee-related complaints against seven Noida schools.

title: Damdami Taksal protest against Dera Sacha Sauda gathering
og_title: Damdami Taksal protest against Dera Sacha Sauda gathering
content: PATIALA: Tension escalated in Banur town of Patiala district after members of Damdami Taksal blocked Banur Landran road to prevent a congregation of Dera Sacha Sauda . Key Dera members had planned to hold the Nam Charcha as part of its inception-ceremony (Sathapna Diwas) but allegedly failed to take any permission from the administration. Expecting a huge gathering, the Dera management had planned to hold the congregation at an open agricultural land. Police from Mohali and Banur reached the spot and got the land vacated and issued prohibition orders to hold any congregation without any permission. Tension prevailed after a large number of Sikh community members led by BS Parwana headed towards the venue to confront the Dera followers. However, the district administration and the police immediately reached the spot to avert a clash between the two sides. The members of the Damdami Taksal appealed the district administration to not allow the congregation and later gave them a two-hour ultimatum to take action. However, at around 1pm, the Sikhs under the Taksal blocked the road near Banur barrier as no action against was taken against Dera. “The Dera local management was not allowed to hold the congregation or political rally as they did not have any permission in this regard. The Dera packed up at around 3pm. There was no tension as the protesters held a protest peacefully while within no time a swift action was taken following which the gathering of Dera followers was not allowed,” Mohali sub-registrar Rajpal Singh said, Sinder Paka, member of Dera’s state political wing said, “We had already held these gathering under ‘Nam Charcha’ in almost all the districts including Faridkot, Bathinda, Patiala, Muktsar, Ferozepur, Sangrur and Ludhiana. However, Mohali and Ropar are yet to be covered. We are only taking the opinion of the Dera followers as to which candidate or party they should support in the Lok Sabha elections.” "Everything remained peaceful. No case was registered against anyone. However, the matter was resolved amicably after a discussion was held with the Dera local management and they were told to vacate the private land," DSP Rajpura, Manpreet Singh said.

title: Amarinder protests Canada dropping references to Sikh extremism from terrorism report
og_title: Amarinder protests Canada dropping references to Sikh extremism from terrorism report
content: CHANDIGARH: Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh on Sunday protested the Canadian government's move to remove all references to Sikh extremism from its 2018 report on terrorism which had earlier listed it as one of the top five terrorist threats to the country. The 2018 report on terrorism , first released in December last year, drew the ire of the Sikh community at the time of its release as it was the first time it listed Sikh extremism as one of the top five extremist threats in Canada , the Toronto-based CBC news said. Singh protested the Trudeau administration's decision, saying it "succumbed to domestic political pressure". "The move is a threat to Indian and global security," he said. Amarinder said the "knee-jerk decision" by the ruling Canadian Liberal Party was aimed at protecting its political interests in an election year. It could have serious consequences for the Indo-Canadian relations in the long run, Singh said. "(Canadian Prime Minister Justin) Trudeau is playing with fire with his decision to assuage inflamed domestic passions through this ill-considered move," he claimed. The world cannot afford to fan extremism in any form, which is what the Trudeau government is effectively doing with such ill-thought moves, he added. He pointed out that he himself had given proof to the Canadian Prime Minister during his India visit last year, of his country's soil being used to spread the separatist Khalistani ideology against a friendly country. Trudeau had been informed of Khalistani activists being involved in financing terror activities in India from Canada, said the chief minister in a statement here Sunday. Singh had handed over to the Canadian Prime Minister a list of nine Canada-based operatives allegedly involved in promoting radicalism in Punjab, which has the highest number of Sikhs in India. The chief minister dubbed the "erasure of the various references to Khalistan and Khalistani organisations" from the latest threat report "as an unpardonable act in the eyes of the peace-loving global community." "It is obvious that Trudeau had played safe in view of the upcoming elections in Canada, giving in to pressure within his country. In the process, he has quite blatantly ignored the adverse impact this could have not only on Canada's relations with India but also on geopolitical stability," he added. The updated version of the '2018 Public Report on the Terrorism Threat to Canada' was released on Friday, Toronto-based CBC news quoted The Canadian Press news agency as saying. The language in the report was changed to remove any mention of religion, instead discussing the threat posed by "extremists who support violent means to establish an independent state within India", it reported.

title: Pregnant woman stages protest
og_title: Pregnant woman stages protest
content: VELLORE: Disappointed over alleged police inaction against the man who impregnated her and later refused to marry, a 21-year-old woman staged a sit-in in front of the man’s house near Ambur on Saturday. Police said the woman, a daily wager, stays with her elder sister’s family. Janakiraman, 26, a car driver, was in a relationship with her. The woman who found she was pregnant six months ago asked Janakiraman to marry her. Initially, he kept on postponing the marriage but later he refused to marry. The woman with help from a few local women lodged a police complaint on March 3. As there was no action against the man, she staged a sit-in in front of Janakiraman’s house on Saturday. On information, police came to the spot and pacified the woman. Police have launched a search for Janakiraman who is at large.tnn

title: Tripura high court cancels bail of five accused of attacking doctor, protests called off for now
og_title: Tripura high court cancels bail of five accused of attacking doctor, protests called off for now
content: AGARTALA: The agitating doctors in Tripura called off their ongoing protest on Saturday after the Tripura high court, in a midnight hearing, cancelled the bail order of five persons accused of assaulting a surgeon at Indira Gandhi Memorial (IGM) Hospital on Thursday. Since it was established in 2013, this was the first time that the Tripura high court convened at midnight to conduct a hearing. Hearing a petition moved by the state government at 9pm to challenge a lower court’s decision, Chief Justice Sanjoy Karol stayed the interim bail order till the next hearing on April 15. Health services across the state have been severely affected over the last couple of days, with private clinics, chambers, diagnostic centres and pathology laboratories remaining closed in protest against the attack on the doctor . Chief minister Biplab Deb had said on Friday said that the state would file a petition in the high court, seeking cancellation of the bail order passed by a judicial magistrate. On Wednesday evening, after a pregnant woman, Mampi Das (20), died in the labour room of the state referral IGM hospital, her friends and relatives, led by her husband Gabinda Das, had reportedly attacked the resident gynaecologist Dr Dipanakar Debnath, dragging him away from the hospital, severely assaulting him and leaving him by the roadside. Dr Debnath, who was found lying in a sewage drain in front of Agartala Municipal Corporation office, has been undergoing treatment at Agartala Government Medical College. He is reportedly in a stable condition now. Immediately after the attack on the doctor, police had arrested five accused and booked them under non-bailable sections, with charges of attempt to murder and kidnapping against them. But the local court had granted them bail, leading to widespread protests among doctors. The government then moved the high court, seeking cancellation of the bail order. Though the doctors’ bodies called off their protest on Saturday, they demanded action against all the accused involved in carrying out attacks on doctors and health workers in the state. At least 13 such incidents were reported from hospitals in Tripura in the last one year. Last week, Sabroom BJP Mandal president Arjun Debnath had reportedly barged into the Srinagar Primary health centre and thrown his shoes at Dr Dipal Mitra. The accused has not been arrested yet. The doctors’ bodies also demanded custodial trial for all the accused in these cases, improvement in working condition and better security for doctors, including installing CCTV cameras across all hospitals in the state. On Friday evening, health minister Sudip Roybarman had surrendered his personal security escort in protest against the attack. The Tripura government has ordered an inquiry into the incident.

title: Sudan military leader vows civilian govt after protests
og_title: Sudan military leader vows civilian govt after protests
content: KHARTOUM: The new head of Sudan’s military council said on Saturday a civilian government would be formed after consultations with the opposition and the transition period would last for a maximum of two years, as protesters kept up pressure for rapid change. In his first televised address, Lieutenant General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan Abdelrahman ordered the release of all prisoners jailed under emergency laws ordered by ousted President Omar al-Bashir . Bashir was overthrown on Thursday after weeks of mass protests brought on by rising food costs, high unemployment and increasing repression during his three decades in power. Protest organisers had earlier on Saturday urged people to keep marching to demand a civilian government after the defence minister and the intelligence chief stepped down. Salah Abdallah Mohamed Saleh, known as Salah Gosh , the former head of the National Intelligence and Security Service quit on Saturday. He was once the most influential person in the country after Bashir and protesters held him responsible for the killing of demonstrators demanding an end to military rule. Defence minister Awad Ibn Auf stepped down as head of the transitional military council on Friday after only a day in the post. Celebrations erupted on the streets overnight after Ibn Auf ’s resignation.

title: Jet employees protest at IGI, seek pending salaries
og_title: Jet employees protest at IGI, seek pending salaries
content: NEW DELHI: Employees of cash-strapped Jet Airways on Saturday protested outside terminal 3 of Indira Gandhi International (IGI) airport, seeking release of pending salaries. The airline which is flying just six-seven aircraft on Saturday, has asked its lenders to grant some interim funding. Several pilots, engineers, cabin crew members and security persons joined the silent protest in their uniforms. They carried banners that read “Save Jet Airways, Save our future” and “Hear our cry, Let 9W fly”. 9W is the code for Jet Airways flights, just like 6E is for IndiGo flights. On Friday, Jet Airways employees had participated in a silent march in Mumbai. On Monday, the lenders — lead by SBI — will again meet the management of Jet Airways, which will present a plan to use the interim funding, if granted, officials said.

title: Girl dies after snake bite, family protests
og_title: Girl dies after snake bite, family protests
content: KALYAN: A six-year-old girl died of a snake bite at Dombivli on Friday evening. The family on Saturday blamed the civic-run Shastri Nagar hospital for delay in treatment and protested against it. Swara Waghmare was residing with her parent at Mothagaon in Dombivli (West), where they had come a few months back. Her father Pramod operates an auto, while her mother is a housewife. Swara was playing outside her house when the snake bit her. Swara informed her mother, who rushed her to the hospital in Dombivli. The family claimed hospital staff gave her an injection but claimed she had to be admitted to the ICU. As they did not have staff, they told the family to go to a nearby private hospital. The family took Swara to Aptech hospital, where the doctor said it was too late. After the family conducted the last rites, they protested outside Shastri Nagar hospital.

title: NC protests ban on civilian traffic twice a week on Jammu-Srinagar highway
og_title: NC protests ban on civilian traffic twice a week on Jammu-Srinagar highway
content: JAMMU: National Conference activists Saturday protested in the highway township of Banihal against the ban on the movement of civilian traffic twice a week on the Jammu-Srinagar national highway. The protesters, led by National Conference district president, Ramban, Sajjad Shaheen, staged the protest to press for revocation of the "anti-people" and "authoritarian" order. The nearly 270-km highway, the only all-weather road linking Kashmir with the rest of the country, will remain closed for civilian traffic on Wednesday and Sunday from 4 am to 5 pm till May 31 to facilitate smooth movement of security convoys. "Such an unprecedented move is first in the history of Jammu and Kashmir . It has turned out as a nightmare for the commuters on the highway as also various towns, suburbs and rural pockets on the route. "The proponents of such an order have not applied their mind, which speaks volumes about their disconnect with the people, who have been pushed to the wall," Shaheen said addressing the protesters. The NC leader hoped that governor Satya Pal Malik would undertake immediate review of the situation and revoke the ban in the larger interest of the people especially those living along the highway.

title: Kerala: Days ahead of Lok Sabha poll, Sabarimala outfit holds 'namajapa' protest
og_title: Kerala: Days ahead of Lok Sabha poll, Sabarimala outfit holds 'namajapa' protest
content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With Lok Sabha polls just nine days away in Kerala , activists of an umbrella organisation of various Hindu outfits Saturday staged a dharna here to protest the alleged mass imposition of cases against them in connection with the Sabarimala agitation. 'Sabarimala Karma Samithi', which had spearheaded the agitation against the CPI(M)-led LDF government's decision to implement the Supreme Court September 28 verdict permitting women of all age groups into the shrine, alleged that their members had been implicated in various criminal cases "unlawfully". Braving the scorching heat, a number of activists, including women, squatted on the road in front of the Secretariat here, and held 'namajapa' protest by chanting Lord Ayyappa hymns near the god's picture. The outfit's protest, days before the April 23 Lok Sabha polls, rekindles the memories of the Sabarimala agitation, which had seen frenzied protests by devotees across the state and the alleged police action against them. The parliamentary election in Kerala will be held in a single phase on April 23. Addressing the gathering, Swami Chidanandapuri of the Kolathur Adavaitha Ashram here urged the Hindu community not to forget the "barbaric acts" of the police against the devotees during the Sabarimala protests. "The Karma Samithi will continue to raise the Sabarimala issue. It will not be a violation of the model code of conduct as the outfit is neither a political party nor a political movement," Chidanandapuri, who is also the chief patron of the Samithi, said. The seer said the left government had no moral right to continue in the office in the wake of the action taken against the Ayyappa devotees. Samithi leader K P Sasikala, who was arrested during the protests, said the outfit would extend support to those who had stood by them and the devotees during the stir. Hitting at the state police for allegedly registering "false cases" against the Samithi activists and devotees, former DGP T P Senkumar said the police should act in accordance with the Indian Penal Code and CrPC (Code of Criminal Procedure). "They should implement the rule of law and not the law of Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan . Don't try to scare anyone by registering false cases," Senkumar, national vice-president of Sabarimala Action Council, said. Sources in the ruling LDF said the party would petition the Election Commission against the dharna staged by the right-wing outfit. Kerala last year had for days witnessed a series of violent protests by various groups of devotees and Hindu outfits demanding that the sanctity of the temple rituals be protected. On September 28 last year, a five-judge Constitution bench had lifted the ban on the entry of women of menstrual age into the shrine.

title: 500 unpaid Jet staffers hold protest, want cops to book airline, bankers
og_title: 500 unpaid Jet staffers hold protest, want cops to book airline, bankers
content: MUMBAI: A union representing Jet Airways officers and staff sought police intervention on Friday to resolve issues arising over non-payment of salaries and employee grievances. The move came after more than 500 Jet Airways employees marched from the Mumbai airport to its office in Siroya Centre, Andheri, and held a demonstration that lasted for over four hours, to give voice to their plight. The struggling carrier has not paid its 17,000-odd employees salaries for March. Referring to the non-payment of salaries, Kiran Pawaskar, president, All India Jet Airways' Officers and Staff Association, sent a letter to Sahar police asking the senior inspector “to register offences under cheating, criminal breach of trust, misappropriation and other offences against the chairman (Jet Airways, the CEO and the representatives of the State Bank of India (bankers)”. The law provides for criminal action against employers and given the fact that Jet Airways has been taken over by bankers, the provisions of law would apply to them, he said. The letter sent by the 19-year old Jet union stated that this violation, apart from being legal violation under the labour law, is also a serious offence of breach of trust as the company was handed over last month by the former chairman Naresh Goyal to the State Bank of India under the Resolution Plan. Earlier in the afternoon, Pawaskar met some officials from the Jet management to discuss the salary non-payment issue. “The salaries cannot be paid till the lenders and bankers release the amount needed to pay the employees. The management gave us no deadline or word on when the payments would be made,” said a Jet official.

title: TB hospital staffers protest against biometric ‘failure’
og_title: TB hospital staffers protest against biometric ‘failure’
content: MUMBAI: Class IV workers from the civic-run TB Hospital in Sewri held a protest on Friday to highlight their loss of pay due to the implementation of the biometric attendance system. “Almost 400 workers got nil salary in March and lost all their leaves due to the failure of the system,” said Pradeep Narkar of Municipal Mazdoor Union . The system only recognizes a Sunday off, but as workers have weekly offs on different days, they were marked as absent. He added that their protest didn’t affect patient care. In the evening, the hospital agreed to appoint a clerk to oversee the biometric system.

title: Chandrababu Naidu protest threat to EC over ‘unfair AP polls’
og_title: Chandrababu Naidu protest threat to EC over ‘unfair AP polls’
content: AMRAVATI: Chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu on Friday accused the Election Commission of making a “mockery of democracy” on the issue of “mishandling of elections” in the state. He said he would go to New Delhi on Saturday to protest in front of the poll panel’s office if it didn’t come out with a “convincing answer”. “EC owes an explanation to people of Andhra on unfair and improper conduct of elections. We are going to Delhi on Saturday,” he said. Naidu said he was confident of winning the elections despite “large-scale violence, disturbance and malfunctioning of EVMs”. He alleged EC had failed to ensure peaceful polling as it transferred senior officials at YSR Congress’ behest. “Jagan Reddy and BJP thanked the EC despite people facing so much trouble. EVMs might have been tampered in the guise of repairs. It exposed the unholy alliance,” said Naidu. Expressing displeasure at EC’s response to the situation, he said, “The CEO himself could not cast his vote in the first instance. Isn’t it a shame for EC?” He said TDP would file a review petition in the Supreme Court on counting VVPATs.

title: Bijnor village protest over delay in bridge construction, vote after SDM’s assurance
og_title: Bijnor village protest over delay in bridge construction, vote after SDM’s assurance
content: MUZAFFARNAGAR: Residents of Yogendra Nagar village in Muzaffarnagar (under Bijnor Lok Sabha constituency) sat on the protest to boycott polls outside a polling booth here over the delay in construction of a bridge over a river here on Thursday. It took two hours for the administration to convince the residents who resolved to boycott polls to finally cast their vote . The villagers said that they have to face problems whenever they want to go somewhere as the only route has to be over the river. According to locals, the came into existence in 1976 and now has nearly 1,000 voters. Lok Pal, a villager, said, “We have been demanding a bridge over Sonali river since four decades but nothing has been done yet. Recently, 12 people, including children drowned in the river. In the absence of a bridge, we have to walk 8 km extra every day to reach our farmlands. Politicians come here only to ask for votes but they have done nothing for us.” Meanwhile, sub-divisional magistrate of Jansath Vijay Kumar said, “When I got to know of their protest, I reached the village and showed them sanctioned documents of bridge construction. Following which, they cast their votes.”

title: Fee-hike protest turns ugly, school rejects claim it switched off ACs
og_title: Fee-hike protest turns ugly, school rejects claim it switched off ACs
content: NEW DELHI: A protest against a fee hike at a south Delhi private school on Thursday degenerated into a tussle between the parents and teachers, with the latter shouting, “Go back parents”. The parents of students studying in KR Mangalam World School in Greater Kailash II said the fee was increased without consulting them and demanded a rollback. Delhi high court has stayed till April 30 all fee hikes in schools built on land provided by Delhi Development Authority (DDA) or other government agencies. KR Mangalam administrators, however, argued that the school wasn’t built on subsidised government land and the court stay did not “pertain” to the school. In an email, principal Sangeeta Arora said, “Our school has come up on private land. The parents need to appreciate that school fee is the only source of school income. The increasing cost of administration particularly on account of implementation of 7th Central Pay Commission or wage incremental factors like dearness allowance (twice a year), annual increment payable to staff, higher provision for gratuity on account of increase in salary and length of service do necessitate corresponding increase in fees.” A parent retorted, “How can they use the fact about the school being built on private land as a reason not to follow rules? They did not take the consent of the parents before increasing the fee. And they keep on increasing the fees very year. There is no transparency in how they run the institution.” The earlier fees of Rs 36,100 per quarter have gone up to Rs 46,400, including arrears. The parents gathered at the school around 8am and the demonstration ended around 1pm. The school put up resistance, even calling in the police. One parent alleged, “When we reached the reception area, the school administration summoned the teachers and stood them in our way. They then began shouting, ‘Go back parents’.” The school was also accused of switching off the air conditioners in the classrooms during the protests, leaving the children sweltering. The management later clarified, “The allegation of ACs and fans being purposely switched off is baseless. In fact, an MCB developed a problem, which was resolved in 10-15 minutes.” The parents held a meeting till late in the evening and decided to take up the matter with every possible authority. Earlier, on April 10, the parents had submitted a representation to the management pointing out that the institution did not issue the fee bill in the prescribed format and charging the school with not running on “fair administrative practices”.

title: Dozen villages boycott polls in protest
og_title: Dozen villages boycott polls in protest
content: Hyderabad: About a dozen villages boycotted the polls in protest against government apathy in resolving their problems. People of Anantagiri Thanda in Vikarabad constituency boycotted polling on the grounds that district administration failed to address their drinking water issue. They protested with empty vessels. Similarly, Avusupally voters did not take part in polling in protest against merger of their village into Medak. The entire villge of Bhandhampally of Peddapalle district also refused to vote as they were not getting MGNREGS benefits. In KTR’s Sircilla Rajanna district, Ayyoripally villagers refused to vote over merger into Vemulawada municipality.

title: Autowallahs, families accuse Gadkari of giving free run to app-based taxis
og_title: Autowallahs, families accuse Gadkari of giving free run to app-based taxis
content: NAGPUR: Frustrated with the free run to app-based cab services like Ola and Uber , over 20,000 auto owners and their families, totalling over a lakh, claim to have voted against the BJP. The frustration was evident during discussions with autorickshaw owners in slums like Rajendra Nagar, Hasanbagh, Pardi, Kalamna and Minimata Nagar. “The government taxes us, but lets app-based taxis operate illegally at our expense,” said Mohammed Shahid of Hasanbagh. Vilas Bhalekar, president of Tiger Autorickshaw Union, the biggest union of autorickshaw owners, confirmed this, “On March 26, we had openly declared support to Congress nominee Nana Patole at a meeting of all members.” “Auto owners were disillusioned with the BJP government for taxing us in last 5 years. In 2014, vehicle insurance was increased from Rs3,600 to Rs7,500, permit fee from Rs200 to Rs10,700, RTO passing fee from Rs200 to Rs600, and hypothecation fee from Rs100 to Rs1,500. BJP is only promoting capitalism in all sectors,” said Bhalekar. Bhalekar claimed all their votes went to the Congress across the city. Even former corporator and BJP leader Ibrahim Chudiwale, who set up party booths, admitted there was resentment against the party among auto owners. This was reflected during polling, as autorickshaw owners were seen ferrying relatives and families to voting booths in slum areas. “I swear I voted against the BJP. Ola and Uber are eating into our livelihood. For example, if an autorickshaw from Rajendra Nagar to railway station charges Rs150, cabs ferry you for Rs70-100,” said Sheikh Ayyaz, an auto owner.

title: Parents protest fee hike in south Delhi school, allege electricity cut-off due to non-payment
og_title: Parents protest fee hike in south Delhi school, allege electricity cut-off due to non-payment
content: NEW DELHI: Parents of children of a private school in south Delhi on Thursday staged a protest alleging that school authorities had cut-off electricity supply in classrooms after they refused to pay the increased fees. The 12 per cent fee hike, which the parents alleged was implemented by K R Manglam School in Greater Kailash , despite the high court's order not allowing the same. However, school principal Sangeeta Arora said the high court order on fee hike is not applicable to their school as it is built on a private land and not on Delhi Development Authority (DDA) land. "It is informed that the HC order referred in your mail pertains to schools that have come up on land allotted by DDA or other governmental agencies. Our school has come up on private land. The allegation of the school increasing the fees despite HC order is therefore not tenable," she said. The electricity blackout was not a deliberate attempt, but due to power failure, she said. Gautam Sharma, whose son studies in class 5, said, "They have increased fee by 12 per cent despite the high court's order and they are forcing parents to pay the hiked fees. Due to non-payment of hiked fee, they have turned off AC and fans of the school and students are studying in such a hot temperature." Another parent Preeti Kapoor, said, "Height of shamelessness and irresponsibility has been seen in the K R Manglam School. Teachers left small kids alone and unsafe in the class against the protests, shocking to see that this can happen even in the world class school." "Fee hike in private schools is torturing both parents and children. When parents refused to pay increased fees, the school management switched off lights and AC inside classrooms to disturb the kids," Saranpreet Singh. Several parents also took to Twitter to post videos of protest outside the school and chaos inside classrooms. The school principal said the parents need to appreciate that school fees is the only source of income. The increasing cost of administration, particularly on account of implementation of seventh CPC or wage incremental factors like DA (twice a year), annual increment payable to staff, higher provision for gratuity on account of increase in salary and length of service do necessitate corresponding increase in fees.

title: Police see hand of Lala gang in Mandsaur murder
og_title: Police see hand of Lala gang in Mandsaur murder
content: INDORE: Mandsaur police detained seven people including history-sheeters Bhola Tiwari and Kannu Lala of Lala gang in connection with Anil Soni murder case on Thursday. Diamond jeweler Anil Soni was shot dead by unidentified persons when he was moving out of his residence in Choudhary Colony on Wednesday night. The attackers pumped over four bullets into Soni and fled the spot. SP Vivek Agarwal said that two teams have been formed to investigate the case - one is involved in detaining suspects and the second team is collecting technical evidence, CCTV footage and recording statements of locals and family members. “Seven people have been detained in the case. We are working on it and more arrests will be made soon,” said SP Agarwal. Mandsaur kotwali police station in charge KL Dangi said that they were mapping the route taken by the accused to flee Mandsaur. Teams were sent to Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh. Family of the diamond jeweller staged protest against police inaction by keeping the body at Gandhi square. They demanded immediate arrest of the accused while threatening a ‘bandh’ if the accused are not arrested within 24 hours. “Even after we received numerous threats from Lala gang, my brother said that we will wait for police action in the case. They had asked for Rs 1 crore from us and had also said that they have ties with the police,” said Ashish Soni, Anil’s brother. Anil’s family said he had survived attacks in the past and had opted for police security. But, due to imposition of model code of conduct, his security was revoked. They accused police of failing to ensure his security. Two years ago in January 2017, brother of the deceased Ajay had sustained injuries in his back after they were attacked while returning from their shop in Neemuch .

title: This picture of the Sudanese protests could be the image of the revolution
og_title: This picture of the Sudanese protests could be the image of the revolution
content: KHARTOUM: A Sudanese woman propelled to internet fame earlier this week after leading powerful protest chants in the capital told on Wednesday that women are key to the uprising against Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir's iron-fisted rule. "Sudanese women have always participated in revolutions in this country," Alaa Salah said after footage went viral of her standing on a car, singing and conducting crowds outside the army headquarters in Khartoum. "If you see Sudan 's history, all our queens have led the state. It's part of our heritage." In the clips and photos, the elegant Salah stands atop a car wearing a long white headscarf and skirt as she sings and works the crowd, her golden full-moon earrings reflecting light from the fading sunset and a sea of camera phones surrounding her. Pic courtesy Twitter "I'm very proud to take part in this revolution and I hope our revolution will achieve its goal," added the engineering and architecture student at Sudan International University. Dubbed online as "Kandaka" or Nubian queen, she has become a symbol of the protests which she says have traditionally had a female backbone in Sudan. Her new-found fame pushed her to set up her own Twitter account in which she thanked everyone "from the bottom of my heart. The struggle for a democratic and prosperous Sudan continues". In another tweet Wednesday she says she "wanted to get on the car and speak to the people... speak against racism and tribalism in all its forms, which affects everyone across all walks of life. "I wanted to speak on behalf of the youth. I wanted to come out and say that Sudan is for all." Supporters celebrated the young protest leader across social media networks, calling her a "hero" and an "icon". "This image from Sudan will be in the history books," wrote one user. Dubbed online as 'Kandaka', or Nubian queen, Alaa Salah has become a symbol of the protests which she says have traditionally had a female backbone in Sudan But late on Wednesday she tweeted that she had been receiving "death threats" after her footage went viral. "I will not bow down. My voice can not be suppressed," Salah wrote. Demonstrators have been camped outside the military complex for days asking the army to back them in demands that Bashir step down. I've been receiving death threats after my picture & video went viral. I will not bow down. My voice can not be sup… https://t.co/XSbCpEUmwZ — Alaa Salah (@iAlaaSalah) 1554926927000 Women have made up a large part of the demonstrators that since Saturday have thronged outside the sprawling army complex. Braving regular volleys of tear gas, the crowds have been the biggest yet to rally against Bashir's rule since unrest broke out in late December. "In such movements, women are widely participating not only for their rights but for the rights of the entire community... there's no difference between women's rights and community rights," Salah told AFP. "Women of Sudan always encourage their youths to fight. This is part of the history of Kandaka," she added. Salah said she has taken part in the protests since they first erupted on December 19 in response to a government decision to triple the price of bread. The unrest quickly morphed into a nationwide campaign against Bashir's rule with rallies held across cities, towns and villages. The longtime leader has remained defiant and imposed a slew of tough measures including a state of emergency across the country. Officials say 49 people have died in protest-related violence so far.

title: Sudden rail roko protest at Navsari derails traffic for 4 hours
og_title: Sudden rail roko protest at Navsari derails traffic for 4 hours
content: SURAT: A flash rail roko agitation by daily commuters at the tracks on Navsari railway station resulted in 18 trains on both up and down lines of Mumbai-Ahmedabad route running late on Wednesday morning. The regular passengers were demanding old coaches to be fitted to train no 12929 Valsad -Dahod Intercity Express so as to accommodates more passengers. After four hours of melee, 10 trains coming from Mumbai including Shatabdi Express, Delux Train to Delhi, Gujarat Express among others, had to be stopped at different stations leading to almost four hours’ delay. Eight Mumbai-bound trains also ran 3-4 hours late. However, after the assurance by railway authorities to set things right and meet all the demands made by the commuters within a week’s time, the agitation was called off and normalcy was finally restored . According to a rail official at Navsari station the commuters stopped the Valsad-Dahod intercity which arrived at the station at 7.50 am and didn’t let it leave. The miffed passengers were demanding bigger coaches as the new ones that had been fitted by the railways on the intercity were unable to accommodate the large number of daily commuters. A traveller from Navsari who commutes to Surat daily in the train said, “ We used to have three tier coaches in the train regularly that can accommodate large number of people even on the parcel seat and in the coaches which had a capacity of 102 people. Nearly 300-400 passengers travel to work daily. However, for the past 15 days they have replaced those coaches with the new Rajdhani-type coaches that doesn’t have space for parcel seat. Therefore, not more than 105 people can travel in the coach,” he alleged. “Despite our repeated pleas, nobody was paying heed to our plight and so we were left with little option but to sit on a flash agitation. Large number of women too joined our protest .” Station director at Surat station, SN Yadav, had to rush to Navsari to pacify the crowd and assure them of adding the old type coaches which could accommodate more people. Later Yadav told TOI, “We will take care of the demands in a week’s time. We plan to replace the new coaches with similar type of old coaches so that more people can travel in the train. Trains restarted at 12.10 pm and normalcy was restored. However, the agitation resulted in the cancellation of the Surat-Bharuch memu shuttle for the day.”

title: Jeweller shot dead in front of his house in Mandsaur
og_title: Jeweller shot dead in front of his house in Mandsaur
content: INDORE: A well-known jeweller of Mandsaur was shot dead at point blank range in front of his house late on Wednesday. The attackers pumped over five bullets into Anil Soni, owner of Diamond Jewellers, when he was moving out of his residence in Choudhary Colony of Mandsaur town, police said. As Anil fell on ground, people rushed to his rescue, but the attackers fled the spot. He was immediately taken to district hospital where he was declared dead. Doctors said that he had sustained bullet injuries on his chest and back. Anil’s family members said he had survived attacks in the past and had opted for police security. But, due to imposition of model code of conduct, his security was revoked. They accused police of failing to ensure his security. They alleged that soon after the attack, they had approached the police, but no help was received. Soon after the news spread, people thronged district hospital, where police were deployed in strength to prevent any flare-up. Kotwali police have started gathering initial clues about the attackers. However, they were not sure about their numbers. Four empty cartridges were found from the spot indicating that country-made pistols were used by the attackers. “We are looking into the case and investigation is on. CCTV footage of nearby shops are being checked to trace out the attackers,” Mandsaur Kotwali police station in charge KL Dangi said. Anil was in news in the past for several customer schemes that were questioned over legality. Couple of years ago, CCTV footage of two persons firing at his shop had gone viral.

title: App-cab protest fizzles out as riders’ backlash forces drivers to keep ACs on
og_title: App-cab protest fizzles out as riders’ backlash forces drivers to keep ACs on
content: KOLKATA: The app cab drivers’ no-AC protest lost steam on Wednesday with only a handful of them sticking to the plan. On April 8, the West Bengal Online Cab Operators Guild had decided to keep ACs in app-cabs switched off for the entire day. “Perhaps, they did not take into account the commuters’ backlash,” said an app cab driver. At various parts of the city, cabbies not only had tiff with commuters, they were forced to turn the ACs on. A few stubborn cabbies, who refused to budge, had a piece of commuters’ mind and worst possible rating, which is a very good excuse for aggregators to block cabbies in the system. A majority of driver-partners refused to toe the diktat of the guild as switching off ACs during the peak hours would be suicidal. “Peak hours are also surge hours. If we charge higher fare and in return switch off the AC , commuters would not spare us and poor ratings would ruin my reputation, which I have built over last five years,” said Shankar Pal, an app-cab driver. This is why on the second day, the guild was forced to confine the agitation to non-peak hours —1pm to 5pm. “Any agitation needs solid moral and legal footings to sustain itself. The problem is such agitations are misdirected and legally untenable. App-cabbies cannot do anything that violates the agreement they have with the aggregators. Secondly, the dynamic pricing is the hall-mark of these app-cab services, which follows market economy. If the supply exceeds demand, fare will be less, if demand exceeds supply, fare is high,” said Arindam Ghosh, a transport economist working on the aggregators’ regime in transportation. In fact, in last couple of days, the aggregators acted promptly against the errant cabbies (who switched off cab AC while carrying passengers), leaving a lot of cabbies out of job. But commuters outrage over “unreasonable behaviour of cabbies” and quarrels that almost led to a scuffle made the guild leaders retreat. In fact, Madan Mitra , a seasoned politician, who is also the president of the Guild, was quick to understand how the agitation was fizzling out before it peaked. On Wednesday, he asked the agitators to soften their stand. As a face-saver, he asked them to confine the agitation to one hour in the afternoon. The agitators were also under pressure as the transport department was sending signals against such agitation.

title: PWD contractors protest over non-payment of dues
og_title: PWD contractors protest over non-payment of dues
content: JAIPUR: Public works department contractors launched a protest in the city for non-payment of dues for the works they had done in the past few months. The agitating PWD contractors claimed that they have not received dues for the works that have already been done in the past six months. “More than 7,000 PWD contractors have not received payments. The works have already been done but payments have not been made. If is happening for the past six months. We have not left with other option except to protest,” said Kamlesh Sharma, spokesperson, All Rajasthan Contractor Association. The agitating contractors claimed that they have constructed roads and completed maintenance work of government buildings and other such works. “Initially, we thought that the government will pay and payment could be delayed due to certain reason but now the situation is turning worse,” he said, adding that there is almost Rs 3,000 crore which has not been paid to the contractors. Till late in the evening they were sitting on dharna. The police have rushed to the spot to maintain the law and order

title: Chandrababu Naidu protests at EC office over transfers
og_title: Chandrababu Naidu protests at EC office over transfers
content: VIJAYAWADA: Chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu on Wednesday staged a dharna outside the Election Commissioner’s office protesting the “tyrannical and undemocratic attitude” of the Election Commission of India (ECI) towards TDP. Earlier, Naidu called on chief electoral officer Gopal Krishna Dwivedi and submitted a memorandum protesting the transfer of the chief secretary, Director-General of Police, three SPs and five police inspectors. Naidu’s protest follows the transfer of Prakasam district SP Koya Praveen and inspectors of Mangalagiri and Tadepalli. Naidu said this was the first time that a chief minister met a chief electoral officer to lodge a complaint against the EC’s partisan attitude. The TDP leadership also submitted a complaint to the Chief Election Commissioner in New Delhi on Wednesday. He urged the EC to make a level playing field for all contesting political parties. This is the second time that Naidu has protested against the EC in the last one week. Naidu said the EC transferred Srikakulam district collector a day after he joined. He is the first civil servant from Scheduled Tribe caste. “Transferring a district collector without reason so soon, not only affects the officer’s morale, but also causes agony to his family,” Naidu said. Naidu added that the chief secretary has an impeccable track record throughout his career. “The new incumbent has been posted without even consulting the state government. It is evident that ECI is acting on behalf of YSRC under the guidance of BJP,” he alleged. Naidu alleged that YSRC resorted to cybercrime to delete seven lakh TDP voters. “It is strange that whenever YSRC complains, the EC promptly takes action. If this continues, the opposition will make allegations against all honest officers who are helping in conducting transparent and fair elections,” he said.

title: Gujjar quota agitation leader Kirori Singh Bainsla joins BJP
og_title: Gujjar quota agitation leader Kirori Singh Bainsla joins BJP
content: NEW DELHI: Gujjar quota agitation leader Kirori Singh Bainsla on Wednesday joined the BJP at the party's headquarters in Delhi. Bainsla's son Vijay Bainsla also joined the party in the presence of BJP's Rajasthan-in-charge Prakash Javadekar . "I have seen rarest of rare qualities in Prime Minister Narendra Modi and that's why I am joining the BJP," Kirori Singh Bainsla said, adding the PM interacts with common people and he is inspired by Modi's working style. Bainsla said that he has been close to chief ministers of both parties - the BJP and the Congress - and had seen their ideologies. "After seeing two parties closely, I am joining the BJP," he said. Javadekar said Bainsla had also met party president Amit Shah in the morning.He said that with each passing day, the BJP is emerging stronger in Rajasthan and win all 25 Lok Sabha seats.

title: AP CM Chandrababu Naidu stages protest outside CEO's office, says EC actions 'tyrannical, undemocratic'
og_title: AP CM Chandrababu Naidu stages protest outside CEO's office, says EC actions 'tyrannical, undemocratic'
content: AMARAVATI: Andhra Pradesh chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu staged a sit-in protest outside the Chief Electoral Officer's (CEO) block at the Secretariat here on Wednesday, protesting the "tyrannical, undemocratic and arbitrary actions" of the Election Commission (EC) with regard to transfer of several officials. Earlier, Naidu met CEO Gopal Krishna Dwivedi and submitted a memorandum to him, accusing the EC of acting "on behalf of the YSR Congress under the guidance of the BJP". The Telugu Desam Party (TDP) chief also wrote to the chief election commissioner on the issue. He denounced the "autocratic and partisan attitude" of the EC in handling election-related matters pertaining to the state. "It is surprising that the EC is taking partisan and hasty steps to harass and intimidate government officials with a view to trigger panic in their minds for carrying out legitimate responsibilities," Naidu alleged, referring to the transfer of the state chief secretary, director general (DG) intelligence and three district superintendents of police (SPs). He also objected to the appointment of retired IPS officer K K Sharma as a special police observer for the Lok Sabha election in the state, alleging that he was a "prejudiced person with an RSS background". "It is strange and surprising that whenever the opposition YSR Congress party made a complaint, the EC not only promptly responded, but also took action without verifying the facts and without giving an opportunity to the officers against whom the complaint was made," Naidu said in the memorandum. "The commission should not fall prey to the baseless allegations of such a political party, the leader of which himself is involved in 31 criminal cases. The complaints filed by the TDP have not so far been attended to by the commission. "This deliberate inaction on the part of the EC on the complaints filed by the TDP and prompt action on the complaints filed by the YSRC only strengthens the suspicion that the commission has been toeing the line of the Union government led by the BJP and also assisting the political parties which are in connivance with it," he alleged. Further, the chief minister noted that ever since the polls were announced and the Model Code of Conduct came into force, the Income Tax authorities had only been targeting the TDP candidates, workers and sympathisers. "This is, thus, creating an atmosphere of fear and terror and not only violating the Model Code of Conduct, but also disturbing the level-playing field," he said in the memorandum. None of the candidates belonging to other political parties had been targeted, projecting a message that the TDP candidates and sympathisers alone were the culprits, Naidu added. "This is encouraging the other parties in the state to make false complaints against the TDP," he lamented. "Therefore, I strongly protest against such tyrannical and undemocratic attitude of the EC and I hope that it conducts its business by giving a level-playing field to all the contesting political parties in the state, upholds the democratic values and respects the Constitution of India," the TDP chief added

title: Second time in seven days, Naidu stages protest against poll body
og_title: Second time in seven days, Naidu stages protest against poll body
content: Naidu said this was the first time that a chief minister had met a chief electoral officer to lodge a complaint against the EC’s alleged partisan attitude. The TDP leadership also submitted a complaint to the Chief Election Commissioner in New Delhi on Wednesday. He urged the EC to give a level playing field to all the contesting political parties in the state and uphold the democratic values and respect the Constitution of India. Naidu decried the “autocratic and partisan attitude” of the Election Commission . This is the second time that Naidu has staged protest against the EC in the last one week. Naidu said the EC transferred Srikakulam district collector only a day after he joined the assignment. He is the first civil servant from a backward Scheduled Tribe of Andhra Pradesh, i.e., Erukala. Transferring a district collector without assigning any reason in less than he took over charge as district collector, not only adversely affects the officer’s morale but also causes deep agony to the family of the concerned officer, Naidu said. Referring to the transfer of chief secretary and police officials, Naidu said the chief secretary has an impeccable track record throughout his career. “The new incumbent has been posted without even consulting the state government. It is clearly evident that ECI is acting on behalf of YSRC under the guidance of BJP ,” he alleged. He alleged that YSRC resorted to cybercrime of sending pseudonymous complaints, electronically, through Form-7 for the purpose of deleting almost seven lakhs votes of TDP sympathisers. “It is strange and surprising that whenever YSRC made a complaint, the EC not only promptly responded but also took action without verifying the facts and without giving opportunity to the officers against whom the complaint was made. If this trend of culprits to commit crimes and counter attack police continues, the opposition will make absurd allegations against all straight forward and honest officers who come in their way of trying to conspire, connive and disturb transparent, and fair elections,” he said.

title: Locals plant paddy saplings on slushy road as sign of protest
og_title: Locals plant paddy saplings on slushy road as sign of protest
content: RUDRAPUR : The residents of Transit Camp colony and Congress workers in Udham Singh Nagar district headquarters Rudrapur chose a unique method of exposing the failure of authorities to repair a road in the area. On Tuesday, locals planted paddy saplings as a mark of protest on the Transit Camp link road from Kichha bypass to highlight its poor condition. The unprecedented protest did not just end there the residents of the area have taken it to the social media by uploading photographs and videos on internet. The local residents, led by former Congress minister, Tilak Raj Behar, planted the saplings on the slushy road. Behar condemned the alleged indifferent attitude of district administration and the local BJP legislator Rajkumar Thukral in repairing the road. He said that MLA Thukral has publicly said that he has written to the Chief Minister 22 times to get this road constructed all over again. "If an MLA can not get one km stretch of a road built by his own ruling party, he should resign. This road caters to more than fifty thousand commuters everyday but the long standing problem has not been addressed by the concerned leaders and authorities for more than two years", added Behar. “We have been giving memorandums to district administration for the last two years to repair the road,” said Monu Nishd, corporator of the area. However, according to him, the authorities concerned have failed to develop the road and the pathetic condition of the road has made travelling a nightmare. “This is a silent protest to seek answers from the administration and the local legislator. If we had blocked the road instead, it would have only added to the problems of public,” Parimal Roy a resident said. Residents said the rainwater gets accumulated on the one km stretch of the dilapidated road making it impossible to walk. “Because of the poor road condition, its impossible to walk on the road let alone be driving cars or bikes,” said Shankar Goldar, a resident of Raja colony located on the this stretch. Some angry locals said they are going to press NOTA in the coming elections due to lackadaisical approach of all political parties.

title: Family stages protest after woman dies post delivery
og_title: Family stages protest after woman dies post delivery
content: TIRUVANNAMALAI: Relatives of a 33-year-old woman, who died after delivering a boy, staged a protest near a hospital in Tiruvannamalai on Tuesday. Ealumalai, a relative of the deceased woman, said Sivakumar, 39, a daily wager married Kavitha, 12 years back and they were living with their two daughters aged 11 and seven at Chellangkuppam village near Tiruvannamalai. Kavitha, who became pregnant, was undergoing treatment at JIPMER in Puducherry for the past 10 months. Doctors, who found Kavitha to be anaemic, recommended blood transfusion before her due date on April 18. Meanwhile, Sivakumar, who suffered a hip fracture in an accident while digging a farm well, was undergoing treatment at a government hospital in Chennai for more than a month. Against this backdrop, his relatives and family members on Monday took Kavitha to a private hospital in Tiruvannamalai town for the blood transfusion. The founder of the hospital, after diagnosis, said the foetus was in a critical condition and urged Kavitha’s relatives to admit her immediately for an operation to deliver the baby. Kavitha also underwent a family planning operation the same day. Subsequently, the woman, who started bleeding profusely, was sent to Tiruvannamalai Government Medical College and Hospital in an auto-rickshaw without any medical support by doctors at the private hospital. However, doctors at Tiruvannamalai GH declared Kavitha brought dead. Following this, more than 50 relatives of Kavitha undertook a protest near the facility condemning the medical negligence and sought action against the doctors and hospital staff. On information by the hospital administration, Tiruvannamalai town police and local politicians, who came to the spot, pacified them assuring help to them to get compensation from the hospital after which they withdrew the protest. With police claiming that the case was still under investigation, the doctors at the private hospital denied allegations of medical negligence. Speaking to TOI, S Balaraman, vice president of Tiruvannamalai district Tamil Nadu Vivasayigal Sangam said such an incident was not new in the hospital. At least five such alleged medical negligence deaths had been reported at the private hospital over the past one year, he said. However, the hospital administration managed to cover up the issue with the help of police and politicians, he charged. “Our association plans to take up the issue,” he added.

title: A day before polls, many without EPIC and voter slip, allege BLOs unavailable
og_title: A day before polls, many without EPIC and voter slip, allege BLOs unavailable
content: Vijayawada: Hundreds of angry voters were seen queuing up at various polling stations and Anganwadi schools across the city on Wednesday after many of them failed to get either their voter slip or voter identity card. A majority of voters were seen searching for their booth-level officers to get their elector’s photo identity cards. Owing to the the flagship program of the Election Commission of India’s Systematic Voters’ Education and Electoral Participation program, better known as SVEEP, voter enrolment saw a noticeable rise in the city this year.
