However people alleged that a majority of the BLOs in the city has failed to distribute the voter slips. “I am a first-time voter and I have been waiting for the last one week to get my voter slip and EPIC . I tried to contact the BLO but they were unavailable. Officials asked me to take the slip on the polling day at the polling booth,” said M Mahesh Kumar, a BTech student from Patamata. People further claimed that the local-level poll officials are unreachable and their mobile phones are switched off. “There are five voters in my family and the polling staff gave us only two voter slips. The phone number of the BLO provided at the National Voter Service Portal is not working and we went to the polling booth and Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) office twice today,” complained K V S Rama Sharma, a private teacher from Satyanarayanapuram. When TOI approached the VMC authorities, they said that they have been distributing the voter slips across the city and have arranged boards displaying contact details of BLOs at the polling booths. They further said that the distribution of voter slips will continue at the polling stations. The chief electoral officer Gopala Krishna Dwivedi had said that voter slips can be downloaded from the CEC website and in the absence of a voter ID card, people can produce one of the 11 documents identified by the CEC to avail their votes and a photo voter slip is not mandatory to cast their vote.

title: Medical students protest against quotas in PG courses
og_title: Medical students protest against quotas in PG courses
content: Around 350 students from city medical colleges and their parents gathered at Sion hospital on Tuesday afternoon for a peaceful protest against reservations in postgraduate courses, which have reduced general category seats. The quotas for the Maratha community and economically weaker section have added to their anxiety. Saurab Bhopatrao (21), a third-year MBBS student from Sion hospital, said: “What is happening is not fair to us.” His classmate Simran Dilwari (22) concurred: “An all-India rank of 4,000 is not getting a clinical branch, but an all India rank of 36000 is getting admission in KEM orthopaedic branch, which is clearly unfair.” Sudha Shenoy, a parent, said: “Doctors deal with human life and therefore selection of students should be on merit.”

title: Docs stand with students in agitation against reservation
og_title: Docs stand with students in agitation against reservation
content: Nagpur: Hundreds of specialist doctors and medical professionals from the city came out on road in front of Dhantoli garden on Tuesday afternoon and raised anti-reservation slogans. These doctors, most of them well-known private practitioners and owners of private hospitals in the city, were expressing their support to MBBS graduate aspirants of general (open) category. After implementation of quota for socially and educationally backward classes (SEBC — popularly known as Maratha reservation) and economically weaker sections (EWS) in PG seats, students of open category are left with a very few seats in government and private PG medical colleges. Students have been protesting the “faulty implementation” of these two quotas in PG seats from April 2. On Tuesday, professionals also came to their support and demanded that PG admissions should be done on merit basis. “This type of implementation of quota is injustice with meritorious students of open category. These MBBS students have worked hard and secured good ranks in PG-NEET. Due to less number of seats, many meritorious students will be deprived of the PG admissions. This will also hit the quality of health care in future,” said ophthalmologist Dr Anil Laddhad. Doctors attached to Indian Medical Association (IMA) and its bodies brought placards that had ‘Save Merit, Save India’, ‘Merit deprived, nation destroyed’ among other messages. Other students also joined them later in the protest and they decided to escalate it further in the state. “On April 14, there will be a candle march in Mumbai. On birth anniversary of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar, medical students will be raising the issue of wrong implementation of reservation. In Nagpur too, we are planning to hold such an event,” said Dr Laddhad. Doctors had earlier planned a silent march from Lokmat Square. But police refused them the permission of holding the march. “Dhantoli cops told us to skip the foot march. They permitted us a small public meeting near Dhantoli garden. It was totally non-political event,” said Dr Rajendra Chandak of IMA. The doctors claimed that the issue is not political. “We are not against reservation but no student of any category should face injustice,” he said. The doctors who joined the agitation said that the MBBS degree in itself is a great equalizer and it is unfair to pit one doctor against another on the basis of ‘social and educational backwardness’. They demanded that reservation at PG level should be implemented in a different manner.

title: South Delhi school puts fee hike on hold after protests by parents
og_title: South Delhi school puts fee hike on hold after protests by parents
content: NEW DELHI: St George’s School announced on Tuesday that the management has decided to put the fee revision on hold till further orders. Parents had been protesting about the increase in the fee, despite the school being built on government land. Delhi high court has put a stay on increasing the fee by schools till April 30. The school said, “The management has decided to put the fee revision on hold till further orders. The parents may pay the fee for the first quarter as per last year’s fee structure.” The school had earlier asked the parents to also pay the arrears as they had to pay the teachers following the implementation of the seventh pay commission. Parents have been asked to pay the fee by April 15. The school will be informing them following the new revision. “The fee that has already been paid online will get adjusted once the final decision is taken on the revised structure,” said the message sent to parents by the school. With the school withholding the hike , parents celebrated their victory and hoped that the court’s decision will also be in their favour.

title: Kolkata: Release us to pursue post-graduation course, say doctors as protest continues
og_title: Kolkata: Release us to pursue post-graduation course, say doctors as protest continues
content: KOLKATA: Government doctors who have qualified in NEET-PG to study MD/MS courses continued to protest for the second consecutive day on Tuesday demanding that all qualified doctors be facilitated to pursue post-graduate courses. They had sat on protest at Swasthya Bahwan, the state government’s health department headquarters in Salt Lake. State Administrative Tribunal (SAT) on April 2 had issued an interim order directing the state government to release all NEET-PG qualified doctors for MD/MS courses. MBBS doctors who have served government hospitals for three years and more and have qualified NEET-PG are entitled to study post-graduation under the trained reserved quota. Four-hundred fifty such candidates who are entitled under the trainee reserved category, qualified in the examination this year, the results of which was published in January. But government has enlisted the names of only 217 government doctors for MD/MS courses. This prompted 115 doctors move the SAT. “Despite the SAT order the health department is yet to come out with the new list that will enable all qualified government doctors to pursue MD/MS courses. We have been protesting since Monday. If the government fails to come out with the new list we immediately we will intensify our protest that include filing a contempt of court suit,” said Dr Sajjal Biswas, general secretary Serive Doctors Forum. Sources at the health department said that releasing all these doctors for attending post-graduation courses at one go will leave health units in rural areas under severe manpower. Most of these 450 doctors are posted in rural health facilities. In 2018 also the government had to realised at trainee reserved candidates for post-graduation course only after the Calcutta high court intervened.

title: Withdrawal of 2 cases against Patidar quota agitators allowed
og_title: Withdrawal of 2 cases against Patidar quota agitators allowed
content: AHMEDABAD: A city sessions court on Monday dropped two criminal cases against Patidar quota agitators after the state government insisted on withdrawing criminal charges “in larger public interest”. Five persons had been booked in each of the cases. The state government has been withdrawing criminal cases against some members of the Patidar community, who were booked during the reservation agitation in 2015. Of numerous cases registered against the alleged rioters, additional sessions judge A R Patel allowed the state government to withdraw two cases registered on basis of FIRs lodged with Bapunagar and Krishnanagar police stations in 2015. The public prosecutor sought withdrawal of cases “in larger public interest” under the provisions of Section 321 of the CrPC. He cited various authorities to show that the state government is empowered to decide to drop charges and withdraw criminal cases in public interest. Those who got relief in attempt to murder charges along with the rioting as registered were Umesh Patel, Pratik Mistri, Rajesh B Patel, Rajesh S Patel and Sanjay Patel. Similarly, Mehul Vaghasiya, Sahil Hirpara, Asmita Patel and Ashaben Patel were booked for rioting and unlawful assembly in 2015 the case against them too has been withdrawn.

title: TN woman dies after giving birth to boy, relatives protest medical negligence
og_title: TN woman dies after giving birth to boy, relatives protest medical negligence
content: TIRUVANNAMALAI: Relatives of a 33-year-old woman who died after giving birth to a baby boy staged a protest outside a private hospital on Tuesday demanding action against the doctor and staff for medical negligence . The deceased woman has been identified as Kavitha, 33, wife of Sivakumar, 39, of Chellangkuppam. Sivakumar is a daily waged earner. The couple have two daughters aged 11 and 7 years. Kavitha became pregnant again and was undergoing medication and medical diagnosis at JIPMER in Puducherry. Doctors, who found Kavitha to be anaemic, recommended blood transfusion before the due date (April 18). Sivakumar, who sustained a hip fracture in an accident, had been admitted to Government Hospital in Chennai for more than one month . Relatives and family members of Sivakumar took Kavitha to Sri Balaji Hospital in Tiruvannamalai town for blood transfusion on Monday . Dr Jayalakshmi of the hospital diagnosed Kavitha and said the foetus was in a critical condition. They asked the relatives to admit her immediately for a C-section. After the C-section , Kavitha underwent sterilization. The woman started to bleed profusely. She was sent to Tiruvannamalai Government Medical College and Hospital in an autorickshaw without any medical support. Doctors in the Tiruvannamalai GH declared that Kavitha was brought dead. Condemning medical negligence of the private hospital staff, more than 50 relatives of Kavitha carrying the newborn staged a protest in front of it on Tuesday morning . Police officials and a few local politicians came to the spot and pacified the relatives. They assured them that the family would get a compensation. Following this, the relatives withdrew their protest.

title: Police ‘modify’ youths’ protest plan, arrest 15
og_title: Police ‘modify’ youths’ protest plan, arrest 15
content: KOCHI: City witnessed a dramatic turn of events after police took 15 biking enthusiasts into custody at High Court Junction on Sunday evening. Police said the protest meet organized by the youths against the motor vehicles department’s (MVD) crackdown on modified vehicles created public nuisance and blocked traffic in the area. “The youths had apparently gathered in the city with the intention of breaking the rules. We are checking whether they have any criminal antecedents,” said a Central police station officer. The incident happened around 4.30pm when a group of youngsters clad in full riding gear reached High Court Junction on their bikes . Police confronted them when they reached Chathiyath Road. The youths created a ruckus at Queen’s Walkway when they saw a police team. Though most of the bikers fled the scene, police managed to nab 15 of them. The youths were booked under Section 279 of the IPC for rash driving and were later let off on bail from the police station itself, said an officer.

title: 150% fee hike by south Delhi school sparks stir
og_title: 150% fee hike by south Delhi school sparks stir
content: NEW DELHI: Several parents who send their children to a private school in south Delhi protested on Monday alleging that the school has hiked the fees by almost 150%. Quoting Delhi high court stay on fee hike , parents staged a demonstration claiming that the school was violating the rule and law. On Monday, wearing caps with a message “rollback fee hike”, the parents from St George’s School, Alaknanda, alleged that the high court has extended the stay till April 30 and prohibited schools from increasing the fee. “This is a school built on a government land, how can they increase the fees? It is just unbelievable that the fee has been increased from around Rs 55,000 to Rs 1,21,000, including the arrears. How can one pay so much money? All the charges have been increased. This was done all of a sudden without consultation,” said a parent. Parents put banners which said “paisa nahin duayen lo”, “take back fee hike” and have submitted a memorandum to the school. They have also submitted a complaint to the officials in the education department. “At first, they even refused to accept our memorandum, and then after waiting for so long, they finally accepted it. When the last PTM was held, we were only told about an increase of around Rs10,000,” said another parent. The school officials, however, did not respond to TOI’s calls and email. Meanwhile, deputy chief minister, Manish Sisodia congratulated the parents. “You all have chosen an honest government, and by no means will we allow private schools to increase fees arbitrarily,” Sisodia tweeted. Some of the parents were informed by the school that the high court rule does not apply to them, as they are a “minority school”. However, Khagesh Jha, advocate and member of Justice for All, who is representing the parents, said this order applies to all schools. “This interim order is applicable for minority schools as well. We are planning to file a contempt petition against this. Not only them, the order is also applicable to schools that have been given permission to increase fees. They also cannot charge the increased fees,” said Jha. Now, the parents are worried as the time given to pay the fees is approaching April 10. A senior official in Directorate of Education (DoE) said the school has been asked to rollback the fees. “The school cannot increase the fees without getting their accounts checked by DoE . We have asked the school to rollback. If they don’t comply, we will issue a notice,” said the official.

title: Residents protest over filthy roads, choked drains
og_title: Residents protest over filthy roads, choked drains
content: Ludhiana: Irked by choked sewerage, contaminated water supply and open manholes, residents of Shanti Nagar, Giaspura, staged a protest at Eastman Chowk on Monday and threatened to boycott the Lok Sabha elections as politicians of all hues have ignored their problems. They dared politicians to ask for votes and have rotten tomatoes and eggs thrown at them. Later, area councillor Jaspal Singh Giaspura and MC officials assured the residents of solving their problems to and asked them to end their protest. Abhimanyu Mishra, a resident, rued that for the past five years they have been struggling with contaminated water supply and choked sewerage in the locality and despite numerous complaints the problem still remains. He complained that the situation had gone worse in the last two months, which forced them to stage a protest. Another resident of the area, Shivam Kumar, said, “The main road of the area remains submerged in filthy sewerage water due to which school children and commuters face a tough time crossing it. The uncovered manholes pose a great risk as their presence can’t be judged for water is all around.” He added they will not vote for any party as none of the leaders was taking their problems seriously. The area councillor, however, said he was unable to understand why residents started the protest when they had already kicked off the cleaning works of the main sewerage line. “Due to the cleaning of main sewerage line through super suction machines, the inner drains were blocked temporarily and led to water stagnation. In response to the issue, zonal commissioner J S Sekhon said, “The sewerage water diverted due to super suction cleaning created blockage in the area, but only temporarily. We have installed a machine to clear the stagnant water from the road. The situation will improve as soon as the cleaning works are completed.”

title: Medical students protest against quotas in Mumbai
og_title: Medical students protest against quotas in Mumbai
content: MUMBAI: Medical PG aspirants protested here on Monday against reservations , which have reduced general category seats. An online petition was also shared and a candlelight march is planned on Carter Road on Sunday evening. A student of the Lokmanya Tilak Medical College said: “The government, to satisfy vote banks prior to polls, added the new categories of Maratha and economically backward class in the existing biased quota system.” . Only 4% seats in the state are available for general, unreserved people applying through the state quota, added another. “Candidates having ranks as high as SML (state merit list) 80 are not getting post-graduate seats of their choice. The future is bleak for students and for the healthcare sector,” said a parent. The petition, which has almost reached its target of 25,000 signatories, stated: “Providing reserved seats to students with socio-economically poor background is justified only till graduation. They are no more backward once they become doctors. Everyone deserves a fair chance to prepare and compete for the PG seat they want, and reservation takes that away from them.” It added, “A minimum of 50% of seats have been taken away from deserving candidates in PG institutes in all states. Nowadays, as soon as an election year comes up, governments indulge in vote bank politics, making it even more difficult for a doctor to survive in this nation.” The petition stated, “In 2019 the Maharashtra government increased reservations to a staggering 81%. Now, a candidate with 5,000 rank will not be able to take admission to the branch of his choice, but a student belonging to a reserved category with 70,000 rank will easily secure a seat.”

title: Lok Sabha elections: BJP ignores biggies, protests, drops nine more sitting MPs
og_title: Lok Sabha elections: BJP ignores biggies, protests, drops nine more sitting MPs
content: NEW DELHI: BJP on Saturday dropped nine more of its sitting MPs, disregarding resistance from influential satraps and dramatic protests of the discards. In an interesting choice, the party named Diya Kumari , scion of the former Jaipur royal family, for the Rajsamand seat in the Lok Sabha. In doing so, it has ignored strained equations the former Jaipur royals share with ex-CM Vasundhara Raje. This is the second instance of the brass taking calls which Raje may not be comfortable with. Early on, it reached out to saffron rebel Hanuman Beniwal , who had quit the party in protest against Raje’s unquestioned dominance. BJP is backing Beniwal’s candidature for the Nagore seat as an independent. Diya’s choice for Mewar seat raised eyebrows because Rajputs of the area have not been fond of her family since the days of their challenge to Mughal emperor Akbar. The then rulers of Jaipur chose to side with the Mughals, a call seen by Mewar Rajputs as treason. The surprise choice whetted the speculation about the party opting for a hardline Hindutva figure for the Bhopal seat to engage Congress veteran Digvijaya Singh in what could turn out to be mouth-watering clash of ideologies. Singh was at the forefront of the campaign against “Hindutva terror”, raised doubts about the identity of those who attacked Mumbai on 26/11 while passionately insisting that the Indian Mujahideen terrorists killed in a gunbattle with Delhi Police at Batla House were killed in a “fake encounter”. While Diya’s entry was facilitated by sitting member Hariom Singh Rathore’s decision to opt out because of health reasons, Banda MP Bhairon Prasad Mishra has been replaced with R K Patel despite astubborn resistance from the incumbent. The change had become necessary after Shyama Prasad Gupta entered the fray on an SP ticket, disrupting caste equations. Mishra responded to the leadership’s firmness by resorting to dharna, but to no avail. Gupta switched to SP amid indications that BJP was set to drop him. Union minister Uma Bharati, who has decided not to defend her Jhansi seat because of health issues, has been replaced by Anurag Sharma of the Baidyanath Group, a well-known name for ayurveda medicines. Sharma’s father Vishwanath Sharma has been a BJP leader. Party veteran Ram Tahal Chaudhary has to make way for Sanjay Seth for the Ranchi seat. Chaudhary, a known Kurmi leader of the state who turned 77 this year, was keen on contesting the seat he comfortably won in 2014. Former Jharkhand minister and sitting MP from Koderma, Ravindra Roy, has been dropped with the party bringing in Annapurna Devi, a recent induction from RJD. Sitting Gwalior MP and Union minister Narendra Singh Tomar, who has been shifted to neighbouring Morena, has been replaced by Vivek Sejwalkar. For the Barmer seat in Rajasthan, the party has chosen Kailash Chaudhary at the expense of sitting member Colonel Sonaram Chaudhary (retd). The retired army official had lost the recent assembly polls, a possible reason why he had to face the axe. In 2014, the party had defied protests from its veteran leader Jaswant Singh to field Sonaram, leading the former to contest as an Independent. The saffron party is yet to announce candidates from several key constituencies including Gorakhpur, Deoria, Bhadohi, Jaunpur, Ghosi and Bhopal. Diya Kumari had won the assembly polls on the BJP symbol in 2013 from Sawai Madhopur but did not contest the recent state polls. In Video: Lok Sabha polls 2019 : BJP drops nine more sitting MPs

title: J&K political parties protest 2-day a week highway ban
og_title: J&K political parties protest 2-day a week highway ban
content: SRINAGAR: Mainstream political parties in Jammu and Kashmir on Sunday took out protest marches against the government's restrictions on movement of civilian traffic on the Jammu- Srinagar national highway. The government has ordered the closure of the Jammu-Srinagar highway for all kinds of civilian traffic from Udhampur to Baramulla every Sunday and Wednesday in order to facilitate movement of security forces for Lok Sabha election duty. It will remain effective till May 31. National Conference president Farooq Abdullah has demanded the immediate roll back of the restrictions, while PDP chief Mehbooba Mufti termed the government's decision as "wrong". The decision came in the aftermath of the February 14 terror attack on a Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) convoy on the highway in Pulwama district . Forty CRPF personnel were killed. On March 30, another attempt was made to target a CRPF convoy with a car bomb on the highway near Banihal in Ramban district. NC leaders led by Abdullah took out a march at Athwajan on the highway to protest the ban imposed by the government. "This is a wrong order. They should use train service for the movement of the security force personnel or they can move them at night so that people do not have to suffer,”the NC president said. "It is our demand that this order be revoked. It sounds like dictatorship," Abdullah added. Former chief minister Omar Abdullah also slammed the authorities over the ban order, terming it "mindless". "Driving to Uri I'm getting to see first hand the extent of disruption and inconvenience that is being caused to people because of the mindless highway closure order that is in place today," Abdullah tweeted. Driving to Uri I’m getting to see first hand the extent of disruption & inconvenience that is being caused to peopl… https://t.co/jIkBMVOU9i — Omar Abdullah (@OmarAbdullah) 1554611748000 PDP president Mehbooba Mufti also took out a protest march against the ban. "This is very wrong. We don't have an occupational army here. If the government of India thinks that by resorting to such tactics they can suppress the people here, they are wrong," she said. The former chief minister said her party will go to court against the ban order. "Kashmir belongs to Kashmiris . That they will have to seek permission to use their own roads, we will not allow this to happen. I appeal to people to defy this ban," she said. Later, Mehbooba took to Twitter saying she will not allow Kashmiris to be imprisoned in their own land. "Protested against Guv admins callous & absurd ban today. How can you restrict civilian movement on our main highway? You want to smother Kashmiris, change the demographics of the state & imprison them in their own land? Over my dead body," she tweeted. Protested against Guv admins callous & absurd ban today. How can you restrict civilian movement on our main highway… https://t.co/OHFDqnDDbk — Mehbooba Mufti (@MehboobaMufti) 1554623771000 The People's Conference leader and candidate for Srinagar Lok Sabha seat Irfan Ansari also staged a protest near Bemina against the ban. Meanwhile, the Jammu and Kashmir administration sought cooperation of the people in the smooth regulation of traffic along the Jammu-Srinagar National Highway, saying it was "committed" to ensure least inconvenience to civilian vehicles during movement of security convoys on the notified days. The elaborate arrangements made by administration for convenience of the people on the highway, the only all-weather road linking Kashmir with the rest of the country, during the restricted travel period was quite successful on the first day of the traffic prohibition, an official release said.

title: FRA: Himachal Van Adhikar Manch announces one-day protest on April 11
og_title: FRA: Himachal Van Adhikar Manch announces one-day protest on April 11
content: CHANDIGARH: Himachal Van Adhikar Manch has announced a one-day protest on April 11 at Seri Manch in Mandi to seek a speedy and just implementation of the Forest Rights Act (FRA) 2006. Its members said that despite the significance of this Act for the communities in Himachal Pradesh whose livelihoods are dependent upon agricultural and livestock rearing, the state government and bureaucracy have both failed to implement this Act efficiently on the ground. They demanded revision of FRA claims of people in Mandi after proper dissemination of information among people and training regharding which they alleged that entire Mandi district has been declared zero/nil-claims by the district administration machinery and is now being replicated in other districts of the state as well. TOI made repeated calls and texted message to head of forest force, Himachal Pradesh, Ajay Kumar for his version on the issue, but he did not respond. According to Shyam Singh Chauhan, member of the organisation, “Only 129 claims have been recorded by the state ever since the Act came into being in 2006. Such indolence in the implementation of this act has continued because of misunderstandings and doubts about the Act among the concerned authorities and bureaucracy as well as due to lack of any technical training for the line officials. So we demand that the governments must provide proper information and organise trainings for all the members of Forest Rights Committees, and concerned line departments (Revenue, Forest and Panchayati Raj), so that a time-bound and in informed decision can be taken on the matter.” The Forest Rights Act was passed by Parliament in 2006, with the aim of protecting the interests as well as providing legal recognition and recording the rights of the communities dependent on forest land for their bonafide livelihood needs. Pawna Kumar, another member, said that in 2014, in order to ease out forest land diversion for development activities, all Forest Rights Committees (FRC) and gram sabhas in the entire Mandi district of Himachal Pradesh have been made to pass 'nil certificates' through the panchayat secretaries, therefore declaring that the people of the entire district do not have any forest rights or claims under the mentioned act. Manshi Asher, activist and member, said that the district administrative officers are now replicating the same model of Mandi in other districts as well. “A similar approach has been carried out in the district of Chamba whereas in Kangra district, the bureaucracy is on the drive of collecting similar nil certificates by putting a timeline of 90 days for FRA claim collection. This is impossible to achieve when people have no idea about the provisions of the Act itself,” she said, adding that in reality not just in the district of Mandi but in the entire state more than lakhs of families have held the forest land under occupation since much before the cut off date of December 13, 2005 prescribed under the Act for the purpose of agriculture and day-to-day living. “These families have been facing the threat of eviction and living in insecurity and it is only under the FRA 2006 that they can claim individual rights for the occupied land and ensure their livelihoods. These lakhs of forest dependent households that rely on forest land for fuel wood, timber, fodder, streams, herbal medicines, stone and sand etc., are also eligible to claim for community rights over the same under this act,” she explained.

title: Venezuelans protest as Guaido declares 'definitive' escalation
og_title: Venezuelans protest as Guaido declares 'definitive' escalation
content: CARACAS: Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido on Saturday launched what he promised will be a "definitive" escalation of pressure to force the country's embattled leftist leader from office. Addressing a giant anti-government rally in Caracas , Guaido — whose claim to be interim president is supported by around 50 nations — kicked off what he called "Operation Liberty," his plan to oust President Nicolas Maduro. "Everyone to the streets, let's start the final phase of the end of the usurpation!" he told supporters, speaking from the back of a pickup truck. He called for a huge nationwide turnout on Wednesday, and urged his followers to redouble their efforts to maintain pressure in the streets. "The greatest escalation of pressure we have seen in our history" has begun, Guaido said. The call comes amid massive blackouts and the collapse of water supplies affecting the nation, further exacerbated a growing political crisis. The United States meanwhile has stiffened its economic sanctions against Maduro, and one top US official warned Venezuela 's military that it must protect the rights of peaceful protesters. At the rally, Guaido also warned Cuba's President Miguel Diaz-Canel that the supply of subsidized Venezuelan oil to the Caribbean communist island nation was over. Venezuela has been sending cheap oil to Cuba in exchange for labor from Cuban doctors and teachers, but Guaido said the oil was actually financing a Cuban intelligence group known as G2 that was cracking down on Maduro opponents in the Venezuelan military. "The exploitation of Venezuelan oil is over, so Mr Diaz-Canel... Venezuelan oil will not be used to submit and investigate our military officials" through the G2, he told the crowd. Pro-Guaido protests drew thousands in rallies across the country on Saturday. A pro-Maduro counter-demonstration in Caracas, with supporters dressed in red, drew a large crowd that gathered at the Miraflores presidential palace. "Together, permanently mobilized, let's keep defending national peace and independence; no more interference!" Maduro tweeted. Later, he called upon Mexico and Uruguay to relaunch their proposal for dialogue to resolve the crisis without foreign intervention. The two countries had first introduced that idea in January. Two opposition deputies were detained at an anti-government demo in the western city of Maracaibo, but a few hours later Guaido announced that the two had been released. Elimar Diaz, a lawmaker who marched in Maracaibo, told AFP the protest there had encountered "brutal repression," including tear gas canisters dropped from helicopters, the use of National Guard armored vehicles and attacks by members of the pro-government militia, known as "colectivos." Diaz said people in Maracaibo had gone "days without electricity" amid "inhumane rationing" by the government. Maduro has blamed US-backed sabotage for the massive blackouts that have deprived millions of power. The opposition blames a failure to maintain critical infrastructure. Facing intense pressure at home and abroad, the Maduro government has sought to weaken Guaido. The government has stripped his parliamentary immunity, authorized his prosecution for proclaiming himself acting president, and banned him from holding public office for 15 years. Guaido said earlier this week he feared that he could be abducted by government agents. Speaking to the pro-government Constitutional Assembly, Maduro's top lieutenant Diosdado Cabello slammed the US point man on Venezuela, Elliott Abrams, as an "assassin." "It is Abrams who should be in prison, condemned in the United States for genocide in Central America," said Cabello, referring to the US official's controversial role in the Central American conflicts of the 1980s. Washington meanwhile kept up the international pressure on Maduro to step down. Vice President Mike Pence on Friday announced fresh sanctions against 34 vessels belonging to Venezuela's state oil company and two companies that ship crude to Cuba. "This is only a first step," US national security advisor John Bolton tweeted on Saturday in reference to the sanctions. He cautioned the Venezuelan defense minister in a separate tweet of the official's "constitutional responsibility to protect innocent civilians who are peacefully demonstrating," adding: "Do not let the Cubans or the 'colectivos' inflict violence against Venezuelan patriots." Maduro is supported by the Venezuelan military, China and Russia. Washington and its allies view the socialist president as illegitimate since he took office in January for a second term following elections widely seen as deeply flawed. Washington has convened a UN Security Council for Wednesday to discuss the Venezuelan crisis. Since Venezuela's massive blackout of March 7, the country has been subject to repeated power cuts, with electricity being rationed outside of Caracas. The blackouts have knocked out water supplies as well as transport and communications, forcing many people to trim their work days to six hours.

title: Education department warns Ramgarh schools of de-affiliation following protests against fee hike
og_title: Education department warns Ramgarh schools of de-affiliation following protests against fee hike
content: RAMGARH: The district education department reportedly issued letters to private schools , warning them of cancelling their affiliation in the wake of ongoing protests by parents alleging collection of annual capitation and hike in tuition fees. On Saturday too, several parents staged protests outside DAV Public School in Rajrappa against arbitrary hike in fees ahead of the commencement of the new academic session. A group of parents also demonstrated outside the office of the general manager of Central Coalfields Limited (CCL) since morning, claiming that they are being forced to buy books and uniforms from schools against the norms. CCL (Ramgarh division) funds the operations of DAV Public School, Rajrappa. Gopal Chaudhary, one of the parents leading the protest, claimed that DAV Public School has hiked its tuition fee by more than 40% and is collecting annual capitation fee in the name of annual development fund. “This is against the directives of the government as well as the norms of Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE),” he said, adding, “Some of the other private schools in the district are also resorting to such tactics.” Chaudhary said their protests will continue till the school management rolls back the hike. H K Jha, principal of DAV Public School in Rajrappa, admitted that the school has increased its tuition fee but refuted the allegations of any violation of government norms. “The hike is for the annual development of the school and facilities that we provide. I don’t think it is any violation of government directives,” he said. Raja Ram Sahu, district superintendent of education (DSE), didn’t wish to comment on this particular issue. He, however, said owing to growing protests by parents he has issued directives to all the private schools under their jurisdiction, warning them to cancellation of their affiliation if the hike is found to be unjustified or arbitrary. “On the orders of the deputy commissioner we have sent letters to all schools in this regard. The state government gives affiliations to schools from LKG to Class VIII while boards such as CBSE and ICSE provides affiliations to schools from Class IX till XII,” Sahu said, adding, “We have sought reports from all schools from Classes I to VIII with details of facilities, infrastructure and fee structure etc. Once we get the reports we will take action if we find any cases of violations by such schools,” he said.

title: Goa University teachers write to NSUI over student protest
og_title: Goa University teachers write to NSUI over student protest
content: PANAJI: The Goa University Teachers’ Association (GUTA) has written to the president of the National Students Union of India (NSUI) condemning Thursday’s incident wherein students affiliated to the student body confronted Goa University’s controller of examinations over the delay in declaration of re-evaluation results of fifth semester law students. The re-evaluation results were declared by examination authorities hours after students protested at the GU premises. A group of students gheraoed the controller of examinations . The teachers’ association asked NSUI to “desist from any such future actions”. Denying the abuse charges, NSUI said that in a democratic country, students have a right to question the functioning of any authority if it is not functioning efficiently .

title: French yellow vest protesters hit streets for 21st weekend
og_title: French yellow vest protesters hit streets for 21st weekend
content: PARIS: Protesters from the yellow vest movement are taking to the streets of France for a 21st straight weekend, with hundreds gathered for a march across Paris , one of numerous protests around the country. Paris police have fine-tuned their strategy of being more mobile and proactive to counter eventual violence since the first Saturday of protests Nov 17. The Champs-Elysees avenue is off-limits to protesters after it was hit by rioting last month. Hundreds gathered in Rouen, in Normandy, a past flashpoint, and hundreds more in eastern Paris at the Place de la Republique, the start of a march to the business district on the capital's western edge. The yellow vest movement, demanding social and economic justice, has attracted dwindling crowds but still remains a challenge to president Emmanuel Macron .

title: A protest for freedom, in Sudan
og_title: A protest for freedom, in Sudan
content: NEW DELHI: On April 6 every year, the people of Sudan commemorate the suspension of the east African country’s constitution in 1985 after a coup led by general Swarreddahab. At Jantar Mantar on Saturday, however, Sudanese students gathered not to remember that event but to protest the rule of President Omar al-Bashir , who himself came to power after a similar coup four years after Swarreddahab. Waving the red, white, black and green flag of Sudan, Ibrahim Shingrai expressed solidarity with demonstrators in Khartoum, who have been on the streets since December 19 last year, raising a voice against the economic crisis and demanding an end to the 30-year rule of al-Bashir. After submitting a memorandum addressed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi about the worrisome situation in Sudan, Ibrahim said, “We are sending messages to the Indian government and the UN requesting them to not only express concern, but to take action immediately and advise al-Bashir to resign peacefully without killing more people.” The students are all worried about the events back in their country. Shingrai, Abdullah Yahia, Awad, Fahat and Arif, all students, are tense and fear for the safety of their families. Arif said, “My family’s only inspiration is Mahatma Gandhi, whose story our father told us.” Gandhiji had stopped in Port Sudan en route to England in 1935. Yahia was emphatic that the al-Bashir government had to step down. “We want a fresh revolution by the youths,” he said. “We are a small group, but other Sudanese across India also support us.” This is the students’ second protest at Jantar Mantar after one on February 1.

title: Patiala: Parents protest after kids denied entry to school
og_title: Patiala: Parents protest after kids denied entry to school
content: PATIALA: After a long protest by students, parents , Patiala MP Dr Dharamvira Gandhi on Sunday and directions from the Punjab and Haryana high court, Budha Dal Public School allowed entry to hundreds of students, who failed to clear their dues. The issue was resolved after district administrative officials intervened. On Friday, the Punjab and Haryana high court directed the school to allow students to attend their classes, but the adamant school authorities still refused to comply with the court orders. The students and their parents then staged a protest in front of the school. Patiala MP Dr Dharamvira Gandhi also joined and pressurised school authorities. Meanwhile, Dr Gandhi said strict action should be taken against the school authorities for denying students the right to education. He said he would discuss the issue with the state education secretary Krishan Kumar and find a permanent solution to the problem. Patiala SDM too rushed to the spot after the protest intensified. The administrative officials then played a key role and held talks with the school authorities and parents, following which the students could entry the school. A final decision will now be taken by the secretary education. J S Singh, a member of Budha Dal Parent Association, said, "We had to knock the doors of the high court after the district administration and police failed to implement the orders of secretary education."

title: Hundreds protest in London over Brunei's anti-gay sharia laws
og_title: Hundreds protest in London over Brunei's anti-gay sharia laws
content: LONDON: Hundreds of people rallied outside the Brunei-owned Dorchester hotel in London on Saturday in protest at new Islamic sharia laws in the country that punish homosexuality , adultery and rape with the death penalty. Brunei, a Muslim-majority former British protectorate with a population of 400,000, has defended its right to implement sharia that punishes sodomy, adultery and rape with the death penalty -- including by stoning, and theft with amputation. The laws, elements of which were first adopted in 2014, have been rolled out in phases since then including this week, stirring international outrage. Brunei's state-owned investment agency BIA owns the Dorchester Collection hotel group, which features luxury venues such as the Dorchester, the Beverly Hills Hotel and the Plaza Athenee in Paris . On Saturday, protesters gathered outside the Dorchester carrying banners, with some breaking through a barrier to reach the entrance where they held rainbow flags and chanted slogans such as "shame on you" and "gay rights, human rights ", television footage showed. Human rights campaigner Peter Tatchell said death by stoning "has no place in the 21st century". "Stoning to death is a particularly unique, cruel, brutal punishment designed to prolong the agony of the person being killed," he told Reuters. The Dorchester hotel did not immediately respond to an emailed request from Reuters for comment on Saturday. The United Nations said on Wednesday Brunei was violating human rights by implementing its sharia measures.

title: Azam Khan seeks permission to protest against Rampur DM
og_title: Azam Khan seeks permission to protest against Rampur DM
content: RAMPUR: The Samajwadi Party (SP) has accused Rampur district magistrate (DM) Aunjaneya Kumar Singh of supporting BJP’s Rampur Lok Sabha (LS) candidate Jaya Prada , and trying to “impose sanctions on Azam Khan’s speeches”. SP’s Rampur LS candidate Azam Khan’s media in-charge Fashat Ali Khan led a SP delegation to meet Moradabad Division Commissioner Yashwant Rao and presented a memorandum in Moradabad on Thursday. District SP president Akhilesh Kumar alleged that the Rampur DM tried to “impose sanctions on the speeches of Azam Khan and hence, violate our leader's constitutional rights”. “Our country’s constitution guarantees freedom of speech and expression for one and all. On behest of the district magistrate, fake and manufactured defamation cases were registered against Azam Khan,” Kumar alleged. “Such FIRs cannot stop us from telling the truth and we are not going to be scared of these cases. In fact, we are ready to go to jail,” Kumar also said. Local SP leaders also alleged that Rampur administrative officials were trying to create an atmosphere of fear ahead of the polling date. Fashat Ali Khan said, “Azam Khan along with the other party leaders will stage a protest against the DM on April 9. It will be a peaceful protest and we have sought permission from the commissioner’s office as the model code of conduct is in place ahead of the Lok Sabha elections.” DM Aunjaneya Kumar Singh told TOI that all the allegations against him were “entirely baseless”. “The SP is levelling baseless allegations against me. If they have any evidence then they can produce it before the election commission,” the DM said. The DM further said, “An FIR was lodged against him [Azam Khan] by the police on a local Congress leader’s complaint. After watching video footage, we have only taken cognizance of the compliant. We need to be very clear about one thing that nobody is above the law. We will not compromise with law and order during the elections because we need to abide by the model code of conduct.”

title: Arabul blocks road, Bhangar protesters ‘shove’ him away
og_title: Arabul blocks road, Bhangar protesters ‘shove’ him away
content: Bhangar: Women at a rally in Bhangar , called by Jami Jibika Bastutantra Committee, shoved Trinamool leader Arabul Islam out of their way , when the leader blocked the road with his car in a bid to stop them from going to a meeting, being held in support of Jadavpur CPM candidate Bikash Bhattacharya on Friday. It was Bhattacharya who had offered the outfit members legal help when it had led the land protest against the power grid project in Bhangar. The Committee on Friday organised the meeting on the Bhangar’s Shyamnagar Primary School ground, where CPI(ML) Red Star leader Aleek Chakrabarty and Bhattacharya were among the speakers. A day earlier, at a Trinamool gathering, Bhangar strongman Arabul had announced he would not allow the CPI(ML) leader to enter his birthplace. Even as supporters started heading for the Shyamnagar meeting on Friday, Arabul and his associates arrived in a car and parked it across the road around 4.30pm. “He started browbeating the participants and abused women,” said rally organiser Sharmistha Choudhury. But the women, followed by others, rushed towards him and shoved him out of the way. Arabul later claimed he was on the spot, returning home. “People with lathis led an attack on me. My security saved me. They damaged my car. I am going to the police station to lodge a complaint,” he said. Shortly, Arabul loyalists assembled at Shyamnagar and later at Natun Hat More and blocked the road for about two hours. Arabul and his son Hakimul were part of the demonstration.

title: Mylapore residents protest CMRL land acquisition move
og_title: Mylapore residents protest CMRL land acquisition move
content: CHENNAI: Residents of Mylapore and neighbouring localities are planning to write to the central government to change the alignment of phase-2 of Chennai Metro Rail and avoid their busy stretches like TTK Road, Luz Church Road and Kutchery Road, as it would disturb the locality and displace residents. On Friday, more than 50 residents gathered in a hall on the TTK Road to discuss CMRL’s plans to acquire land in these roads for the construction of phase-2 of metro rail network. “We are well connected by MTC. Let metro rail improve MRTS after takeover instead of building a new metro rail network here,” said E Murali, one of the residents. These roads in city’s core localities like Alwarpet, Mylapore and Mandaveli will be linked in corridor 4, planned from Lighthouse to Poonamallee. “Instead of entering the TTK Road, the line can go straight to Mandaveli from Adyar Gate and link Lighthouse through Santhome,” Murali said. “For TTK residents, we have a station on the Anna Salai which is only about half a kilometre,” he said.

title: Palsora villagers hold stir against opening of liquor vend near school
og_title: Palsora villagers hold stir against opening of liquor vend near school
content: CHANDIGARH: The residents of Palsora village on Friday staged a protest against the opening of a liquor vend at the entrance of the village. Some political parties too joined the protesters and raised slogans against the Chandigarh administration and municipal corporation. Congress leader Bhupinder Badheri said liquor vend is close to a school and temple and the authorities should not have allowed its opening at the site. The administration should consider the genuine demands of the villagers instead of only worrying about generating revenue, he added. Local area councillor Satish Kainth said even the allotment of site to the liquor vend is questionable. “The shop where the liquor vend has been opened belonged to the Chandigarh municipal corporation. The shop was rented out to a person and as per the rules, he can’t sublet the shop to anyone else. However, there has been a clear vioaltion of the rule in this case.” He along with villagers have lodged a complaint in this regard to MC, following which the civic body has formed a committee to look into the matter, he added. Meanwhile, Gurinder Singh, a villager, said a few days ago, the authorities had closed down the liquor vend but it was opened again on Friday. “We only want that the liquor vend should be immediately shifted away from the village entrance,” he added. Requesting anonymity, a senior MC official said they have formed a committee and are looking into the matter.

title: Parties, protesters give a clean burial to illegal sand mining
og_title: Parties, protesters give a clean burial to illegal sand mining
content: TRICHY: Illegal sand mining was singled out as the root cause of water scarcity and protests have been raging for years over it, but come elections, the issue figures nowhere in party manifestos or speeches of leaders. In fact, it is not just the political parties which have pushed the issue of illegal sand mining to the backburner, even the protesters seem to have forgotten it. Both the AIADMK and DMK have consciously left out the issue from their election manifesto. Ever since the Madurai bench of Madras high court clamped a ban on sand mining and quarries across Cauvery, Kollidam, Thamirabarani, Palar and Amaravathi rivers were shut in August 2018, illegal mining has been thriving with the support of influential people. The anti-social elements now target small rivers in the area as is evident from the cases registered in Trichy region in the past seven months. Curiously enough, the farmers’ associations and activists who had staged protests against the illegal sand mining saying it led to depletion of ground water are now silent. Tamilaga Vivasayigal Sangam district president M P Chinnadurai pointed out the failure of the farmers’ associations to rake up the issue during the election. “Our focus is restricted to agriculture loan waiver. The sand mining issue should have been on top of our demands,” he said adding that the mysterious disappearance of environmental activist S Mugilan also may have prevented others from taking up the issue. The protests by activists and farmers were spurred mainly by the excess sand that was being extracted from the rivers. Sustainable sand mining guidelines 2016 say the mining depth should be restricted to 3 metres and the distance from the bank 3 metres or 10 % of the river width whichever was less. However, the miners cared two hoots for it and violated the norms. The negative impact of the decades-long exploitation of the rivers by the sand miners still keeps the people in several areas along the Cauvery, Kollidam rivers running from pillar to post for drinking water. There were times when loading of sand from the quarries was round-the-clock. The regular movement of about 1,000 sand-laden heavy vehicles every day also posed serious threat to lives and caused damage to roads. Tamil Desa Makkal Munnani state committee member advocate J Kennedy who fought the plundering of river sand in the delta region said, “None of the parties have any idea about an eco-friendly environment. In the context of crony capitalism, there is no bond or bondage with nature,” he said. One of the co-ordinators of Cauvery River Protection Movement S Vijayan, a close associate of Mugilan, pointed out that PMK which raised the pitch against sand mining was on the side of AIADMK for electoral gains. Trichy district secretary of the pro-CPI Tamilaga Vivasayigal Sangam Ayilai Siva Suriyan said, “The two regimes of AIADMK government destroyed the major portion of the rivers through indiscriminate sand mining. As an ally, we will demand that the DMK regulate sand mining if they come to power,” he said.

title: Safai sewaks protest against exploitation
og_title: Safai sewaks protest against exploitation
content: PATIALA: Safai Sewaks on Thursday protested in the hometown of the Amrinder Singh in Patiala against the exploitation as they say they are allegedly forced to work at private shops or as domestic helps in the houses of administrative officials. A large number of class four employees, brought half a dozen of garbage collection vans and dumped the garbage in front of a shop where allegedly a female safai sewak was forced to work at the behest of a senior official in the Patiala Municipal Corporation . The protesting safai sewaks claimed that it had become a common feature here in the city where they had to work either in the leaders or district administrative officials which was not their job. They said that keeping the city clean and clearing garbage from public places was their job. A large number of vacancies continue to remain. While there were 1470 worker in 1990, there were only 627 of them in 2017. They claimed of the 627, 100 of them were working in private houses and shops. Sunil Kumar, President of safai sewak union said, ``We would intensify our agitation against the corporation officials if the exploitation of our colleagues did not stop. ‘’ The protest was however called off on assurance of action.

title: OGH doctors resume work, continue protest
og_title: OGH doctors resume work, continue protest
content: HYDERABAD: Junior doctors of Osmania General Hospital (OGH) continued their protest for the second consecutive day on Thursday despite calling off their strike. The junior doctors are protesting against the alleged 'vote bank politics' of health minister Etala Rajender, who attended a meeting organised by registered medical practitioners (RMP)s and private medical practitioners (PMPs). The angry doctors demanded that the government should stop encouraging 'quacks'. The junior doctors launched the strike on Wednesday with a threat that they would not work until their stipend, which had been pending for over seven months, is cleared. The medicos cried halt to their strike temporarily after the stipend of most was credited on Thursday. Nevertheless, they held a protest in front of the administrative building questioning the minister's meet with RMPs and PMPs. "Although the strike has been withheld for now, we will come up with a plan of action to campaign against quackery within a few days," a statement from the Telangana Junior Doctors Association (TJUDA) said. TJUDA demanded that the government appoint a qualified MBBS doctor in every village to put an end to RMPs practising. The TJUDA has taken a strong stand against the RMPs and PMPs as they claim that these terms are often misused by quacks. "Many persons are using terms like RMPs to fool gullible people. The Indian Medical Council does not have such a term. Such quacks are a threat to public health and instead of curbing their practice, the government is supporting them," said Dr PS Vijayender Goud, President TJUDA. The government should ban them to save the people, he added.

title: After protests, Goa University releases LLB re-evaluation results
og_title: After protests, Goa University releases LLB re-evaluation results
content: PANAJI: Goa University on Wednesday declared the results of re-evaluation of marks for fifth semester LLB students after agitated candidates visited the office of the varsity’s controller of examinations to voice their protest. The students asked officials why results of the re-evaluation had not been declared even over two months after they had applied for them. Re-exams are scheduled to begin next week, and students said they were still unaware if they had cleared the original exam after re-evaluation. A video of students questioning the university’s authorities began circulating online on Wednesday. The same evening, Goa University officials said results of the re-evaluation had been announced. Last year too, students of the undergraduate law programme had protested the same issue. They said they were uncertain if they had to prepare for a retest if they were left uninformed about re-evaluation results until the week of the retest. “Additionally, we have to study for regular exams. We do not know which exam to focus on and don’t understand why this repeated delay occurs,” a student said. Goa has two colleges, one each in both districts, offering graduate law programmes. Both are affiliated to GU.

title: Bees at Mhovacho Guno still agitated but no more attacks
og_title: Bees at Mhovacho Guno still agitated but no more attacks
content: KERI: Bees continued to be scattered at Mhovacho Guno in Caranzol-Sonal on Thursday but no one was attacked. On Tuesday, a group of picnickers had mistakenly disturbed a hive, agitating the bees. A consequent attack had resulted in the death of one person and serious injuries to eight others. The scenic spot along the Mhadei attracts a large number of visitors and over the years, unruly behaviour has seen many deaths due to drowning, but never bee stings. Lau Satu Gaonkar, 57, from Sonal told TOI, “Every year, bees build their hives on the boulders locally known as Mhovacho Guno, which sit on the bank of the Mhadei. These stones hold historic and cultural significance and we never touch or harm the hives. We have never experienced a bee attack.” However, Tuesday’s incident was the result of unruly behaviour on the part of some visitors. Sources said a picnicker was throwing stones in the river, when one mistakenly hit a nearby hive, rousing the bees. Shamrao Morey, 60, jumped into the river to hide, but drowned. Locals said visitors should exercise caution and not get too adventurous, especially in wild hinterlands like this. Earlier, several picnickers had drowned in the river, and locals added that visitors get carried away by the silent waters and fail to factor presence of currents.

title: Kerala HC orders action against Sabarimala protesters
og_title: Kerala HC orders action against Sabarimala protesters
content: KOCHI: The high court on Thursday directed for taking action against the agitators who attacked a 32-year-old Tamil woman and outraged her modesty when she was on her way to Sabarimala on March 18. A division bench of Justice P R Ramachandra Menon and Justice N Anilkumar issued the directive after considering a report filed by Sabarimala special commissioner M Manoj. The agitators blocked Rajam Sathyamoorthy of Chennai around 7.35pm at Marakoottam and tried to verify her age. She was criminally intimidated and wrongfully restrained by them when she resisted. Police came to the scene and dispersed them. Two cases were registered for threatening the woman and obstructing police on the basis of the incident, the special commissioner's report said. Along with the special commissioner's report, a report filed by police controller at Sannidhanam has also been filed before court. This report mentions the incident in detail. As per the report, the agitators tried to verify her age proof which she refused. The agitators then obstructed the journey of the pilgrim group to which she belonged. The members of the group then came out in the woman's support and argued with the agitators for demanding to know her age and also their behaviour towards her, the report said. "Suddenly more agitators came and joined, one of them hit her and pulled her back and also threatened her that she wouldn't be allowed to move forward to visit the shrine if she did not show the ID card. By touching her body and continuously threatening for a while, they intentionally outraged her modesty. When her husband tried to protect her, the violent agitators also manhandled him. He was a heart patient who had undergone angioplasty," the police controller's report said. The agitators were members of the Sabarimala Karma Samithi, Antharashtra Hindu Parishad, Hindu Aikya Vedi , Aachara Samrakshana Samithi, and Vishwa Hindu Parishad, the report said.

title: Greens to launch protest against Padmasarovaram in Kochi
og_title: Greens to launch protest against Padmasarovaram in Kochi
content: KOCHI: Environmental protection groups in Kochi have decided to form a common platform to intensify agitations against projects that are not eco-friendly. A meeting of environmentalists held here on Thursday decided to conduct a joint and long-standing protest against Kochi corporation's Padmasarovaram, a cycle track and walkway project, and a bund constructed by Kochi Metro Rail Ltd (KMRL) across Kaniyampuzha River at Chambakkara. The meeting also decided to carry out campaigns for creating awareness among the public about the damages caused by Padmasarovaram and the bund across Kaniyampuzha. "We have decided to carryout protests against the two projects. Padmasarovaram project is being implemented violating coastal regulation zone (CRZ) norms. A bund was constructed across Chilavannoor backwaters for facilitating the construction of a viaduct as part of the project. No approvals, including that from Kerala Coastal Zone Management Authority (KCZMA), has been secured for constructing the bund as well as the viaduct across the backwaters," said environmentalist and state convener of AAP C R Neelakandan. "Same is the case with the bund constructed by KMRL across Kaniyampuzha. It was constructed three years ago for facilitating the construction of Metro pillars. Though KMRL authorities had promised to demolish it once the pillars were constructed, they didn't keep their word," he said. Environmentalists will start an agitation demanding implementation of Padmasarovaram project as per its original design. Had the project been implemented as per the original design, Padmasarovaram would have come up on the marshy land off the backwaters. Then, it would not have affected the backwaters. "But authorities changed the design. The original project was more eco-friendly. So, we have decided to start an agitation demanding that the project should be implemented in its original design. Though we had applied before the Kochi corporation seeking a copy of the original design of Padmasarovaram, they failed to provide it. But we have secured the original design through other means," said RTI activist K T Cheshire. There are allegations that the bund was being constructed across Chilavannoor backwaters for helping land mafia who possess holdings near the backwaters. The flow of water through both Chilavannoor backwaters and Kaniyampuzha river has been affected due to the construction of the bunds. Meanwhile, Cheshire has filed a complaint with ombudsman for local bodies seeking measures to stop implementation of Padmasarovaram project based on the revised design. Revenue department had issued a stop memo for the project a month ago. He also submitted another complaint requesting immediate measures to stop the work on a park at Elamkulam. As per the complaint, Kochi corporation is constructing the park on a reclaimed land. "DLF had reclaimed the land near its apartment complex. Following the Supreme Court order against the reclamation, around 50 cents which was reclaimed by the firm had been taken over by the corporation. Rather than removing the mud and debris and restoring the levelled land, corporation authorities are being constructing the park. This is to help the private builder," Cheshire said.

title: Mumbai: Their path blocked by ‘train bullies’, women spill onto Diva tracks
og_title: Mumbai: Their path blocked by ‘train bullies’, women spill onto Diva tracks
content: MUMBAI: Women commuters protested by jumping onto the train tracks in front of a suburban train and staging a flash rail roko at Diva station on Thursday morning after being denied entry by “train bullies” in crowded ladies compartments. This delayed train services during morning peak hours along the Karjat/Kasara - CSMT corridor and affected travel during peak hours early morning. Sources said that a few women commuters had also complained that whenever they managed to enter the compartment of a fast train from Diva, they found it difficult to get a seat as there were “groups” which only allowed their own members to occupy seats. Central Railway’s senior public relations officer, Anil Kumar Jain, said that not a single train had been cancelled due to the incident and services were gradually restored to the normal schedule. The railway authorities are however not happy with the protest incident due to which the train was detained between 7.10am and 7.18am, and this led to bunching of other trains. Sources said that the women had first approached the motorman with a verbal complaint that those standing at the door of the ladies compartments were not allowing anyone to board. There was an altercation between two groups of women commuters after which those who were standing on the platform went on the tracks to stop the movement of train, the sources added. A video of the incident went viral on social media and brought back memories of January 2015 when Diva had witnessed a flash rail roko which led to violent protests. The commuters had then protested spontaneously after watching several fast trains go by and no train stopping at their station, and said they were being “neglected” as there has been a longstanding demand for locals originating from and terminating at Diva. “Following this protest, we had ensured that fast trains stop at Diva. But now, even after providing the fast train service, there is a new problem of train bullies . Whatever the problem, the women have no right to stop trains,” said a senior official. He added that it is unwarranted as trains are the lifeline for lakhs of daily commuters and if you stop one train, it disturbs the frequency of other trains during peak hour rush. He said that the women could have complained to the railway police or RPF officials or the station master about the trouble, and got the train bullies booked. “Rail roko is completely uncalled for,” he said.

title: Pay hiked fees or leave Dahisar school, protesting parents warned
og_title: Pay hiked fees or leave Dahisar school, protesting parents warned
content: MUMBAI: A group of parents from Rustomjee Troopers, Dahisar, who have been fighting a fee hike for the past one year, alleged the school has issued warning letters asking them to pay the fees or take their children out of school. Last year, parents of class I students had complained to the education department that the school was hiking fees every year by 10%, charging unauthorised fees, forcing them to buy uniforms from a particular vendor and not following procedure while getting approval for fee hikes from the Parent-Teacher Association. "Last week, the school sent us a letter asking us to either pay fees or take the leaving certificate," said a mother. School trustee, Hanif Kanjer, did not respond to calls or email from TOI.

title: Arunachal Dy CM blames Cong for violence during PRC protests
og_title: Arunachal Dy CM blames Cong for violence during PRC protests
content: ITANAGAR: Arunachal Pradesh Deputy Chief minister Chowna Mein on Wednesday alleged that the Congress was the "mastermind" behind the violent protests in the state over granting of Permanent Citizenship Certificate (PRC) to six non-tribal communities in Changlang and Namsai districts. The state capital in February had witnessed large scale violence over the issue, resulting in the loss of three lives, besides causing damage to public and private property. "The PRC is a social issue but the Congress politicised it to gain mileage which did not work. The people of the state have now realised who was the mastermind behind creating the situation," Mein said while addressing an election rally here. "When the properties of BJP leaders were damaged, why not a single property of any Congress leader was under attack during the violence?" Mein asked. The deputy chief minister also alleged that the intention of the Congress was to "dislodge" the BJP government in the state and to come back to power through "evil designs" and by disturbing peace in the state. "People will give a befitting reply to the party this time," Mein added.

title: Thane: Women stage rail roko at Diva station
og_title: Thane: Women stage rail roko at Diva station
content: MUMBAI: Women commuters staged a rail roko on the tracks of Diva station here on Thursday morning after they were denied entry into the crowded compartments. The women complained that people standing at the door of the ladies compartments refused entry to them when the Up fast train arrived at Diva station. There was an altercation among the women commuters after which some of them complained to the motorman and tried to stop the movement of train. The local train was detained from 7.10am to 7.18am. Trains on Central Railway line are operating with delay after the incident.

title: SPPU forms panel to probe mess protest
og_title: SPPU forms panel to probe mess protest
content: PUNE: The Savitribai Phule Pune University has instituted a fact-finding committee to look into the protest against the ‘no meal-sharing policy’ by students. The protest had led to police cases against 12 students. The committee will be headed by R S Mali, the former vice-chancellor of North Maharashtra University . “A person from outside has been chosen so that there is no bias. The other members are management council member Sanjay Chakane, dean of science and technology Arvind Shaligram, senate member Manohar Jadhav, head of law department Durgambini Patel and myself,” said Prabhakar Desai, the director of the board of students welfare. The issue started when the students alleged that they had found worms in the food served in the refectory four times in eight days. The university, however, said that while it may be possible that worms were found, but it was due to a mischievious act by some students with ulterior motives. The VC of the university formed a committee, which gave the controversial recommendation — that students cannot share meals. Till March 31, the students could opt for monthly mess passes and pay Rs32 for a limited thaali, which they could share. On April 1, the new rules kicked in. This led to a scuffle between students and officials. A security guard was injured and 12 students were booked. The SPPU has since relaxed the meal sharing rules. “The committee will consider the FIR and students’ letters. It will submit its report in 15 days,” said Desai.

title: Grant Medical pupils protest 'mental agony'
og_title: Grant Medical pupils protest 'mental agony'
content: MUMBAI: Students of JJ Hospital 's Grant Medical College on Wednesday protested at GMC Gymkhana, Marine Drive, against "harassment and mental agony" by their dean Dr Ajay Chandanwale. The Grant Medical College Students' Association ( GMCSA ) last week complained to the department of medical education and research ( DMER ) which has instituted a panel to inquire the matter. The stand-off between the dean and MBBS students started during the college festival about a week ago, with students protesting against a 'diktat' to girls not to wear short clothes. Girls were reportedly told by teachers not to sit or dance with boys during the festival, said members of GMCSA. "After our protest , the dean sent a letter asking for 14 students to meet him. But why should he single out these students? He should address the association, not individuals," said a student who did not want to be named. Dr Chandanwale was not contactable despite several attempts. DMER director Dr T P Lahane told TOI that the panel's report should be out by April 11 or 12. "The panel will hold interviews on April 8 and 9," he said. In the letter to DMER, the students have listed over a dozen points including "moral policing". "Boys and girls have been told to not talk on the campus grounds as well," said a student. A senior teacher, supportive of students' demands, said, "We should ask students to observe discipline on hospital premises, not dictate so many commands." Another allegation was about "control" of the GMC gymkhana. "The dean is trying to curb our rights....," said a protester. The boys' common room, a property of GMCSA, is illegally occupied by superintendent Dr Sanjay Surase.

title: Teachers’ protest turns violent
og_title: Teachers’ protest turns violent
content: KOLKATA: Several people, including policewomen, were injured on Tuesday after a protest by over 350 government school computer teachers turned violent at Minto Park . One of the injured had to be hospitalized. The teachers, who were appointed through a private firm, staged the protest to demand higher pay. After being denied entry to the firm’s office by lathi-wielding cops, the protesters went to education minister Partha Chatterjee’s residence at Naktala in the evening. According to the protesters and the police, IL&FS Education & Technology Services Limited had secured the tender to provide contractual computer teachers to all government schools in West Bengal and, accordingly, placed the candidates. “The company got Rs 3,49,536 per school annually from the government and paid a salary of Rs 4,500 per month to every teacher,” a protester claimed. Over the past four years, the teachers had been demanding Rs 15,000 — the same as that of their counterparts in other states. On Tuesday, they demanded to know the break-up and profit made by the company from the amount stipulated by the government. Six people, including three women, were detained for the violence.

title: Hit by Maratha & EWS quotas, gen category med students launch protest
og_title: Hit by Maratha & EWS quotas, gen category med students launch protest
content: Nagpur: Graduate doctors aspiring to pursue post graduate courses in medicine from the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) on Tuesday protested the state government’s decision to implement new reservation quotas, leaving very limited seats for general or open category meritorious students. MBBS doctors who have cleared PG-NEET claimed their careers are in serious peril due to the new reservations for Socially and Educationally Backward Classes (SEBC — popularly known as Maratha reservation), and Economically Weaker Sections (EWS) in PG seats. They have sought an appointment with chief minister Devendra Fadnavis to discuss the possible solutions to this issue and their future prospects. “Only 233 seats are available for 2,054 MBBS doctors from open category who have qualified for PG admissions. Even if we add 37 seats in private medical colleges, only 270 seats are available for general category students. This type of implementation will be the end of meritorious students in Maharashtra,” said Dr Sameer Deshmukh, a resident at GMC. The seat matrix declared by the CET Cell says 3,913 candidates have qualified for PG admissions in Maharashtra for 1,441 PG seats. Out of these, 2,024 candidates belong to open category. For them, 233 seats are available in all state-run GMCs. These seats can be claimed by reserved candidates as well. Condition in private medical colleges is even worse. As 16% of SEBC cannot be implemented in management and NRI quota of private colleges, the government has added this number to the state quota, which has increased SEBC quota to nearly 30%, eventually leaving only 37 seats for general category students in private medical colleges. Dr TP Lahane, Director of Medical Education and Research, Maharashtra state, said general category students should go for seats of management quota in private medical colleges. “It’s a fact that only 37 seats are available for general category students in private colleges. We had no option but to implement the reservation as the high court has directed the same. However, we have deliberately kept the management quota and NRI quota out of any reservation. All 215 seats are available for general category students,” he said. However, fees in management and NRI quota is three to five times higher than the state quota seats, so this suggestion has left the protesting students angry. ISSUE AT A GLANCE UNTIL NOW: Reservation limited to 52% in Maharashtra NOW: Reservation rises to 78% after including SEBC and EWS quota EWS Reservation: 10 % EWS reservation introduced in Feb 2019 by central government and hastily implemented in Maharashtra within months, despite assurances from the centre about proportionate (25%) increment in seats soon SEBC reservation: 16% SEBC reservation (Maratha reservation) introduced on November 30, 2018, by state government and implemented in this session. Doctors claim this is against the SEBC Act, which says “new reservation shall not be implemented after commencement of admission procedure, which includes commencement of registration for the entrance exam for admission”. NEET-PG registration began on November 2, 2018, almost a month before SEBC was announced Can MBBS doctor be educationally backward?
