General category students say the MBBS degree in itself a great equalizer and it is unfair to pit one doctor against another on the basis of ‘social and educational backwardness’ Seat position after implementation of SEBC and EWS in GMCs Total seats of PG (MD/MS) of State Quota 972 Total Reserved seats for SC/ST/VJ/NT/OBC (50%) 486 Total reserved seats for SEBC (Maratha Quota) (16%) 156 Total Reserved seats for EWS (10%) 97 Seats available for OPEN category 233 Total students qualified from OPEN category 2024 Seat position after implementation of SEBC and EWS in Private medical colleges Total seats of PG (MD/MS) 469 Seats reserved for Management and NRI quota (35% Management and 15% NRI) 215 Seats available for State Quota 254 Total Reserved seats for SC/ST/VJ/NT/OBC (50%) 117 Total reserved seats for SEBC (Maratha Quota) 75 Total Reserved seats for EWS 25 Seats available for OPEN category 37

title: Gumla students lock down campus to protest faculty crunch
og_title: Gumla students lock down campus to protest faculty crunch
content: GUMLA: Students of Kartik Oraon College in Gumla , which falls under Lohardaga parliamentary constituency, on Monday locked down the campus in protest against acute faculty crunch at th ecollege. Ruing that students in this tribal heartland are unable to pursue their academic aspirations, the protesters demanded that all political parties fielding their candidates must include provisions to improve the education system in the area in their election manifestos. The students started the lockdown around 10am and continued till afternoon. During their protest, the students prevented entry of both teaching and non-teaching staff inside the campus. Those who entered before the protest were not allowed to come out. The students’ union president, Kunal Sharma, said, “We are forced to take this step today as all our earlier pleas to the authorities concerned fell on deaf ears. We want this as an election issue.” The college, affiliated to Ranchi University, has 14,000 students and needs 100 teachers. But barely half the strength exist. The students alleged that notwithstanding the staff crunch, the varsity is arbitrarily transferring existing teachers to Ranchi, creating further problems in their regular classes. Sharma added, “To tackle the manpower crunch, the college appointed contractual tutors but many of them left the job due to non payment or delay in their salaries and lack of job security.” Other students said there posts for biology and mathematics teachers have been vacant for several months. Similarly, there is only teacher for botany while physics and chemistry departments are run by one teacher each. The college’s head of department for chemistry, P K Keshri, admitted that the college is facing staff crunch. He said, “The science faculty is badly hit by the faculty crunch.” Professor of the economics department, Amitabh Bharti, also said, “The college requires 100 teachers but there are only 54 now. Conducting classes is becoming difficult with this strength.” Sources said since 2008, no regular appointments have been made in the college and they have to depend on contractual staff. “No one wants to work in this rural area. Even those who join, leave for greener pastures,” Keshri added. The college’s principal, Jitbahan Baraik, said they had apprised the varsity of the problems long back and have demanded appointment of teaching staff.

title: Farmers block highway, 25 detained
og_title: Farmers block highway, 25 detained
content: Rajkot: About 1,000 farmers of 43 villages of Padadhari taluka in Rajkot district staged a road block on Rajkot-Jamnagar highway, burned tyres and an effigy of the government and held a demonstration on Monday. A total of 25 farmers were detained by the police. The farmers were protesting against the non-implementation of crop insurance scheme in Padadhari taluka and no supply of drinking water and fodder to the taluka after declaring it scarcity hit.

title: ‘Failed’ Intermediate students stage protest, raise slogans
og_title: ‘Failed’ Intermediate students stage protest, raise slogans
content: PATNA: As many as 100 candidates, who have failed in their Intermediate exams, staged a protest outside the Bihar School Examination Board’s (BSEB) office on Monday. They also raised slogans against board chairman Anand Kishor. The results of the Inter exams were announced on Saturday. While many protesters claimed they were given negative marks in theory papers, others pointed out errors in the tabulation of marks. Shashi Kumar Suman from Purnia told this newspaper, “I had taken all the exams, but my mathematics score was missing from my marksheet.” Junaid Khan from Saran was equally disappointed. He said, “I scored 59 in physics , 70 in chemistry, 42 in biology , 58 in English and 62 in NRB Hindi-MB English. However, my results state that I have failed in the Inter exams.” Another candidate Adarsh Kumar Azad, a student of B D College-Patna, was allotted negative marks in Hindi, physics and chemistry. “I got -1 in three papers. How is that possible?” he asked. When BSEB officials verified the marksheets of some students, it was found that they were different from those available on the board’s official website. Kishor told this newspaper, “The protesters must have downloaded their results from fake websites. We have already told students to visit www.biharboardonline.in, www.biharboardonline.gov.in and www.bsebinteredu.in for results. The BSEB head recalled an incident when a student, who had downloaded his marksheet from a fake website, got 260 marks out of 500. “As per our official website, he had secured 405 marks,” Kishor said. Scrutiny of papers begins tomorrow: BSEB chairman Anand Kishor on Monday asked the students, who were unsatisfied with their results, to apply for scrutiny. The online process for scrutiny can be checked on www.bsebinteredu.in from April 3 to 12. “Those, who have failed in one or two papers, can register for compartment exam. Forms for the purpose will be available on our website from April 5 to 10,” Kishor said.

title: Roshanpura locals protest liquor vend
og_title: Roshanpura locals protest liquor vend
content: BHOPAL: Residents of Roshanpura , mostly women, on Monday protested the opening of a liquor shop in the neighbourhood. They threatened to abstain from voting in the upcoming general elections if the decision was not reversed. Over 200 locals gathered from early morning at the new liquor establishment at Malviya Nagar. Printouts stating -'No voting if the liquor shop opens' - were stuck on shops in the area by the protesters. They also stuck the posters on some autorickshaws parked there. "Location of the liquor shop has been declared by the district administration. We identified this location (at Roshanpura) by the interior furnishings work being conducted. There is a school nearby. Besides, the Durga Puja pandal is placed at this very spot where the liquor shop is to open. It is an unacceptable situation," said former corporator, Waheed Laskari. The location allotted to the store is about 500 metres from the current location, he added. By 8 am, elected representatives from both the Congress and BJP came out in support of the women. Congress corporator from nearby ward (Shymala Hills area) Sabista Zaki said, "No liquor store can be at 500-metres of a densely populated residential area. The main road traffic would be affected and also lead to a law and order issue." When asked how the ruling party allowed such a move in the first place, local Congress leader Asif Zaki replied that the government had only permitted the tendering process; locations had to be decided later. From April 1, new excise allocations come into effect. Alka, a resident of the area, was furious with the idea of a liquor store in the vicinity. "The ease of access would mean that slumdwellers would consume more alcohol. It would impact our families and children," she said. Area SDM Sanjay Shrivastava, who reached the spot, assured that the location had not been decided. "The process of allocation of excise permits is still on-going," he said. Roshanpura has a densely populated slum. The votebank is crucial for candidates in the upcoming elections, said a local leader. Sources said that local MLA and state minister, PC Sharma, has stated that the matter would be reviewed. Protesters have also lodged a complaint in this regard with the state election commissioner.

title: Noida: Kin of two killed in accident block road
og_title: Noida: Kin of two killed in accident block road
content: NOIDA: After the accident near Chalera that killed two men on Saturday, their families blocked Maharaja Agrasen Marg to protest police inaction causing a jam on the road Monday. The wives of the two deceased men laid down on the road and demanded that the police arrest the accused and share his name with them. Police later shared the name of the accused, Sumit Bhargava, a resident of D block, Sector 50, and assured them of due action. Krishna Tiwari (33) and his father-in-law Amir Mishra (55) were walking towards Sector 37 when a silver WagonR (DL3CBL1901) crushed the duo near Chalera area on Saturday afternoon. According to the FIR, the driver of the car was drunk. He allegedly fled the spot while the WagonR was seized by police. While Amir died at the Prayag hospital on Sunday, his son-in-law Krishna was shifted to the ESIC hospital on Sunday. “As the ESIC hospital did not have all the facilities for better treatment, they shifted Krishna to the Prakash Hospital, Sector 33 where he expired around 11 am on Monday,” said Ramesh, one of the protesters. Around 5 pm, protestors gathered at the Maharaja Agrasen intersection blocking traffic alleging that the police forcefully tried to transport the body from the hospital to the Sector 94 mortuary. Krishna’s wife Jhankoorpa Devi, along her mother, blocked the road and alleged that the police were hiding the accused. They refused to get up till the police share the name of the accused with them.

title: SPPU students stage protest against no sharing of thali rule in refectory
og_title: SPPU students stage protest against no sharing of thali rule in refectory
content: PUNE: Students pursuing various courses at the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) held an agitation on the campus on Monday to protest against ‘no sharing of thali’ policy introduced at the refectory. A protesting student said the limited meal came for Rs 32 and contained four chapatis, rice, two curries and one sookhi sabji. “Since it is a limited thali, we do not get any extra serving. I wonder what is bothering the university if we share the food among friends. The university regulation means either we finish the food or throw it as sharing is prohibited. I wonder what’s the logic behind the move,” he said. Another student opposed the discontinuation of guest ‘thali’ facility at the refectory. “Earlier, students who did not wish to enrol for monthly mess facility could pay Rs 40 for a meal at the refectory. Now, that facility has also been discontinued,” he said. The students also opposed the removal of television from the mess. “The authorities have removed the television and put a radio instead in the mess. This radio is being used to force us to hear programmes like ‘Man ki Baat’ with the university vice-chancellor. This is an university and we have every right to watch the news,” a student said. A glass frame on the refectory door broke during the agitation. When asked about it, a students said, “It broken during a scuffle between the security guards and students. Blaming just the students is wrong. It was just a student agitation against the dictatorial policies of the vice-chancellor.” A statement issued by the assistant registrar of SPPU Rajesh Raherkar stated that 850 students were enrolled for monthly mess facility, which was way more than the capacity of 750 members. “Hence, from April 1, it was decided to serve the mess facility only to regular subscribers of the mess facility at the refractory for convenience of the students,” it read. Following the protest by the students, the university issued a statement stating that only the students who have enrolled for the mess facility would be served food at the refectory. “Rest of the students can have food at the hostel buildings number 8 and 9. Women students can utilise the facility at their hostels apart from the three canteens located within the campus. The decision has been taken to provide good services to the students and they must cooperate. If there are any objections, the students must submit them formally to the food committee,” the statement read. The city unit president of the Maharashtra Navnirman Vidyarthi Sena, Kalpesh Yadav, said the guidelines issued for the refractory should be revoked immediately. “The union will wait for four days. If the university failed to act, we would stage a protest against the rules,” Yadav said. Senior inspector Bhaskar Jadhav on Chatushrungi police station told TOI, “We have booked 12 students of the university for physically abusing the security guard on the university premises.”

title: Parents launch hunger strike to protest Timpany school fee hike
og_title: Parents launch hunger strike to protest Timpany school fee hike
content: Visakhapatnam: Parents of children studying in Timpany School protested against the school management hiking fees by 30 to 40 per cent here in Visakhapatnam city on Monday. Over 10 parents launched an indefinite hunger strike demanding the management roll back its decision. It may be recalled that some days back, the parents had staged a protest against the school management for forcing them to buy books, stationery, uniform and shoes from the school premises at high prices. With this latest protest, Timpany School is again in the news for increasing its fees. Parents were unhappy as there has been no consent from the Parent-Teachers Association before implementing the hike. Though the management assured that it would roll back the increased fee by Friday, it had ignored their promise, said Manmohan Pasari, one of the parents. The agitating parents said the management needed to abide by the guidelines laid down by the ICSE and CBSE boards. Instability in taking a decision and the exorbitant fee hike would hit the future of thousands of students hard, they added. In an appeal to the district collector, the parents requested he address the issue and also control the management. The parents also requested the Board of Education to take action against the management of the school for fleecing the parents. The hunger strike would be continued until the management rolled back its decision, the parents said.

title: Maoists call for bandh in Bihar on Tuesday to protest PM's Gaya visit
og_title: Maoists call for bandh in Bihar on Tuesday to protest PM's Gaya visit
content: RANCHI: The Bihar Regional Committee (BRC) of CPI Maoists has called a 24 hour bandh in Magadh zone of Bihar beginning Monday midnight. The bandh has been announced to protest the proposed Gaya visit of Prime Minister Narendra Modi in connection with the upcoming parliamentary election. Describing the BJP-led government and Centre as RSS backed communal dispensation of imperialist rulers the Maoists have expressed strong resentment to the incidents of mob lynching in the name of cow protection. Spokesperson of the BRC, Manas told TOI that they have already punished one of the BJP leaders, former MLC Anuj Singh by blowing up his house in Bodhibigha village under Dumaria PS of Gaya district on March 27. "Singh represents the oppressor ruling class and highly communal mindset of the RSS brigade which has targetted people of religious minority groups including the Muslims and Christians and our action against him will not remain limited to blowing up his house. In the days to come our party along with armed villagers will confiscate his movable and immovable property to distribute it among the villagers," he said. The Maoists have described action against Singh as a token of protest against the "fascist rulers '. Manas said that BJP at Centre has been fooling people in the name of conducting peaceful elections. " There were a series of attacks on revolutionary forces in Kashmir, Manipur and Assam ever since the government was voted to power but the attacks increased in every form since 2018 when the government launched its secretive mission Samadhan, aiming to mute all voices of rebellion by 2022," a letter issued by the BRC read. Manas said the so called idea of peaceful parliamentary election for 17th Lok Sabha is a farce because if the government was so convinced of peoples voluntary participation it wouldn't have deployed CRPF and other armed para military forces. "These deployments are meant to pull out people from their homes to force them on gun point to cast vote whereas public in general are tired of the system and are voluntarily standing with us to support our call for poll boycott," Manas added. The Maoists have said that the Modi government will bear the brunt of bloodbath if the para military forces use undue methods to pull out people for participating in the electoral process.

title: Residents protest lack of doorstep waste collection
og_title: Residents protest lack of doorstep waste collection
content: BENGALURU: Residents of Munnekolala near Marathahalli on Sunday descended near the railway line, which cuts through their locality, demanding the Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) put in place a better garage disposal system. The protest site was chosen by residents to highlight all that ails the solid waste management system in their locality; the area around the railway line has become an illegal dump yard. On Sunday, too, people kept coming in bikes and cars to dump garbage near the railway line, even as the demonstration was under way. "It was shocking to see people carry bags of garbage on two-wheelers and cars and throw them here. When questioned, some of them complained of lack of garbage disposal facilities,"said Prem Nath, a resident of Munnekolala. The protest was preceded by a vigil residents kept at the site for three consecutive nights, during which they found that people from restaurants, hotels and other food joints dumped garbage on the tracks. Residents said the biggest problem was absence of garbage collection in the area. Shamir, a resident, said BBMP does not send its vehicles to lift garbage from doorsteps and other establishments, forcing people to store it indoors. "The concept of door-to-door garbage collection is missing and we have no choice but to throw garbage outside," he added. The problem is acute on 6th and 7th Cross of Munnekolala, where residents have begun throwing garbage in open areas. "Lack of a proper disposal system is forcing me to throw garbage in open areas. If I don't do so, garbage piles up inside my house and it starts stinking," said Preethi K, a resident of Munnekolala. The residents have now formed a group - Protest against Garbage - to lobby for a solution to the menace. On March 24, they had staged a similar protest at the railway line. The BBMP promptly cleaned up the area, but soon garbage was back on the tracks. "We want the BBMP to come with up a permanent solution and also ensure door-to-door collection," said Sunand K, another resident. BBMP's AEE (SWM) Mamatha MS said they have initiated action against illegal garbage dumping and have also been asking the local health officer to check the place frequently. She asserted the problem will be resolved in three days.

title: Shukla is CIC, Murthy IC, administered oath
og_title: Shukla is CIC, Murthy IC, administered oath
content: BHOPAL: Governor Anandiben Patel administered oath of office of chief information commissioner to Arvind Kumar Shukla at Rajbhavan on Saturday. The governor also administered the oath of office of information commissioners to Golla Krishna Murhty and Rahul Singh. Principal secretary general administration department Vinod Semwal conducted the oath-taking ceremony. High court Justice VPS Chouhan, Lokayukta and former Justice Naresh Gupta, member of Rajya Sabha Vivek Tankha, deputy Lokayukta, information commissioner, additional chief secretary public relations M Gopal Reddy, senior officers of police and administration, were also present. Three days ahead of the scheduled swearing-in of the chief information commissioner (CIC) and two information commissioners (ICs), a single-judge bench of MP high court had issued notices to the state government and others on Wednesday in response to a petition challenging the appointments. RTI activist from Mandsaur , Rupali Dubey, in her petition alleged that guidelines laid down for selection of CICs and ICs were not followed while appointing the CIC and two ICs in MP.

title: Thevar outfit members stage protest mid-air, held
og_title: Thevar outfit members stage protest mid-air, held
content: MADURAI: A group of members from the Bharatiya Forward Bloc, who have been demanding to rename the Madurai airport after Pasumpon Muthuramalinga Thevar took their protest to the sky, as they staged a protest on board a flight bound for Madurai from Chennai on Saturday. President of the party K A Murugan alias Murunganji along with seven functionaries staged a protest on board the IndiGo flight minutes after it took off from the Chennai airport. They raised slogans urging the state and the central governments to rename the Madurai airport after Thevar, a demand which has been put forth by various political and communal outfits for some time now. The protesters left their seats and gathered on the aisle of the flight, and shouted their demands. Many of the fellow passengers were taken aback by the unexpected event. A police team was mobilized at the Madurai airport, where the protesters were arrested on getting off the plane. A team led by Madurai district superintendent of police N Manivannan produced them before a judicial magistrate and lodged them in prison. The Perungudi police registered a case against them under various Sections of the IPC including 147- rioting, 290- public nuisance, 341- wrongful restraint, 342- wrongful confinement and 153 (a) wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot. Muruganji had made a video about the protest on board minutes before reaching the airport.

title: 500 to run protest marathon today
og_title: 500 to run protest marathon today
content: BENGALURU: Around 500 residents of apartment complexes in Rayasandra, 5km from Electronics City , decided to stage a ‘healthy’ protest, demanding better amenities in their locality: They are holding a marathon on Saturday. Residents said they will kick off the protest with yoga and zumba at 5.30am, followed by a marathon (3K, 5K and 1K for kids). At 8am, they will form a human chain with placards, urging the authorities to repair Adi Kavi Pampa Road in Rayasandra, ensure proper garbage clearance and prevent power fluctuations. “We tried meeting the authorities, including the MLA. But that didn’t solve our woes. So we chose to hold a healthy protest,” residents said.

title: Protest as Airports Authority of India eases norms
og_title: Protest as Airports Authority of India eases norms
content: MUMBAI: An Airports Authority of India (AAI) assistant general manager is on a fast-unto-death outside civil aviation Delhi headquarters at Rajiv Gandhi Bhavan since Friday. Yogendra Gautam, general secretary of the union that represents AAI officers, is protesting against the management's decision to recruit engineers with no experience in aviation-related fields to the post of general manager.

title: Congress has made graft a cause: Arun Jaitley on Karnataka protests
og_title: Congress has made graft a cause: Arun Jaitley on Karnataka protests
content: NEW DELHI: Finance minister Arun Jaitley hit out at Congress on Saturday saying it had made " corruption a cause" by protesting with the Janata Dal (Secular) outside the income tax office in Bengaluru and termed it a "transparent self-goal". Chief minister of Karnataka HD Kumaraswamy, some of his cabinet colleagues and senior leaders of Congress had protested against income tax searches with a "political motivation" and alleged that ministers had been searched. "The best evidence they could provide for was that the 'nephew' of a minister was searched. In an unprecedented move the CM and ministers of the state decided to join the protest," Jaitley said, adding that the tax department had said no MP, MLA or minister was searched. The finance minister said the search was only against contractors and engineers of the PWD department. "If no minister has been searched, then why the protest?" Jaitley said in a blog. The finance minister said the incident illustrates a textbook method of the UPA on two fronts: use government money, round trip it through contractors and beneficiaries and enrich yourselves. "The second is lip sympathy for federalism and destroy it whenever the opportunity arises," Jaitley said. He said the disproportionality of the reaction of Congress and JD(S) raises suspicion. "Why the CM and ministers should be seen raising slogans on the streets when corrupt contractors and engineers are being searched?" Jaitley asked.

title: Sitaram Yechury protests EC ruling over PM’s ‘Mission Shakti’ address
og_title: Sitaram Yechury protests EC ruling over PM’s ‘Mission Shakti’ address
content: NEW DELHI: A day after the Election Commission ruled that PM Modi’s national address on “Mission Shakti" was not in violation of the model code of conduct, CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury has written back to the commission and dubbed its decision a “narrow interpretation” of his complaint. The CPM leader said Modi's address to announce a feat achieved by scientists during the election campaign was a “gross misuse” of the PM’s office and added that the EC “had confined itself exclusively to the issue of “misuse of official media”. The CPM chief also sought a similar leeway for speeches made by leaders from other national parties, saying that if Modi’s speech was not in violation of the model code, the commission should direct “official media to treat speeches and statements made by leaders of recognised national parties in a similar manner as they treated the Prime Minister's speech”. “Soon after the speech, the PM is on record to claim that he is a ' chowkidar ' not only on land and air but also in outer space . The PM and other leaders of the BJP are actively campaigning saying that this government has shown guts which previous governments did not,” Yechury wrote, pointing out the “larger issue” is that the PM is a candidate in the ensuing election and is using the office of the Prime Minister for “furthering electoral objectives”. “What else does this mean but a gross misuse of the office of the Prime Minister for seeking electoral gains. An announcement of this nature is normally done by senior officers of the establishment like the DRDO Director. That the Prime Minister chose to announce it himself constitutes a gross violation of the Model Code of Conduct,” he said.

title: Jaitley criticises JD(S), Congress for protest against I-T searches
og_title: Jaitley criticises JD(S), Congress for protest against I-T searches
content: NEW DELHI: Finance minister Arun Jaitley on Saturday criticised JD(S) and Congress leaders for organising a protest outside the Income Tax Office at Bengaluru for conducting searches on PWD contractors and engineers. Stating that the disproportionality of the reaction of the Congress and the JDS raises a needle of suspicion, Jaitley said "If no politician has been searched, no minister has been searched, then why the protest?" "The Bengaluru case is a text book method of the UPA on 2 fronts: use government money, round trip it through contractors and beneficiaries to enrich themselves and then lip sympathy for federalism destroying it whenever the opportunity arises. This is a very transparent self goal," Jaitley said in his blog titled 'The UPA makes corruption a cause'. Led by Karnataka chief minister HD Kumaraswamy, the Congress-JD(S) ruling combine organised a protest in front of the Income Tax department at Bengaluru on Thursday against a statewide crackdown on his partymen and others. Jaitley said that it was unprecedented that the chief minister of a state joined the street protest against income tax searches with a political motivation. "The disproportionality of the reaction of the Congress and the JDS raises a needle of suspicion. Was the minister's nephew a PWD contractor to whom largesses have been given – a case of nepotism? The CM and the ministers who joined the protest need to answer these questions," Jaitley said. Even as the JDS and Congress leaders in the state alleged that ministers had been searched, the best evidence they could provide for was that the ‘nephew' of a minister was searched, Jaitley said, adding that even the tax authorities have issued a statement saying that no MP, MLA or minister was searched. Questioning whether states' attitude is threat to federalism, Jaitley said federalism is not merely the rights of the states. Indian federalism entails India as a “union of states”. "The rights of the union are equally important. Security of India, sovereignty, dealing with terrorism, managing the borders, custom check points, income tax enforcement are all amongst the several constitutional powers of the union. "If the states stand in way of any of them it is guilty of breaching federal norms. Can a state barge its police into the customs area and direct the customs as to what is to be done? This would be a threat to federalism," he said. Jaitley said many states have stopped giving police security to income tax authorities when they conduct their operations. "Alternatively, when state police is asked for, the information is leaked out to the political government and it reaches the targets of the operations. Tax authorities increasingly have to rely on central forces. In the Kashmir valley recently, searches were conducted under the governor's rule after 17 years. These taxes are meant for the welfare of the poor in India," he added.

title: Maoists urge villagers to boycott election to protest ‘militarisation’
og_title: Maoists urge villagers to boycott election to protest ‘militarisation’
content: RANCHI: The CPI ( Maoist )’s Jharkhand Regional Committee (JRC) has appealed to the people, especially in rural and mineral-rich pockets of the state, to boycott the parliamentary polls in protest against “indiscriminate militarisation and high-handedness of security forces”. Responding to the poll boycott call issued by the Maoists’s Bihar Jharkhand Special Area Committee (BJSAC) — the highest strategic unit of the outlawed rebel outfit at the state level — earlier this week, JRC spokesperson Aman told TOI this was perhaps the last option for the villagers to protest against “militarisation”. He said: “Otherwise, they will be pushed out of their own land and the government will hand over all natural and mineral assets to capitalists and industrialists in the days to come.” The Maoists have drawn attention of the people to Mission Samadhan — a common government scheme in the tribal belts of Chhattisgarh, Bihar, Odisha, Maharashtra , Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, West Bengal, Madhya Pradesh and Jharkhand. “This mission is not aimed at providing solution to issues like irrigation, education, health facilities or equal distribution of resources. Instead, the samadhan (solution) is being offered to the industrial houses as to how they can grab mineral wealth under protection of the security forces,” Aman said. He also criticised the idea of pitching the country’s armed forces against its own people on the pretext of containing ‘biggest internal threat’. Aman said: “Maoists are never a threat for the common people who are already being subjected to repression and exploitation. Rather, we are threat to the exploiting ruling classes and the extortionist system.” Aman said there is a huge difference between the lifestyle of the rural poor of Jharkhand living in mineral-rich districts and the general elite urban classes working for the capitalist masters. “The villagers are coerced by gun-toting security forces, stopped from raising their voice against exploitation and often manhandled if they try to protect their rights over land, water and forest. This is gradually leading rural Jharkhand towards complete militarisation where democracy has become a farce,” he said. Asking the people to boycott the Lok Sabha elections, the Maoists shared a few anecdotes as to how governance in the mineral-rich belts has been passed on to the industrialists on the behest of the security forces. “On the pretext of industrial security and development, village after village is being targeted where either the locals are forcefully evicted from their land or entangled in false cases and sedition charges after being branded as Maoists. This is eventually forcing the young populace to migrate and opening the villages for exploitation,” he said. JRC, which has also decided to carry out an extensive poster campaign and interpersonal communication in areas where dozens of security camps have come up in the last five years, has asked the people to realize what future they are going to make for themselves if they continue to elect “imperialist governments” in the name of democracy. “People should not lose hope and aim towards formation of a pro-people neo-democracy by joining hands together in the fight for a revolutionary people’s government,” Aman said.

title: Kolhapur citizens protest poor water supply
og_title: Kolhapur citizens protest poor water supply
content: KOLHAPUR: Citizens from Ravivar Peth staged an agitation at Subhash Road on Monday to protest against the inadequate water supply and seeking changes in the supply schedule. Traffic along Gokhale College , Madhuri Bakery , Tembe Road and Khasbaug Maidan was paralysed for over half-an-hour as the citizens had blocked the road. Citizens claimed that the area was receiving water at low pressure and the odd times at which the water was being supplied was putting them at an inconvenience. The citizens further claimed that the problem has been reported for the first time in the summer season. The protest was called off after in-charge of water supply department Suresh Kulkarni visited the agitation spot and assured the protestors that the timings of water supply would to changed so that citizens receive adequate water. Citizens from the nearby Mangalwar Peth had protested last month for the same reason. A citizen participating in the protest said, "A few days ago, the taps received water at seven in the morning. Now, the water is being supplied in the afternoon and that too for half an hour. We want the timings to be changed since women have to face a lot of trouble due to the shortage and discrepancies in the timing of water supply." Local corporators too thronged the spot and pulled up the civic administration for poor management of water supply. Responsing to the concerns of the citizens, Kulkarni said that the water supply was inadequate due to technical glitches at Balinga pumping house. Assuring that the water supply would regain normalcy from Sunday, Kulkarni said that if citizens still complained about shortage of water, then the supply timings would be changed. He further added that officials of the water supply department would keep a close tab on the supply conditions in the internal and old parts of the city since the same problem has been reported twice in the last one month. Local corporator Sachin Patil and former corporator Vinayak Phalke claimed that they had informed the water supply department about the need for changing the timing of the water supply and inadequate shortage.

title: Action council to strengthen protests
og_title: Action council to strengthen protests
content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: As the second phase of Kazhakkoottam-Karode NH widening works is progressing, residents of Plavila have objected to digging up of a road in the region for the works. The Kazhakkoottam-Karode Bypass action council has decided to strengthen their protests for construction of an overbridge at Plavila, which can provide connectivity between Marappalam and Nellimoodu. As works continue to progress for the Kazhakootam-Karode bypass project, several restrictions are imposed at Plavila and neighbouring locality, which has made life very difficult for the residents. The works came to an abrupt stop after residents demanded NHAI to approve overbridge at Plavila before digging up the road to make way for the bypass. Residents said that they have requested the same to public works minister G Sudhakaran, district collector K Vasuki and National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) regional director over three years ago. Raveendran Tripthi of Plavila said that the bridge could save them crucial time and energy. “There are around three markets, four temples and multiple educational institutions that will become difficult to access if the bridge is not constructed. We will have to go all the way towards Vengapotta, which is 2.5km away, to cross the bypass and further travel another 2km to reach Nellimoodu. If the bridge comes, the same destinations can be reached by travelling 500 metres,” Tripthi said. According to Sherin M S, another resident of Plavila, the road which was used by multiple school buses is used by lots of students and residents. “All of us will be affected if the bridge does not come up and if construction begins for the bypass,” he said. According to action council secretary S Mani Rao , the council demands immediate construction of the bridge. “If the road gets dug up and the bridge does not come, we will be forced to travel a lengthy route to reach the other side. The bypass is supposed to cut through Kinattadi-Thazhankaadu Road which was constructed as part of Pradhan Manthri Sadak Yojana. This means, connectivity between Marapallam and Nellimoodu will be affected. We will protest until the demand for the overbridge is met,” Rao said.

title: Poor water supply: Locals from Cidco nodes protest
og_title: Poor water supply: Locals from Cidco nodes protest
content: NAVI MUMBAI: Enraged residents of New Panvel gathered near the Cidco water tank premises, Sector 3 demanding regular water supply in the node. Erratic water supply after the festival of Holi has added to their woes and this they claimed is an unending issue. This was the fourth such protest by the residents in the past six months after Cidco failed to give any satisfactory response about the issue. Cidco officials said that the supply was disrupted as Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran (MJP) took up repair work in its pipeline early this week. Owing to this, they claimed that the water pressure was slowly building up in the tail-end areas and that it may take a day or two for the supply to get streamlined. The neighbouring Kalamboli and Karanjade nodes, too, have been facing water crisis. The dilapidated MJP pipeline has been the major reason of erratic supply in Cidco-developed nodes. Protesters demanded immediate restoration of supply in some areas, which are bearing the non-supply slots for the past few days. They have threatened to come back in larger numbers to put pressure on authorities for their fundamental rights of getting a basic amenity like water. G J Dalal, Cidco executive engineer, water supply, said, “The problem started from Holi when MJP enforced a shutdown to repair the ruptured pipeline coming from Patalganga. It was followed by the Tata Power weekly off on Sunday when it does not release the river water leading to no supply of water. In this case it takes two to three days for the pressure to build up in the empty pipeline for full supply. Most of the areas have started getting good supply and remaining parts will get their quota soon.” Apoorva Prabhu, who led the delegation, said, “We have been facing water scarcity from last September and more severely in the past 20 days. Cidco has been giving the same explanations every time we protest and passes the buck to other agencies. We are asking for at least two hours of supply daily.” “We are working on some modalities as the MJP supply line is over three decades old. We are in the process of repairing the storage tank in Sector 3,” said Rahul Sarode, Cidco deputy engineer. Surendra Dashore, MJP sub-divisional engineer said that the damaged pipelines are being replaced part by part.

title: Villagers of Subrahmanya defer protest over demands
og_title: Villagers of Subrahmanya defer protest over demands
content: MANGALURU: The Lok Sabha poll is a blessing in disguise for residents of Subrahmanya and surrounding villages. Even as residents of Subrahmanya and surrounding villages in Sullia taluk were all set to stage a protest against poor network of BSNL and frequent interruptions in power supply, officials on poll mode rushed to address their grievances. People residing in Kukke temple area, Guthigaru, Panja, Madappady, Devachalla, Kandrappady, Yenekallu, Balpa, Kamila, Beedigudde, Valalambe, Nadugallu, Devaruliya, Bilinele, Kaikamba, Mettinadka, Harihara, Kollamogru, Balagodu, Ainakidu, Kalmakaru, Karangallu and Mullubagilu had decided to hold a novel protest by begging on the streets of Kukke temple town on Friday. They had also planned a protest in front of the Mescom office for power supply. Villagers had already distributed handbills requesting people to participate in the protests that scheduled for 10.30am on Friday. “With no regular power supply and because of weak or no signals, we have not been able to make calls over phone. A large number of students, farmers, merchants and women face difficulties. After we planned the protests, the officials promised us to look into our demands. Hence, we have decided to postpone the protests,” a villager said. When contacted, Sullia tahsildar Kunhi Ahamed N A told TOI that the villagers have been requested not to hold protests when the model code of conduct is in force. “We have convened a meeting of villagers, officials of Mescom and BSNL on Friday. We will listen to the grievances of villagers and discuss the issues with the officials. Efforts will be made to solve some of the issues immediately and initiatives will be taken to address all their grievances (over time). Based on our request, they decided not to hold protest on Friday,” the tahsildar said.

title: Independent candidate stages protest as nomination rejected
og_title: Independent candidate stages protest as nomination rejected
content: TIRUPUR: An 42-year-old independent candidate staged a sit-in protest after his nomination was rejected in Tamil Nadu's Tirupur on Friday. R Selvaramalingam, a former Indian Air Force employee from Edappadi in Salem district, had filed nomination from Tirupur in the Lok Sabha elections. The election officials told him that he did not mention from which university he graduated, and that was main reason for rejection. But Selvaramalingam has staged protest at Tirupur collectorate condemning the election officials. He alleged that "When I reached the collectorate around 10.30am on March 25 to file nominations, the officials delayed in receiving the papers. If I was allowed, I would have mentioned the required details in the papers before submitting them. It was discrimination from the officials, because in many constituencies, the candidates had extra time."

title: Protesting farmers rounded up
og_title: Protesting farmers rounded up
content: Chandigarh: To ensure no untoward incident took place, police on Saturday took farmers into custody who had come to show black flags to chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar during his road show. According to information, a group of farmers from Raiya village of Jhajjar had assembled near the venue where CM was scheduled to arrive. On noticing them, police took the farmers into custody. “Initially, we were not told the reason (for being rounded up), but we were released after the programme. Anyhow, such incidents will be a detterent for us. Farmers are already on the warpath,” said Shamsher Singh, a farmer leader. Farmers in Raiya village have been on protest for 90 days to oppose a township planned in Jhajjar.

title: Congress-JD(S) protest brings traffic to standstill in Bengaluru CBD
og_title: Congress-JD(S) protest brings traffic to standstill in Bengaluru CBD
content: BENGALURU: The pre-dawn I-T raids triggered a protest by Congress and JD(S) activists outside the income tax department’s office at Queens Road, causing huge traffic snarls in the surrounding areas for over three hours. With vehicles piling up on Raj Bhavan Road , Ambedkar Veedhi, Palace Road, Queens Road and adjacent roads from 3.30pm to 5.30pm, traffic police deployed additional personnel to handle the situation. Police blocked Coffee Board signal at Infantry Road, preventing the movement of vehicles towards Shivajinagar, Minsk Square and Balekundri Circle. The measure affected vehicular movement towards MG Road and Ulsoor. The traffic was diverted towards Shivajinagar through Balekundri Circle. A private firm employee, who was stranded on his bike near Indira Gandhi musical fountain, said that it took him more than 30 minutes to travel a kilometer from Basaveshwara Circle. “We deployed more than 500 traffic policemen on roads and junctions near the IT office to ensure smooth movement of traffic. The traffic movement became normal only by 6pm,” a senior traffic police officer said. Nine agitators detained More than 1,000 policemen were deployed at the I-T office. Police started detaining agitators around 5pm when they tried entering the I-T office premises. A few of them attempted to blacken the office signboards. “We did not allow anyone to blacken the signboard and immediately took them into custody and put them in a bus,” a police officer said. Seemanth Kumar Singh, additional commissioner of police (East), said the protest was peaceful. “We detained nine agitators as a preventive measure and released them later in the evening,” the officer said.

title: Police detain lawyers who were set to protest at PM's rally in Meerut
og_title: Police detain lawyers who were set to protest at PM's rally in Meerut
content: MEERUT: West UP lawyers who were set to protest at PM Modi’s rally for their pending demand of High Court bench here were stopped from going to the venue and detained by police on Thursday morning. The lawyers who had placards of ‘We want HC bench’ were stalled from going to the venue. After a dramatic stand-off between the lawyers and the police, the lawyers were let off only after Modi 's rally got over. The lawyers showed 'disappointment' over not being able to protest in a democratic country Devki Nandan Sharma, convenor, central action committee for HC bench, said, “We live in a democratic country and even then we were not allowed to peacefully protest at PM Modi’s rally. If we have certain demands, where are we supposed to go with them, if we cannot even go to our leaders?” The lawyers who had gathered at Kutchery road at 10am, moved further to PL Sharma road after removing police barriers and reached Begampul – from where they were not allowed to go to the rally spot. They were detained at 11am and left only at 1:30pm – the time by which PM Modi had already left the city. “Though we did not get the chance to protest at the rally venue, but this doesn’t mean that our demands will not find a way to reach the higher ups. We will utilise the opportunity of the elections and continue our protest for other rallies too,” said Sharma. The lawyers from Western UP had planned to protest at PM Modi’s rally venue to put forward their long pending demand of a HC bench in West UP.

title: Denial of ticket: Ballia BJP MP supporters continue protest
og_title: Denial of ticket: Ballia BJP MP supporters continue protest
content: VARANASI: BJP’s lotus (party symbol), which bloomed for the first time in Ballia in 2014, seems to be in troubled waters in 2019 as the supporters of incumbent MP Bharat Singh are on a warpath after he was denied ticket for the parliamentary election and continued their protest on the second day on Thursday. Party leaders, however, claim that the issue would be sorted out soon. Singh has been replaced by Bhadohi MP Virendra Singh in Ballia for Lok Sabha polls. Slogans like ‘Virendra Singh vapas jao’ (Virendra Singh go back) and ’BJP se Bharat Singh nahi to koi nahi’ (Bharat Singh or no one else) raised by his supporters. However, BJP senior leaders take it casually claiming that the protest would not damage party’s prospect and things would be managed. BJP men took out a procession from the premises of Ballia Zila Panchayat to the party office, where they sat on dharna. Raising slogans against Virendra Singh, they demanded from the central leadership to withdraw its decision of fielding Virendra Singh from Ballia Lok Sabha seat. “We are shocked after knowing the decision of the ‘kendriya netritva’ (central leadership) to field Virendra Singh from Ballia in place of Bharat Singh,” said the latter’s supporter Ashok Singh. “The decision would prove costly to the party in Ballia in the parliamentary poll,” he warned adding that the party workers would not accept Virendra Singh in Ballia as he had done nothing for the district. Some of them also burnt the effigy of Virendra Singh as mark of protest. However, BJP state general secretary Salil Vishnoi claimed that “it is a momentary upheaval that would be calmed efficiently”. “Such protest is natural when someone is denied ticket, but it would not harm party’s prospect in the polls,” he told TOI over phone on Thursday. In 2014 LS poll, Bharat Singh had defeated two-time SP MP Neeraj Shekhar by a margin of about 1.39 lakh votes. Ballia had been represented by former Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar for eight times since 1977 to 2004, except 1984 when Jagannath Chowdhary of the Congress won. The seat went to Chandra Shekhar’s son Neeraj Shekhar, who contested on SP ticket and won in 2007 and 2009.

title: Parents protest 15% school fee hike
og_title: Parents protest 15% school fee hike
content: NOIDA: As many as 250 parents of children studying in Genesis Global School (GGS) have complained against the institution for introducing new categories in its existing fee structure, including ‘imprest’ payment and an ‘additional’ security deposit. The parents claimed that the school had increased the basic fees by 7-8% but the annual fees had increased by 15% due to these new categories. On Thursday, parents approached the district inspector of schools and the issue was taken up by the All Noida School Parents Association (ANSPA) for discussion at the next meeting of the district fee regulation committee. “We were sent a notice by the school, informing us about fee hike , 10 days ago, and the fee due date is March 30. We wrote to the school, demanding that it follow the Uttar Pradesh Fee Regulation Act (UPFRA), 2018. The school has responded with a rationale for the hike but we are not convinced with it and have reached out to the DIOS,” said Sudip Jain, a parent. The school authority, however, has given arguments to defend fee hike. “There’s a significant difference between earlier and new security deposit amounts. Earlier it was Rs 30,000 but newly admitted students have to pay Rs 40,000. So, we asked the parents of those who were admitted earlier to pay Rs 10,000 extra and fill the gap... The imprest amount is being charged in advance for minor expenses...,” said school authorities. “Imprest amount or levelling of security deposit are unheard-of-methods of securing more money...,” said K Arunachalam, general secretary, ANSPA. The DIOS has not responded to the complaint so far.

title: Dismissed SGPC employees begins agitation
og_title: Dismissed SGPC employees begins agitation
content: Amritsar : The 523 dismissed employees of Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee (SGPC) staged demonstration along with their children in front of the SGPC office and also began serial hunger strike demanding their reinstatement.Earlier they had threatened to leave Sikhism and embrace some other religion if they were not reinstated. A committee constituted by SGPC had reported that all of them were recruited in violation of service rules.

title: With 185 candidates in fray, ballot papers to be used in Nizamabad
og_title: With 185 candidates in fray, ballot papers to be used in Nizamabad
content: HYDERABAD: Ballot papers will be used for polling in Nizamabad Lok Sabha constituency in Telangana as 185 candidates, a majority of them farmers, remained in fray for the next month's elections, officials said. Telangana chief minister K Chandrashekhar Rao's daughter K Kavitha is seeking re-election from the constituency, where the Congress has once again fielded Madhu Yaskhi Goud. With the deadline for withdrawal of nominations coming to an end on Thursday, Chief Electoral Officer Rajath Kumar said 185 candidates, including 178 farmers, remained in fray in Nizamabad. Turmeric and red sorghum farmers filed their nominations en masse to highlight their problems, especially with regard to remunerative prices. As Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) can be used for a maximum of 64 candidates, the authorities will have to use ballot papers for polling in Nizamabad. Rajath Kumar said the arrangements for conduct of polling with ballot papers were still under discussion and a final decision would be taken by the Election Commission. He also said a total of 443 candidates were in fray for all 17 Lok Sabha seats in the state, going to polls on April 11. Medak constituency has only 10 candidates.

title: BJP MLA violates poll code again, sent to jail
og_title: BJP MLA violates poll code again, sent to jail
content: INDORE: A court in Neemuch jailed BJP MLA Dilip Singh Parihar and another BJP politician on Thursday for violating the poll code . During last December's assembly polls, too, Parihar was accused of violating the model code and had been warned by the EC . This time, on March 23, the MLA and some partymen organised a bike rally and fireworks show in Neemuch - without taking the administration's permission - to celebrate the renomination of sitting MP Sudhir Gupta for the Mandsaur Lok Sabha seat . An EC flying squad filed a complaint with police, who lodged an FIR against Parihar and four others the next day. On Thursday, the MLA was arrested, along with Neemuch Nagar Palika chief Rakesh Jain and three BJP workers. They moved bail pleas before chief judicial magistrate. The court allowed bail to the workers but rejected pleas of Parihar and Jain who were jailed till April 5.

title: Students protest against VC outside senate meet venue
og_title: Students protest against VC outside senate meet venue
content: SURAT: A group of students held protest outside the Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VSNGU) senate hall on Wednesday and shouted slogans against vice chancellor Shivendra Gupta . The VNSGU senate meeting was held at the administrative building in which two-third members remained absent. Majority of the senators remained absent to register protest against the alleged dictatorial administration by the VC and his aides, sources at the university informed. The group of students started protest soon after the senate meeting began at 12 noon and continued till the senate meeting ended at 3.30 pm. The students initially shouted slogans on stairs of the administrative building and demanded to submit their memorandum. But the VNSGU officials refused to come out to accept the memorandum after which the students rushed to the senate hall pushing away the security. During the protest the students broke a portion of the door. The VNSGU officials called the police which tried to mediate a compromise between university management and agitating students. After discussion, students agreed for a peaceful protest and sat on dharna outside the senate hall with demand to submit memorandum. Police officials, who were trying to control the situation, were also surprised by the approach of the VNSGU officials who refused to come to accept the memorandum. “VNSGU officials refused to allow a number of senators to speak on important issues citing model code of conduct for election. But by organising senate and tabling budget for next year the university has openly violated the code of conduct,” said Bhavesh Rabari , a sanator.

title: I-T raids several ‘individuals’ in Karnataka, CM Kumaraswamy leads protest
og_title: I-T raids several ‘individuals’ in Karnataka, CM Kumaraswamy leads protest
content: BENGALURU: Income-tax raids on aides of top coalition leaders in Karnataka early Thursday brought Congress and JD(S) together once again. Karnataka chief minister HD Kumaraswamy led a joint protest against the central agency, calling the searches 'revenge politics' by the Modi government. The CM addressed Congress-JD(S) workers outside the I-T office here, following raids on aides of top leaders of both parties in the Old Mysuru region. Kumaraswamy singled out BR Balakrishnan, principal chief commissioner of I-T (Karnataka and Goa region), in his fusillade against the department. "We are not against raids. But we protest selective raids conducted in Mysuru, Mandya, Hassan, Shivamogga and Kanakapura. Don't work as agents of the NDA government in its last hours,'' the CM said. The income tax department said no MP, MLA or minister had been covered in the ongoing searches in Karnataka. Though the department, till late Thursday evening, didn't identify individuals whose properties were searched, sources privy to the developments revealed some details. According to sources, 20 premises of eight individuals, including minor irrigation minister CS Puttaraju's relatives in Mandya and Mysuru were searched. "Among those whose properties were raided include a senior JD(S) leader in Bengaluru, a business venture of a relative of former PM HD Deve Gowda in Shivamogga, offices of PWD in Hassan and taluk office in Kanakapura. The office of a Congress leader in Kanakapura too was raided," they said. Kumaraswamy, who had Congress leaders Siddaramaiah , G Parameshwara, DK Shivakumar, Dinesh Gundurao and JD(S) ministers by his side during his address to the workers of the two parties, took exception to raids on government offices in Hassan and Kanakapura. "Raid the Hassan PWD engineer's house, not his office. Visit my office in Vidhana Soudha too. Income-tax officials think they are above reproach and descendants of Harishchandra. Everyone knows how a 'settlement' takes place after a raid,'' he alleged. After predicting on Wednesday that 300 CRPF personnel would arrive in Bengaluru to assist in the raids, a furious Kumaraswamy on Thursday said he, too, can unleash the Anti-Corruption Bureau on tax sleuths. Later, in a tweet, the chief minister accused the PM of misusing the income tax department to threaten Congress and JD(S) leaders during elections. "This is revenge politics; we won't be cowed down by this," he said.

title: Karnataka CM Kumaraswamy leads Congress-JD(S) protest against I-T department after statewide raids
og_title: Karnataka CM Kumaraswamy leads Congress-JD(S) protest against I-T department after statewide raids
content: BENGALURU: Karnataka chief minister H D Kumaraswamy Thursday led a protest by the Congress-JD(S) ruling alliance in front of the Income Tax department here in a furious response to a statewide pre-dawn I-T crackdown on his partymen and others. Raising slogans against Prime Minister Narendra Modi and waving party flags, the Congress and JD(S) activists gathered within hours after the I-T raids with the help of CRPF personnel at 15 to 20 places including Bengaluru, Mandya, Mysuru, Hassan and Shivamogga. Congress and JD(S) activists who tried to storm the Income Tax office were arrested and later released as the protest on the ever busy Queens Road resulted in chock-a-block with hundreds of vehicles stuck in the traffic jam. The ruling alliance was particularly angry as they alleged that the I-T raids were carried out on JD(S) leaders overseeing the elections of Kumaraswamy's son Nikhil Kumaraswamy in Mandya and nephew Prajwal Revanna in Hassan. Taking on the Modi government in the first such protest by the state chief minister against a central department in recent memory, Kumaraswamy lashed out at it for "misusing" the I-T department and other central agencies. Terming the Centre's behaviour as an "assault" on the federal system, he alleged that Modi has been misusing the constitutional bodies, which shows his "dictatorial streak." "We are not opposed to raids. We are opposing it because it is restricted to a few political parties in the opposition. They want to threaten them," a visibly angry Kumaraswamy said. The crackdown came within a day after he claimed last night that the I-T raids had been planned from 5 am on Thursday and he would not be deterred and would protest against it like his West Bengal counterpart Mamata Banerjee . In an unprecedented showdown with the Modi government, Banerjee had sat on a dharna after the CBI tried to quiz Kolkata police commissioner Rajeev Kumar in connection with Saradha and Rose Valley Chit Fund scams. "They are out to frighten us but the fact is the BJP is shaken and wants to win election by intimidating us. We are not the ones who get scared," the chief minister said. Strongly defending its action, the I-T department said its activities should not be politicised, personalised or trivialised. "We request that the activities of the income tax department should not be politicised, personalised or trivialised. In particular, statements which sound like an incitement to physical violence issued by persons holding very responsible posts are deeply deplorable," it added. The searches were carried out on a wide range of professions and businesses including bureaucrats, breweries, MNCs, mining barons, diagnostic centres, trusts, educational institutions, medical colleges, real estate, fisheries, and film industry and including "politically exposed persons," it said. The department also said in a release that no MP, MLA or minister had been covered in the searches and they were being carried out on the basis of credible information. "A BJP leader sends list of people to Amit Shah, who eventually forwards it to Balakrishnan (principal chief commissioner of income tax department (Karnataka-Goa region) to carry out raids. Balakrishnan is acting as an agent of BJP. It seems that he wants a post-retirement position such as governor of some state," Kumaraswamy said. Kumaraswamy questioned BJP state chief B S Yeddyurappa as to whether he could win elections without money. He also said for the first time the I-T officials raided government offices too, such as PWD office in Hassan and Tahsildar office in Kanakapura. The coalition partners said the raids were on people, who were monitoring the electioneering of Nikhil Kumaraswamy and Prajwal Revanna from the Gowda clan, targeting state minor irrigation minister C S Puttaraju and his nephew Ashok, who is a district panchayat member in Mysuru. The raids were also carried out at the residences of PWD minister H D Revanna's close associates Narayana Reddy, Ashwath Gowda and Raya Gowda in Hassan, IT sources said. Revanna's son and former Prime Minister H D Deve Gowda's grandson Prajjwal is contesting from Hassan Lok Sabha seat. Nikhil Kumaraswamy and Prajwal Revanna are testing political waters for the first time under the tutelage of Kumaraswamy and PWD minister H D Revanna. Former chief minister and Congress Legislature Party leader Siddaramaiah questioned the timing of raids and said they could have been done a month before the election. "But when the election dates were announced such action raises many eyebrows," he said. At Hassan, Revanna said, "So long as I have the blessings of Sringeri Sharadamba and Shankaracharya, nothing will happen...Anybody conspiring against me or trying black magic will be destroyed. I am so well protected." Yeddyurappa rubbished the charges, saying the Income Tax department was doing its duty and it should not be linked with politics. He wondered why the Congress and the JD(S) were giving it a political colour when it was against some bureaucrats, contractors and others and not the MPs, MLAs and ministers. According to the I-T department, the searches have resulted in collecting credible evidence on tax evasion. The searches on "politically exposed persons" have covered their entire range of the political spectrum, it said. The I-T department also said CRPF personnel being used for the searches had not been flown from outside the state and they were requisitioned from the state police following the normal protocol. In Video: Karnataka CM Kumaraswamy, Dy CM Parameshwara stage protest outside Income Tax office in Bengaluru

title: No RTE funds, school says will close down; parents protest
og_title: No RTE funds, school says will close down; parents protest
content: DEHRADUN: Parents of over 300 students studying in Doon Public Academy, a school on Sahastradhara Road, staged a protest against the school claiming that the administration is closing down the school despite the education department’s orders. The school has over 300 students, 54 of which are enrolled under the Right to Education (RTE) Act, meaning that their fee is paid by the government. However, as reported by TOI earlier, the school had announced this month that they will not induct students for the next session and asked parents to look for other schools since fund shortage has pushed the school on verge of closure. The school administration has said that they have not received funds under the RTE from the government for over two years. Following this, the education department issued a notice to the school asking them to continue for at least a year. The parents, however, alleged that the school has once again asked them to look for other options since the school will not be functioning after March. Arif Khan, president of National Association for Parents and Students’ Rights (NAPSR) told TOI that the school has given an ultimatum to the parents, laid off teachers and even started selling furniture. “This is in clear violation of the notice by the education department. First, the school declared that they will close down without even informing the students and now they are violating the notice. We have asked the district magistrate to file a complaint against the school,” he said. The officials of the education department, meanwhile, said that they have asked the school to make arrangements for the students to shift to other schools or continue for over a year. “We will look into the matter but we have asked the school to make arrangements for students in other school. Only then they can close down, else they should function for at least a year,” said Asha Rani Painyuli, chief education officer, Dehradun . There are over 95,000 students in various schools enrolled under the RTE but the education department hasn’t released funds of over Rs 200 crore for the past two years, forcing at least two schools to send ultimatum to students.

title: Delhi University, teachers spar over course change
og_title: Delhi University, teachers spar over course change
content: NEW DELHI: Following teachers’ opposition to the constitution of the course revision committee, Delhi University said on Wednesday that the revised undergraduate curriculum would be approved by various statutory bodies of DU and suggestions would be sought from experts at national and international levels. DU also announced that from the academic session 2019-20, all students joining undergraduate courses under Non-Collegiate Women Education Board (NCWEB) and School of Open Learning (SOL) would follow the revised curriculum based on Learning Outcome-based Curriculum Framework (LOCF). Teachers have objected, saying it was replacing the committee on courses, which is duly notified in the university statue. They also expressed concern over the selection of “three best teachers” by the head of each department as this, they claimed, would lead to bias. Also, no college teacher was made part of it, they pointed out. Calling the decision “thoughtless”, Delhi University Teachers’ Association ( DUTA ) said on Wednesday that it “has learned that the vice-chancellor has decided to abandon any credible academic application of mind and impose the framework (LOCF) that seems to be thoughtlessly derived from a controversial and widely criticised outcome-based model prevalent in the state-funded US universities”. It’s unfortunate that VC Yogesh Tyagi has not allowed UG course revisions proposed by several departments to be tabled in the academic council for over a year now, DUTA added. “It is disturbing to see that the notified schedule for LOCF is nothing short of a hurried and insincere exercise” in which DU expects the entire revision process to take place in three months, it added. However, the university claimed that this “landmark move” would benefit close to seven lakh undergraduate students from the 2019-20 session. The revision committee has developed a dashboard to facilitate the process, according to a statement issued by university registrar Tarun Das. The dashboard will enable teachers concerned to work collectively and share their inputs online, reducing considerably the need of frequent meetings, it stated.

title: Art for ‘voiceless’, an exhibition of protest
og_title: Art for ‘voiceless’, an exhibition of protest
content: CHENNAI: Rambha considered herself lucky when she married the man she loved. But he turned out to be abusive and one day poured kerosene over her before setting her on fire. She survived, but the transwoman was unable to get legal justice. “There is no succour for people like us. So I left Mumbai and came back to Chennai,” says Rambha. Her story is one of more than 100 handwritten testimonials to be displayed as part of ‘Ask them to Shut Up! because the voiceless need to speak!’, an art show by transexuals at British Council from March 29 to April 14. Organized by Sahodari Foundation founder Kalki Subramaniam, it will feature 25 artworks, including acrylic and watercolour paintings. “While the exhibition doesn’t have a specific theme it does have a larger context, which is resistance against judgements, transphobia , stereotyping, and discrimination,” says Kalki, an activist and artist who also conducts art workshops for members of the community. “The name of the exhibition is in itself a protest. We are asking people who discriminate against other people because of gender and sexual orientation to shut up so our voices can be heard,” she says. The highlight, which is part of the foundation’s Transhearts project, is The #MeToo Files. The large acrylic painting shows a transsexual, spitting fury and teeth gritting in rage, clapping. Around the painting are testimonials by transsexual and non-binary people who have endured violence and been shamed by homophobic and transphobic people. “They could be their friends, relatives, or members of the general public,” says Kalki, who with Sowndharya Gopi, collected these stories from people across Tamil Nadu , Kerala, Puducherry, Karnataka and West Bengal over the last year. “Each person made imprints of their hands in red on the handmade paper and then wrote their own story,” says Kalki. “In college, when I was using the hostel bathroom, a boy broke open the door and sexually harassed me. There were other people around but they just laughed at me. It happened when I was 21 and it haunted me for years. I lost my self-respect and was tormented,” says Kalki. The idea is also to help survivors heal themselves. “The participants wanted the world to know what happened to them and want to ensure it never happens to anyone ever again,” says Kalki. “Also, many of them hadn’t spoken about their traumatic experiences to anyone and it’s an outlet for their emotions...”

title: Chandigarh: Private college teachers to intensify protest
og_title: Chandigarh: Private college teachers to intensify protest
content: CHANDIGARH: Teachers of private colleges of Chandigarh staged a protest on Wednesday and have decided to go on strike during university examinations and lead a march to the office of vice-president of India, as he is the chancellor of Panjab University , if their demands are not met. According to the teachers, certain benefits permissible under pay scale notification are being denied to them. This includes an increment under CAS, while moving from academic grade pay (AGP) Rs 6,000 to AGP Rs 7,000 and from AGP Rs 7,000 to AGP Rs 8,000. "We have decided today that if our demands are not met, we will intensify our protest. We will go on strike during university examinations and would lead a mass deputation to the vice-president of India since he is the chancellor of the university. If our demands are not met before April 28, we will meet the chancellor here at the convocation of the university," said Dr Madhu Sharma, secretary, Chandigarh District Council, Punjab and Chandigarh College Teachers' Union (PCCTU). The protesting teachers met the education secretary Dr B L Sharma and he has given assurance to the teachers that their demands would be met. The demands include counting of past service according to UGC regulations issue and adoption/implementation of clarifications issued by MHRD with reference to UGC Pay Scales as it is the final authority in such matters. The teachers have pointed out that the increment that was due between January 2, 2006 and June 30, 2006 was denied. They also said revision of pay of part-time teachers to Rs 21,600 is being withheld. "We believe that these issues are strongly supported by the notifications and clarifications issued by the competent authorities, UGC Regulations 2010 and the law of the land emerging out of the judgements in different cases," added Dr Madhu.
